descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class is designed as a workshop-practicum in the development of good writing habits as well as dealing with the specific challenges of writing about music. Reading assignments will consist of pedagogical texts about writing and exemplary music scholarship that will serve as a basis for discussion. The goal for the course is to provide you with practical skills that will enhance your writing facility and help you actually enjoy the experience of writing. It will also show how writing can be used to clarify your thinking about musical experience.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class introduces students to ways of approaching and engaging with music from a variety of different cultures, situating it within a broader framework of music's multifaceted relationship with history, society, and politics. Students will examine these interrelations and, along the way, develop a critical vocabulary that enables us to describe and discuss both the music and our musical experiences. Assigned readings and listening examples will be explored in class discussion, with student assessment based on participation, listening quizzes, short essays, and weekly journals.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Mark Evan Bonds, Listen to This, 4th edition. Pearson, 2018. ISBN: 978-0134419510.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to provide students with the tools and vocabulary to discuss, study, and write about music as a social and cultural experience. We will consider musical examples?popular, classical, experimental, and traditional?from a range of genres, cultures, times, and places. We will begin by discussing different definitions of music and tools of music analysis, and then go on to topics including aesthetics, nation, gender, ethnicity, religion, dance, film, theater, concert life, technology, and experimentalism. Student grades will be comprised of active participation, brief weekly writing assignments, a midterm assignment, and a final project. Weekly writing assignments will ask students to reflect on required reading and listening assignments in advance of class meetings.This class is open to all students; no prior musical training is required.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Steven Cornelius and Mary Natvig, Music: A Social Experience, 2nd edition. Routledge, 2018. ISBN: 978-0415789332

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class is designed to help those with an interest in Western art music to develop their listening skills and to gain historical awareness that will help them to engage more critically with what they hear, whether in the concert hall or beyond it. Students are expected to complete reading and listening assignments ahead of class meetings, engage and participate in discussions and prepare for quizzes. In addition, students will be asked to prepare two short presentations for the class on given topics.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: R. Larry Todd, Discovering Music. Oxford University Press, 2018. ISBN: 9780190255107.

name: Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: For decades, the Beatles have been among the most respected and beloved bands throughout the world. But who were the Beatles, and how might they continue to be relevant today? This class aims to understand how the band developed over the course of their career, while allowing students to examine the impact music can have on society and culture. We will spend a generous amount of time with the music itself, listening to and discussing every studio album, as well as demos and previously unreleased recordings. We will look at how the compositional style of the band changed over time, with regards to lyrics, melody, harmony, instrumentation, uses of studio technology, and more. We will also use writings, interviews, and videos of the Beatles, as well as writings about the band by contemporary and current commentators/scholars, to further enhance our understanding of the group. Students' grades will be comprised of active participation, reading and listening assignments, in-class analysis and discussion, and written work. No prior knowledge of music is required to enroll, and students who know the band's music by heart and those who have never heard a single Beatles song are equally welcome.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: No materials required for purchase. Assigned reading and other materials will be available on CANVAS.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the development of the symphony as a musical genre from its antecedents in the seventeenth century to its present-day iterations. By discussing both large-scale trends and pivotal works of specific composers, the course will explore not only the evolution of musical components, but also the genre's relationship with the cultural, economic, and political realms. Students will gain a working knowledge of key attributes of the genre during various time periods as well as an understanding of the forces that contributed to these developments, and will leave the class equipped to continue engaging confidently with symphonic literature on their own.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No materials required for purchase. Assigned readings will be available as PDFs on CANVAS.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The primary goal of this class is to gain fluency in the vocabulary and elements of common-practice tonal music: its notation, construction, and modes of analysis. While emphasis will be placed on harmonic structure and function, through analysis exercises and ear training, we will also discuss other factors that contribute to our enjoyment and understanding of music, such as rhythm, meter, and melodic construction. This class is for non-music majors only.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Jane Piper Clendenning and Elizabeth West Marvin, The Musician's Guide to Theory and Analysis (3rd edition; W.W. Norton, 2016): Coursebook (ISBN: 9780393263053) and Workbook (ISBN: 9780393264623).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Non-technical, chronology from first recordings (1917) through early ?40s peak popularity. Rise of major soloists from Armstrong through Christian; early New Orleans and Chicago music and convergence with commercial dance bands (Henderson, Ellington, Goodman); role of race in context of rigid social segregation. Emphasis on the pre-1942 repertoire (see www.jazzstandards.com). Non-jazz majors welcome. Knowledge of the American Song Book useful.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Non-Bienen and non-Jazz majors may register with permission of the instructor. Contact Prof. John McDonough (john.mcdonough1@northwestern.edu) to request registration permission.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: As an introduction to the basic tools of resources in music research, the class includes study of general library resources, bibliographies of composers, music, music literature, and music sources. Students will experience a broad view of music reference tools and editions of music. Key projects in the class are providing an appropriate bibliography for a selected research topic, and selecting an appropriate performing edition for practical use based on a variety of sources.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a survey of the resources and methods of music research and writing. It covers skills and ideas that can be applied and built upon in other courses, as well as throughout a career in music.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students in Doctor of Musical Arts degree program or Ph.D. in composition.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- A familiarity with core music research tools and an awareness of various types of print and online resources that are available

- Abilities to identify pertinent books, articles, and other materials and then obtain items held locally, available online, and from other libraries

- Comprehension of principles and guidelines for documenting sources according to proper citation style

- Awareness of critical concepts and approaches in music scholarship

- Knowledge of fundamental strategies for planning and completing an original research project

Print, new: $69.95

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: When we talk about "film music," we usually focus on scores for narrative fiction films, but music has also played a significant role - if often a controversial one - in non-fiction film since the very beginning of the cinema. This course will examine documentary films from a variety of periods and approaches to the genre, as well as films initially presented as documentary that now appear to us as propaganda. Some of the material to be addressed may include the "actuality" shorts and "city symphony" films of the silent era; Depression-era documentaries scored by Virgil Thomson and Aaron Copland; World War II propaganda from the United States (the Why We Fight newsreel series), England (Humphrey Jennings's Listen to Britain), and Nazi Germany (Leni Riefenstahl's Triumph of the Will); rock documentaries of the 1960s directed by D.A. Pennebaker (Don't Look Back) and David and Albert Maysles (Gimme Shelter); Philip Glass's scores of the 1980s to films by Godfrey Reggio (Koyanisqaatsi) and Errol Morris (The Thin Blue Line); and related media such as news and "reality TV." In all cases, we will consider both the aesthetics of music in relation to the documentary image and the ethics of how music is employed to persuade the spectator and to impact the presentation of "reality" on screen.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No materials required for purchase

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores the music, writing, and collaborations of John Cage (1912-1992) through archival materials held in Northwestern University Library's Special Collections. It will introduce students to the rich historical documentation held on site as well as develop students' skills using archival material. The course will focus largely on John Cage's collaborations with other musicians and artists including Merce Cunningham, David Tudor, Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Morton Feldman, and Charlotte Moorman. The class will meet in Deering Library 208 (2nd floor Reading Room) and is limited to 15 students. All students must be familiar with music notation.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course considers music and its intellectual and social contexts in sixteenth-century England, an era that continues to inspire the modern imagination. Under the Tudor monarchs (1485-1603), English literary and musical culture flourished as never before, and many works from the period are still regularly read and performed. The Tudor dynasty was marked by rapid and often violent social and political change, as well as by a shifting place in global politics and cultural exchange. The era also witnessed the establishment of the modern Church of England and the professional theatre, institutions in which music was essential and often controversial. The reign of the last Tudor, Elizabeth I, is often considered to be the "Golden Age" of English music as well as drama. Because many of today's "early music" performing ensembles include Elizabethan works among their repertory, period film and television quote Tudor music, contemporary composers reference it, and both Renaissance fairs and high school madrigal dinners tend to be quite partial to sixteenth-century English music, we will also consider modern interpretations of Tudor music. Students will be able to work on performance-based final projects as well as conventional research papers and original compositions.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: When opera entered the 20th century, it had to face the legacy of Verdi and Wagner, the increasing consolidation of a performing repertoire, the new currents of modernism, and the rise of cinema and other mass media entertainments, among other challenges. This course will examine how opera composers (and singers, directors, and audiences) have grappled with the genre - and the question of its continued cultural relevance - from 1900 to the present. Operas to be studied may include works by Debussy, Puccini, Strauss, Janá?ek, Weill, Berg, Gershwin, Britten, Stravinsky, Stockhausen, Monk and others. Beyond repertoire, we will consider shifts in how opera has been staged, sung, marketed, and mediated. Students will be expected to attend a "Live in HD" transmission from the Metropolitan Opera and/or other local performances of relevant repertoire.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: When we talk about "film music," we usually focus on scores for narrative fiction films, but music has also played a significant role - if often a controversial one - in non-fiction film since the very beginning of the cinema. This course will examine documentary films from a variety of periods and approaches to the genre, as well as films initially presented as documentary that now appear to us as propaganda. Some of the material to be addressed may include the "actuality" shorts and "city symphony" films of the silent era; Depression-era documentaries scored by Virgil Thomson and Aaron Copland; World War II propaganda from the United States (the Why We Fight newsreel series), England (Humphrey Jennings's Listen to Britain), and Nazi Germany (Leni Riefenstahl's Triumph of the Will); rock documentaries of the 1960s directed by D.A. Pennebaker (Don't Look Back) and David and Albert Maysles (Gimme Shelter); Philip Glass's scores of the 1980s to films by Godfrey Reggio (Koyanisqaatsi) and Errol Morris (The Thin Blue Line); and related media such as news and "reality TV." In all cases, we will consider both the aesthetics of music in relation to the documentary image and the ethics of how music is employed to persuade the spectator and to impact the presentation of "reality" on screen.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores the music, writing, and collaborations of John Cage (1912-1992) through archival materials held in Northwestern University Library's Special Collections. It will introduce students to the rich historical documentation held on site as well as develop students' skills using archival material. The course will focus largely on John Cage's collaborations with other musicians and artists including Merce Cunningham, David Tudor, Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Morton Feldman, and Charlotte Moorman. The class will meet in Deering Library 208 (2nd floor Reading Room) and is limited to 15 students. All students must be familiar with music notation.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Seminar in Opera: Opera seria and its sources

This graduate seminar focuses on 18th-century Italian opera seria as performative spectacle rooted in neo-classicism. Focusing upon operas by Hasse and Jommelli with librettos by Metastasio, as well as comparative examples from Handel, J. C. Bach, and others, the course will explore the sources of opera seria librettos in the literature of classical antiquity, engage recent musicological scholarship about the voice, body, and operatic performativity, contextualize operatic topics with Enlightenment thought, and explore the notated and improvisational conventions of galant music. Over the quarter, each student will research the history of a specific libretto by Metastasio, explore performance practice, compare operatic treatment of history with visual representations of the same topic, and develop a paper on related material. Students will also learn about challenges to editing eighteenth-century music and prepare an original edition of an operatic excerpt. Knowledge of Italian helpful but not essential.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Open to graduate music students (PhD, MM in Music Studies, or DMA

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The learning objectives of this graduate course include: understanding the basic history, formal structures, and performance contexts of 18th-century Italian opera; gaining research skills working with Italian language librettos and opera manuscripts; understanding the challenges of reviving an 18th-century opera or operatic excerpts; becoming familiar with trends in recent research on 18th-century music; editing 18th-century music from images of original manuscripts

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is intended to help students in all music academic fields, composition, and performance think about the role of editors, editions, performers, and performance in presenting music in all media. We will consider original musical works in score and recorded formats, and the processes surrounding ways in which they've been modified over time for different performers, performances, and audiences as well as presented as the original creators knew them. Each student will create an original edition of a chosen work or linked set of works, using editorial methods covered in the course, and we will consider histories and purposes of notation and other technologies for presenting music; composition students may develop original notation if they so choose. Scholarly material and methodologies will be drawn from all fields of musical inquiry, from critical theory, and from the growing area of textual histories and cultures. We will visit the University Archives and Newberry Library to look at original, unedited music; and consider recording and playback technologies.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All textbooks will be available in the Library and additional readings will be posted to Canvas. Students may wish to purchase Stephen Davies's Musical Works and Performances: A Philosophical Exploration (ISBN 0199274118), James Grier's The Critical Editing of Music (ISBN 0521558638), and/or Christopher Small's Musicking (ISBN 9780819522573), but they will be placed on library reserve.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of this seminar will be to explore the relationship among ensemble members, between ensembles and conductors, and between ensembles and audiences. This will be an opportunity to examine elements of and question assumptions about indicators of ensemble/conductor performance, aspects of ensemble/conductor pedagogy, and the manner in which ensembles develop and communicate.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: TBD

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course serves as an introduction to composition for students of any musical background. Like painters, writers, architects, sculptors, and other artists, composers need to model their work in some way. To that end, students will be asked to maintain a compositional "sketchbook," documenting sonic and musical ideas in a recorded format. Students will also be asked to reflect on their work in writing as a way of refining their ideas. Proficiency with a DAW (such as Logic, ProTools, Ableton Live, Garageband, Audacity, etc.) is helpful but not required. The sketchbook will function as a safe space for experimentation, and ideas explored here may or may not grow into long-term projects. Because of notation's importance as a tool for refining compositional strategies, students may be asked to transcribe long-term projects, in whatever form feels most comfortable (conventional score notation, tablature, text scores, graphic scores, or other method). Students are required to come to class with an open and inclusive mindset, as well as a willingness to share their work in order to encourage in-class critical listening and discussion. Previous knowledge of music creation and/or music theory is not required, but because of the hands-on nature of the class, proficiency - not virtuosity - on a musical instrument, acoustic (including voice) or electric, is required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Mozart's operas belong to the greatest masterpieces of Western art music. In this course we will focus on five of his Viennese operas, representing two different genres: opera buffa (Le nozze di Figaro, Don Giovanni, Così fan tutte) and Singspiel (Die Entführung aus dem Serail, Die Zauberflöte). Understanding their plots and learning their music will be necessary prerequisites of your fruitful participation in class discussion. The discussion will situate the operas in the context of their respective genres and broader socio-cultural context of late-eighteenth-century Vienna and it will delve into their structure in order to tease out their meaning and expression. In the course of this analytical inquiry we will benefit from recent advances in the field of historically informed music theory, including deployment of genres and styles (topics), building blocks of eighteenth-century harmonic language (schemata), expressive import of meter and key characteristics. We will also touch upon problems of German and Italian text setting.

The course will be of interest for students of music theory, musicology, vocal and instrumental performance, composition and conducting.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the class the student will be expected to have become familiar with the five Mozart's operas selected for class discussion and have developed an understanding of how their music achieves its expressive effect and acquires extra-musical meaning through the creative deployment of eighteenth-century conventions.

Independent study: In addition to readings, it will include preliminary analyses of musical examples to be discussed.

Writing assignmentsListening exercisesPresentationsDemonstrationsDiscussion

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Music Theory 335/435: Music and the Body

Professor Mark J. Butler
Program in Music Theory & Cognition, Bienen School of Music
Affiliate Faculty, Department of Performance Studies; MA Program in Sound Arts and Industries

Fall 2019, TR 9:30-10:50

This seminar explores relationships between music and human bodies. Drawing from a wide range of scholarship in music studies and other disciplines, it will consider topics such as rhythm and meter, dance, movement, gesture, embodied meaning, embodied cognition, entrainment, electronic dance music, the body and technology, disability studies, feminism, the history of music theory, philosophy, and mind-body dualism. The course will be reading-intensive, culminating in a substantial paper based on independent research.

Graduate students with a particular interest in the topic from Ph.D. programs outside of the Bienen School of Music are welcome. The extent to which the course will engage with technical issues in music theory will vary. Many readings will be focused on cultural, social, and historical concerns, while others will consider specific musical aspects (e.g., meter) and compositions. Regardless of musical background, students should be ready and willing to engage with both kinds of discussion. Interested students with questions about the suitability of the course are encouraged to contact the professor (mark-butler@northwestern.edu).

For students in the Bienen School of Music, undergraduate prerequisites are successful completion of the theory core (Mus_Thry 111/211); for graduate students, passage of the diagnostic or successful completion of the theory review course. There is no required textbook.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class presents music-analytic concepts and methods focused on chromatic music, primarily in the Western art music tradition from the years 1830 to 1930. Readings will be drawn from historical sources and modern treatises. Works to be analyzed will include compositions of Schumann, Brahms, Liszt, Wolf, Wagner, Faure, and Ravel. The interaction of melodic, harmonic, and rhythmic forces in shaping the "flow" of music for performer and listener will be a primary focus. Evaluation will be based on daily homework assignments, class participation, and a final analysis paper. DM students may, depending on their curriculum, be obliged to observe the 15-page paper requirement.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Paper, final: 30% of final grade
Attendance: Two 'free' absences are allowed, after which each will reduce the final grade by 5 points.
Class participation: 10% of final grade
Homework: 60% of final grade. The two lowest grades are dropped.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No class materials need be purchased; all will be posted through Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Expectation is an aspect of listening experience that has attracted lots of attention from music theorists since the second half of the twentieth century. After the pioneering work of Leonard B. Meyer and his students, Eugene Narmour and Robert O. Gjerdingen, further research of musical expectation was undertaken by cognitive study of music and music psychology, generating an ever-growing number of influential publications. In this seminar we will reconstruct this stream of research from its dawn until today and try to assess its future prospects. To this end, we will retrace the questions that have been asked by earlier authors and appraise the answers that have been proposed. The questions will include: What is expectation? How does it arise? How does it inform musical meaning and emotion? What musical parameters does it concern? Is it determined by structure of these parameters? Or is it just a matter of statistics? What types of knowledge does it engage? How does it relate to consciousness and memory?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the class you will gain understanding of mechanisms involved in musical expectation, appreciate the role of expectation in listening experience and become familiar with analytical methods that allow us to trace expectations generated by different musical parameters.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Seminar: One seminar (2h 50min) per week.
Independent study: Preparation of the final paper.
Readings: Extensive weekly readings (required and optional).
Class participationCase studiesWriting assignmentsPresentations: Research presentation.
Discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Paper, final: 50%
Presentations: Research presentation (20%)
AttendanceOther: Abstract and bibliography for the final paper (10%)
Class participation: Class participation and attendance (10%)
Discussion section: Discussion board (10%)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbooks required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Goals of the course:
1. Develop more systematic ways of thinking about music cognition.
2. Become familiar with important issues, investigative techniques, and literature in music cognition.
3. Know the basics of cognitive psychology.
4. Be able to read a psychological article on music from a standard journal and understand it reasonably well.
5. Know the main journals and texts in which one is likely to find materials of interest to students of music cognition.


Structure of the course:
1. Unit I (one wk): Basics of cognitive psychology and auditory perception
2. Unit II (two wks): The structure of music and music cognition
3. Unit III (two wks): Musical and emotion
4. Unit IV (two wks): Music and the body
5. Unit IV (two wks): Musical performance
6. Unit V (one wk): Creativity and music's relation to other domains

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: This course focuses on primary readings, mostly published articles. A wide range of articles will be used, from cognitive psychology, music theory, and artificial intelligence. Both primary and secondary sources will be used. The typical load should be about 5 articles per week.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: For those wishing a single-volume overview, I recommend (but will not require) Psychology of Music: From Sound to Significance, by Siu-Lan Tan, Peter Pfordresher, and Rom Harre (Psychology Press, 2010)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides students with the social science tools needed to solve organizational problems and influence the actions of individuals, groups and organizations. It prepares managers to understand how to best organize and motivate the human capital of the firm, manage social networks and alliances, and execute strategic change. This is accomplished through knowledge of decision making, team leadership, social capital, strategic negotiation, influence skills, emotional intelligence, political dynamics, corporate culture and leading change. Law students will gain greater insight into organizations they work in and with - including client firms and multidisciplinary teams involved in transactions, litigation, and more. The curriculum is ?flipped classroom' style and includes experiential learning methods, class discussion, interactive lectures, case analyses and real-world practical application.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: JDMBA students are not permitted to take this class at the law school, but must take it in their 2J year at Kellogg.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students in BA Section 2 may not use electronic devices in class; as a result, please purchase a hard copy of the casebook and statutory supplement. We will focus on the Delaware General Corporation Law as the statutory framework (this is included in the casebook's statutory supplement); a general description of most statutory provisions will be provided on Canvas as a guide for students. In addition, a set of mostly-optional quizzes will be posted on Canvas for use in assessing your individual understanding of assigned materials. Finally, Section 2 BA students will learn about the practice of business-related law in a transactional/counseling setting through an interview with a practicing lawyer.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of this course, you will (i) be familiar with the role of law in structuring the relationships among owners, management and other stakeholders in modern business organizations (i.e., what does the law do and aim to do in this context?), (ii) have a basic working knowledge of the fiduciary obligations of managers in business organizations, and especially with regard to corporate directors and controlling shareholders, as well as of the role of law in enforcing these obligations (i.e., what are the fiduciary obligations of managers and controlling stockholders, and how are they enforced?), (iii) have a general understanding of the basic advantages and disadvantages of three major forms of business association in use today (partnership, limited liability company and corporation), (iv) have gained sufficient familiarity with the Delaware General Corporation Law to provide a foundation for reading and interpreting statutory provisions governing corporations and other business organizations and (v) be familiar with certain aspects of the practice and roles of transactional business lawyers.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In-class Q&A: All students are "on-call" each class period and are expected to be prepared for every class. My end of the bargain is to prepare a list of questions and hypotheticals each week to allow you to anticipate the lines of questioning.

Casebook problem write-ups: As a means of formative assessment, you will submit three 1000-word ungraded written responses to casebook problems. These problems are a means of synthesizing and applying what you have learned in the chapter, and present an opportunity to explore employment law themes and policy considerations on a broader level. They also present opportunities to practice the same skills you will use on the final exam.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Pre-Req - Be a second-semester 1L, 2L, 3L or LLM student.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, you will understand how common law tort, contract, competition, and constitutional law doctrines apply in the workplace, and you will understand and be able to apply the major federal anti-discrimination theories and frameworks. You will also understand the policy objectives that stitch together the patchwork quilt of employment law, and you will develop the practical skills of risk management and claim evaluation. Above all, you will sharpen your analytical thinking and legal reasoning skills.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureReadingsProblem setsClass participationWriting assignmentsDiscussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Exam, finalAttendanceClass participationI will assess class participation on a daily basis. After the exams are graded, I will factor in participation assessments. If, based on your exam, you are on the margin between two grades, and your participation has been regular and robust, I will move you up to the next grade level.

The final exam is the only graded assignment in the course. It will be open-book. The exam will be designed as a three-hour exam; however, I will give you 3 hours and 45 minutes to complete the exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
HARDCOVER CASEBOOK: Timothy P. Glynn, Rachel Arnow-Richman, Charles A. Sullivan, Employment Law: Private Ordering and Its Limitations, Aspen Publishers, Third Edition, 2015, ISBN# 9781454860839
**Notes: The 4th edition was recently published, but its changes are not substantial enough to warrant everyone buying a new textbook. I will supplement with pdf cases as needed.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
I offer these suggestions in the simple spirit of saving you time searching for helpful hornbooks or study aids. You do not need to consult or purchase any of these sources, and I will not expect anyone to have read them.

? Jeffrey M. Hirsch et al., Understanding Employment Law (LexisNexis 2d ed. 2013) (from LexisNexis' "Understanding" Series).

? Peggie R. Smith et al., Principles of Employment Law (West 2018) (from West's "Concise Hornbook" Series).

? Employment Discrimination: Examples and Explanations (Aspen 3d ed. 2017).

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course will explore some practical aspects relating to the U.S. commercial banking industry. Banks perform a unique role in the economic sphere and unlike most other private enterprises, are subject to extensive and comprehensive regulation and supervision. Student teams will participate in workshops/simulations involving issues in the formation of a new bank, the formation of a holding company, and the subsequent sale of the organization to another financial institution. Evaluations will be based on participation, including producing power points and business plans, class presentations and negotiations. An investment banker will participate in the M&A segment. A knowledge of corporate issues is recommended, but not required. As a foundation to the various simulations/workshops completed during this course, students will first be acquainted with the fundamentals of the current regulatory systems governing the operation of commercial financial institutions.

Additional Course Information: Counts toward Business Enterprise Concentration, Satisfies Experiential Learning degree requirement

descriptions.value:
Dear ACCT430/BUSCOM 649 Students,

All students taking ACCT 430 or BUSCOM 649 must demonstrate basic proficiency in fundamental accounting concepts and accounting mechanics prior to taking the class ACCT 430/BUSCOM 649: Accounting for Decision Making. Students satisfy this requirement by completing the online Accounting Essentials and receiving a passing score on the Accounting Essentials Final Examination. The Accounting Essentials Final Examination must be completed by 11:59pm CDT on Sunday, September 22. The exam will count for 5% of your grade in ACCT 430/BUSCOM 649.

To access the course materials, the practice exam and the final exam please self-enroll using the link below:

https://canvas.northwestern.edu/enroll/HWEGGR

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The primary objective of the course is to give students a thorough grounding in the antitrust law of the United States. An important secondary objective is to introduce students to economic reasoning in law more generally.

This course will cover the fundamentals of Federal antitrust law. Topics covered include the basic structure of antitrust analysis (market definition, market assessment, remedies). Doctrines covered include those relating to price-fixing and other horizontal conspiracies in restraint of trade, vertical price and non-price restraints, boycotts, exclusive dealing and tying arrangements, price discrimination; monopolies, monopolization, and mergers and acquisitions.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar will examine the history and evolution of legal protections for abortion, contraception and other reproductive health care. We will look at state and federal constitutional, statutory and common law theories used to secure and protect these rights. We will explore current threats and growing barriers to access, including ever-expanding assertions of religious beliefs to limit access to reproductive health care. We will also look at advocacy strategies for addressing those threats and barriers. Grades are based on a final paper and class participation.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course, students will understand:

(i) the impact of changes in the legal industry on law departments and the relationship between law departments and law firms

(ii) the fundamental principles that underlie effective management of a law department and management of outside counsel

(iii) the roles and responsibilities of General Counsel and Chief Compliance Officers and the duties they owe to their stakeholders

(iv) the roles and responsibilities of several functional areas within a law department, including M&A, intellectual property and litigation

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course provides a comprehensive treatment of the state and federal law pertaining to trading based on material nonpublic information, and related legal requirements and prohibitions.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: There are no prerequisites.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of this course, students will have a comprehensive knowledge of the state common law and federal law of insider trading. This will provide them with the ability to analyze whether a specific scenario violates the law and in particular exposes any participant to a successful enforcement action by the Securities and Exchange Commission. In addition, students should be able to determine whether, as a situation unfolds, any participant in the matter can safely proceed with a communication or transaction or whether the participant should refrain from proceeding because the conduct seems likely to violate the prohibition on trading on the basis of material nonpublic information or on unlawful tipping.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureReadingsClass participationDiscussion

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Coursepak (Chapter 7 of Nagy et al. Securities Litigation and Enforcement (2017); Bainbridge, Insider Trading Law and Policy: Concepts and Insights (2014); cases and other materials posted on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None to be purchased; numerous included in the syllabus by citation or posted on Canvas

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This course is given in alternate years with Securities Regulation Liability and Enforcement. That course covers some of the material covered here, in much less depth and breadth. Students who take this course may also take the liability and enforcement course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course focuses on the U.S. federal income tax treatment of corporations and their shareholders, including both "C" corporations (the income of which is taxed at both the corporate and shareholder levels) and "S" corporations (the income of which is generally taxed only at the shareholder level on a "pass-through" basis). The course is designed to provide a basic, yet comprehensive, grounding in an important area of the tax law that is frequently encountered not only by tax practitioners, but also lawyers who represent clients generally in transactional and other business-related matters.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS: Open to 2L and 3L students who have completed the Basic Federal Income Tax course. Students who have had other relevant tax-related instruction (including MBA courses) or work experience may take this course with instructor permission only and must complete the pre-requisite waiver to obtain permission. The course is not open to Tax LLM students.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: The class will be open to all second and third year students. There are no prerequisites, although Business Associations and Secured Transactions are recommended to be taken either before the course or concurrently. Students who have already taken bankruptcy will have been introduced to some of the concepts discussed in the first seven weeks, but not to the depth and in the amount of detail proposed. The last six weeks will cover topics that are not covered by any other course in the curriculum

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
David G. Epstein, Bruce A. Markell, Steve H. Nickles & Lawrence Ponoroff, Bankruptcy: Dealing with Financial
Failure for Individuals and Businesses (4th ed. 2015).

Final Report of the ABI Commission on Consumer Bankruptcy (April 11, 2019) (to be provided in PDF format)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course examines the role and responsibilities of the federal courts in this country's system of government. Particular attention is paid to the structural principles of separation of powers and federalism. Topics to be considered include the origins and functions of the federal judiciary; the justiciability doctrines of standing, ripeness, and mootness; congressional power to control the jurisdiction of the federal courts; legislative courts; state courts and federal power; the various sources of federal jurisdiction; federal common law; state sovereign immunity; the various abstention doctrines; and the role of the Supreme Court.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
In particular, students in this class will become equipped with essential knowledge of the law in the area of financial services regulation, consumer protection, securities, evidence, and?most important?financial and emerging technologies.

In addition, students will develop fundamental lawyering skills, including to: (a) know and understand substantive and procedural law;(b) analyze and apply legal rules and principles; and (c) use the law to solve real-world problems and to create a more just society (by understanding and critiquing articles that seek to improve the law, legal institutions,and technological approaches.)

Students in this class will also be expected to develop the ability to give constructive written and oral feedback on legal and scholarly analysis and writing. Moreover, while you will not be expected to become expert in non-legal subject matter, you will be expected develop the ability to understand non-legal subject matter -specifically financial and emerging technologies such as blockchain and machine learning -sufficiently to comment on it intelligently and apply it to law and policy theories that underlie or touch upon a legal problem.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Final Exam and Presentation: 75%

Class Participation: 15%

Take-home memorandum -10% (A short take-home 2-3 page memorandum will be assigned throughout the course on the topic of the student's choosing. Once a student selects a topic, they will be assigned a legal research question. Student input on topic will be considered.)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1. Primavera De Filippi and Prof. Aaron Wright, Blockchain and the Law: The Rule of Code

2.Other materials (law review articles, cases, etc.) will be publicly available(see syllabus)

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: You are expected to attend class regularly and be fully prepared to discuss the assigned material. Students who regularly miss class violate School of Law and ABA rules and may be precluded from taking the final. I will take attendance every day, and will lower the grade (by one half of a letter grade) of anyone who misses more than two classes (100 minutes of lecture time), without being excused.The reasoning behind this is that the work you do in class is crucial to your understanding of the subject matter and, therefore, we expect that you will be in attendance.If you need to miss class, please let me know ahead of time, if possible.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course students will:
? develop an advanced understanding of the legal, political and cultural
institutions of South Africa;
? gain knowledge and understanding, through a diversity of viewpoints, of a
particular domestic legal issue or comparative legal issue related to South Africa
through rigorous research;
? develop professional interview skills related to that legal issue through live in-country interviews that will supplement their traditional legal research;
? develop their legal analysis and reasoning skills through an advanced,
collaborative research paper and presentation; and
? develop project management skills by working with team members of diverse
backgrounds and cultural experiences, preparing students for a work
environment that demands well-developed group skills.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Students should review the Course Proposal, timeline, and all of the rules and information on the ITP web pages prior to bidding on this course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this survey course, we consider public international law by examining its two primary components: international human rights law and international humanitarian law (also known as the Law of War). Students examine human rights concepts, the influence of customary international law, state responsibility, the role of treaties, the codification of human rights principles in a number of major treaties since World War II, civil and political rights, economic, social, and cultural rights, national security and terrorism in the context of human rights, torture law, universalism versus cultural relativism, religious rights, freedom of expression, the United Nations human rights system, treaty bodies such as the ICCPR Human Rights Committee, regional international human rights systems in Europe, the Americas and Africa, universal jurisdiction, and the role of domestic law relating to public international law precepts.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This seminar concentrates on the U.S. statutory definition of refugee which forms the basis for asylum. That definition is based on the 1951 United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and the 1967 United Nations Protocol to which over 140 countries are signatories. While most governing standards apply globally, cases considered are from the U.S. In addition to qualification for refugee status and asylum, consideration will be given to exclusions from and alternatives to asylum.

Grades will be based on attendance, participation - including role play as counsel or decider, presentation of paper topic, and final paper

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Knowledge of governing legal principles and precedents; experience in advocating for and against refugee status and asylum and in adjudicating hypothetical situations.

descriptions.value: Case studies, Class participation, Discussion, Films / videos, Lecture, Presentations, Simulation / role-play

name: Fair Housing ? Policies, Litigation, and Mediation

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This class will provide an overview of U.S. federal housing laws, regulations, and policies, with a focus on fair housing and fair lending. Students will examine civil rights litigation strategies and compliance with federal regulations from the perspective of lawyers, government officials, developers, fair housing organizations, tenants, and lending institutions. Additionally, we will discuss the intersection between housing discrimination, segregation, and the effects of gentrification. Novel and complex issues, such as civil rights compliant algorithms, and leading cases in civil rights housing litigation and investigatory strategies will be reviewed. The class will also expose students to alternative dispute resolution in the housing context, and students will participate in a mock fair housing mediation.

No pre-requisites.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar will examine the history and evolution of legal protections for abortion, contraception and other reproductive health care. We will look at state and federal constitutional, statutory and common law theories used to secure and protect these rights. We will explore current threats and growing barriers to access, including ever-expanding assertions of religious beliefs to limit access to reproductive health care. We will also look at advocacy strategies for addressing those threats and barriers. Grades are based on a final paper and class participation.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class will meet from 400 pm to 550 pm, primarily to attend and react to a series of lectures by the nation's preeminent historian of the American Revolution, Gordon Wood. We will meet for the first time in a one-hour orientation session on Thursday, October 10, 2019, to clarify expectations and briefly discuss Wood's work as a historian. The remaining six meetings will occur on successive Tuesdays, and Thursdays, from October 15 to October 31, 2019, at which Professor Wood will deliver his lectures on revolutionary constitutionalism. Attendance at all class sessions is mandatory.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students who complete this seminar will gain exposure to the ideas that shaped American revolutionary constitutional thought and will learn to think critically about what roles history can and cannot play in arguments about the meaning or content of law.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Your grade will be based on your attendance and on the quality of your end-of-class reaction paper, which will not exceed six pages in length. Reaction papers should tackle the ideas in the lectures and should not spend any significant time in a general review of the content of the lectures.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Aside from the material available on the course website, which you should read in advance and prepare to discuss during the first class meeting, this class has no assigned readings.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
Gordon Wood
Winner of the Bancroft prize for his first book, Creation of the American Republic, and of the Pulitzer Prize for later work, Wood writes history with a focus on ideas. He regards the American Revolution as the single most important event in American history, the event that continues to shape our sense of ourselves as a nation and a people. In focusing on ideas, Wood does not contend that they caused the events that he describes. For Wood, a whole messy complex of factors shape the behavior of individual participants in historical events; ideas provide the language and framework by which the participants in those events explain their actions to the world. Wood spent much of his career as a professor of history at Brown University; he joined the faculty at Northwestern School of Law for several years after he took emeritus status at Brown.

name: Criminal Justice in Cook County: An Empirical Examination

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course offers students the opportunity to learn about and participate in policy reform while gaining an in-depth understanding of how criminal cases are adjudicated.

Cook County is currently in the midst of a multi-year effort to reduce its jail population, but as one expert recently observed, "only deeper, more challenging reforms, like fundamentally overhauling the way criminal cases are processed through court systems, will move the number [of people in jail]."

In this course, we tackle this question. Students will participate in interviews of courtroom participants, and will evaluate and make recommendations for improving criminal case adjudication in Cook County. We will explore how other jurisdictions have increased the efficiency of criminal case processing while maintaining essential constitutional standards. We will then meet with policymakers and court participants to brief them on our findings.

Not only will students become experts on criminal court adjudication policies and practices, but we will also explore how policy change happens through guest presentations by stakeholders inside and outside government.

Students will be graded on policy research memos they research, write, and present to the class; feedback they give on other students' presentations; and on class participation. There will be no exam.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce students to the law governing the prosecution and defense of federal white collar crimes. The course will cover the substantive law in the area such as mail and wire fraud, bribery, insider trading, perjury, and obstruction of justice. The course will also provide an overview of typical procedural and practical issues, such as the use of the grand jury, Fifth Amendment invocation, internal investigations, parallel civil and criminal proceedings, corporate compliance programs, and federal sentencing. Finally, the course will put these principles into context with examples from past and recent white collar crime cases, such as the Rajaratnam insider trading prosecutions, the Bernie Madoff Ponzi Scheme, the Paul Manafort trial, and other notable white collar cases.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Communication and Legal Reasoning I and II ("CLR") are two courses designed to teach you the fundamental skills required for legal reasoning, research, and communication. In CLR I, you will learn how to read primary and secondary legal sources, analyze cases, synthesize legal rules, identify and research legal issues, organize an objective written analysis, present to legal reader a clear and effective written report of that analysis, provide citation to legal resources in your writing, and edit your own writing. In CLR II, you will learn how to persuade judges and other attorneys to reach a result that you want for your client.

I have carefully planned the progression of the writing and research assignments and you will develop your analytical and writing skills incrementally. Your assignments will begin with less complex, ungraded work, and build to more sophisticated, less professor-guided work.

You will also learn skills that will be useful in any law-related job. The course is designed to strike a balance between providing guidance and fostering self-sufficiency. The assignments are also designed to reflect the skills and competencies that you will need in practice.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students will be able to:
1. Brief, synthesize, and analyze case law;
2. Identify basic legal issues based on fact patterns;
3. Analyze legal issues based on case law;
4. Perform basic case law research; and
5. Prepare written and oral evaluations of those legal issues and provide suggested solutions for clients.

name: Advanced Legal Writing: Writing for the Court

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, students will learn the core principles of effective writing for judicial law clerks. Through readings, class discussion, and writing exercises and critique, students will develop their ability to critically read the parties' briefs, abstract facts and evidence, conduct legal research, apply the rules of jurisdiction and procedure, analyze the facts and law from a judge's perspective, and draft and edit bench memoranda and opinions. The course will be useful preparation for judicial clerkships and externships, and will result in a judicial opinion for use as a writing sample.

LAWSTUDY 540 Communication and Legal Reasoning I and LAWSTUDY 541 CLR II are required pre-reqs.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Literature is a cultural artifact, a creative practice, and a social bellwether. As lawyers we work with legal precedent that reflect a culture of rights and duties, we engage a creative rhetorical practice, and we make arguments about where we are or should be as a society. Stated this way, possible connections between literary and legal practices are revealed.

In this course we will interrogate those connections. There will be three core inquiries around the ideas of: law in literature, law as literature, and literature as law. Does our literary past inform our jurisprudential constitution? What can we learn as lawyers from a fictive practice of storytelling and close reading of texts? Can literary texts serve as persuasive authority for us as we make larger arguments about the social/legal/policy world we inhabit as lawyers?

name: Economic Analysis of Corp. Securities Law

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar will focus on using economic and statistical analysis to study core issues of corporate and securities law. We will study in depth some of the core issues in corporate and securities laws, most of which are introduced at a basic level in Business Organizations and Securities Regulation courses, such as: the role of the board of directors, derivative and class-action litigation, disclosure, various forms of insider or majority theft (especially in private companies), insider trading, shareholder voting, executive compensation, the role of institutional shareholders (especially activist shareholders), and mergers and acquisitions (especially takeover defenses). For some of the topics, we will consider empirical evidence from other countries, and especially from massive cross-country studies involving numerous other countries, and analyze how much value we gain from looking at such evidence.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: prior or concurrently taken Business Associations or Corporations course or consent of the instructor.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The grading is based on the final research project (60%), class participation (30%) and very short weekly reaction papers, consisting of identifying three main issues in the week's readings and explaining their significance,and graded on the pass-fail basis (10%).You can receive a multi-draft paper credit for this course. For this option, you need to submit the requisite number of drafts, as defined by the law school's official credit rules.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: The reading list is included for each week. The readings are listed roughly in the order of importance -the first few articles are the most important. These articles are not meant to be read very closely; you can skip some sections that are very technical. You do need, however, to understand the core issues presented in each article: (1) the research puzzle and why it's important; (2) the research design; (3) the results; (4) implications for theory, policy, and future research. The readings marked as "additional reference" are less critical and can be skipped, but they are useful for those who are interested in this topic. You are always welcome and encouraged to go beyond the reading list, to look into the articles cited by the articles from the reading list, or ask me for more suggestions. This reading list might be modified throughout the semester to reflect the interests and backgrounds of seminar participants.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: The readings will include a combination of classic law review articles and cutting-edge research, mostly from finance, economics, and accounting. You do not need background in statistics or economics, but you need willingness to learn how to read and understand quantitative research, which I will teach throughout the course. Your final research project does not need to quantitative (it is not realistic to complete an original quantitative research paper in one semester, starting from scratch, though I will support any brave souls who wantto try!), but it needs to incorporate the findings of other people's quantitative research, not just hand-waiving, speculation, anecdotes, and "arguments".

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: During this interactive seminar we will examine the privacy regulations that apply to corporate actors. We will look at disclosures companies must make when collecting information, how they can use and combine information, and related issues. Our work will also include an analysis of how big data and digital tracking activities are regulated, and restrictions that exist when companies combine information from multiple sources. This is not a lecture based class. Time together will be spent on interactive group work. Grading is based on group projects and individual assignments that mirror work product created by law firms for their corporate clients (including graphics, charts and tables).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces MSL students to quantitative ideas and techniques that arise in the courtroom through expert testimony. No mathematical background is needed. Topics include chance, descriptive statistics, data collection, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, statistical significance, elementary probability, selection bias, base rates, error rates, Bayesian reasoning, causation, legal studies, and the standards for admitting quantitative evidence.  Application areas include discrimination claims, trademark studies, racial profiling proof, DNA evidence, medical malpractice cases, and epidemiological evidence. Grades will be based largely on several weekly analyses, a group project, and a short test.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will provide an introduction to U.S. federal constitutional law. Areas of emphasis will include the theory and practice of judicial review, including approaches to constitutional interpretation; separation of powers, with emphases on congressional powers and the reserved powers of the states; and individual rights.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the process of US civil litigation. Students will learn the key portions of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing a civil case and the cases interpreting those rules. Particular attention will be given to those elements of U.S. civil procedure less commonly found in other systems, including litigation finance, pleadings, pre-trial motion practice, discovery practice, the use of expert witnesses, trial and post-trial motions, and the jurisdictional requirements and relationship between state and federal courts.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Civil Procedure is the field of law that governs how civil cases are brought, advanced, and resolved in court. But it is much more than the study of technical rules. Civil Procedure is a window into the fundamental values that underlie our system of civil justice, raising some of the law's most interesting issues about government power, democracy, and social policy. Our procedural rules?both code and common law?make deliberate choices that tell us much about what our procedural system deems just. These rules aim to balance efficiency with fairness, access to court with finality, and flexibility with certainty. They attempt to juggle the competing interests of litigants, courts, and society at large. Accordingly, we will not only study the rules and their content, but also assess their underlying choices with a critical eye.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Pre-reqs - 1L required course

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Civil Procedure will teach you not just about lawyering but also how law works. The law in this field consists of constitutional doctrines, judge-made common law tests, federal statutes, and the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure themselves. Each works in tandem with the other, requiring you to sort out the complex relationships among these sources and the governmental bodies that generate them. From a skills perspective, you'll learn how to interpret statutes and rules, which is a different exercise than interpreting cases. You'll practice interpreting cases as well, and work at synthesizing common-law tests that have evolved over time, developing critical analytical skills that will serve you well in law school and practice. You'll begin to see how stories, legal elements, and procedural rules are entwined. And you will learn about courts and their relationships, along with the vocabulary of procedure, excellent tools for reading cases in all of your courses. In these ways, Civil Procedure is a basic building block of your legal education.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Hardcover casebook: Stephen Yeazell, Civil Procedure, 9th edition, 2015, Wolters Kluwer Aspen Casebook Series, ISBN: 9781454868347.

A current paper or electronic version of the The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. You may use any version of the Rules you wish, as long as they reflect all rules changes through December 1, 2018.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
All students are "on-call" each class period and are expected to be prepared for every class. My end of the bargain is to prepare a list of questions and hypotheticals each week to allow you to anticipate the lines of questioning.

I will assess class participation on a daily basis. After the exams are graded, I will factor in participation assessments. If, based on your exam, you are on the margin between two grades, and your participation has been regular and robust, I will move you up to the next grade level.

You will have the opportunity to take an ungraded optional midterm examination. After you upload your exam answers through Canvas, the T.A. and I will embed voice comments with our feedback.

The final exam is the only graded assignment in the course. It will be open-book. It is designed as a 3-hour exam, but I will give you 3 hours and 45 minutes to complete it.

You will have the opportunity to take an ungraded optional midterm examination. After you upload your exam answers through Canvas, the T.A. and I will embed voice comments with our feedback.

The final exam is the only graded assignment in the course. It will be open-book. It is designed as a 3-hour exam, but I will give you 3 hours and 45 minutes to complete it.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The goal of this course is to help students develop certain perspectives and skills and for managing conflict and managing themselves that will enable them to provide better service to their clients and gain more satisfaction in their professional practice.

Lawyers and law students, like all other human beings, frequently misunderstand or mishandle conflict. This could happen when you negotiate a corporate merger or a truce between feuding nations; when you take the biggest slice of a birthday cake or divide your late aunt Dolly's jewelry with your siblings; or when you buy a new Tesla or a used teapot. Some such blunders create or escalate conflict, damage relationships, or lead to missed opportunities, suboptimal outcomes, interpersonal violence, or even war.

Of course, poor decisions spring from countless factors, such as cognitive biases, illusions, mental shortcuts (which social scientists call "heuristics"), cultural misunderstandings, or too much or too little deliberation or information. In addition, as Yogi Berra and Niels Bohr may have said, "It's difficult to make predictions, especially about the future." Most of these unfortunate decisions, however, result from three kinds of management problems: 1. Managing External conflict (between people); 2. Managing Focus (where and how we direct our attention); or 3. Managing Internal conflict (within a person) This course presents three overlapping domains of theory, knowledge, and practice that can help ameliorate these management problems: 1. Negotiation for managing outer conflict; 2. Mindfulness, for managing awareness and focus; and 3. Internal family systems, for managing inner conflict.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students should learn:

to write better;
to understand and respond to external conflict (between persons) using four negotiation models and combining elements of these models as appropriate;
to manage their awareness and focus through mindfulness;

to manage internal conflict through internal family systems;

to combine negotiation, mindfulness, and internal family systems; and

to perform and feel better in a variety of professional situations through combining negotiation, mindfulness, and internal family systems.

Recommended books on negotiation Roger Fisher & Daniel
Shapiro, Beyond Reason: Using Emotions as You Negotiate
(Viking Hardcover, 2005 or Penguin Paperback, 2006). Doug
Stone, Bruce Patton & Sheila Heen, Difficult Conversations: How
to Discuss What Matters Most (Viking hardcover, 1999 or Penguin paperback, 2000) or anniversary edition, 2010). Recommended books on writing
Eugene Volokh, Academic Legal Writing (any edition). William
Zinsser, On Writing Well (any edition is fine, but the more recent
are a bit more helpful).

Recommended basic books on mindfulness Jon Kabat-
Zinn, Wherever You Go, There You Are: Mindfulness Meditation in
Everyday Life (Hyperion paperback, 2005). Henepola
Gunaratana, Mindfulness in Plain English (Wisdom, 1991 or
subsequent editions). Chade-Meng Tan, Search Inside Yourself: The Unexpected Path to Achieving Success, Happiness (and World Peace) (HarperOne 2012) (About Google's mindfulness-based emotional intelligence program). This
book is particularly clear, even though the author's unusual sense
of humor (which he acknowledges) shows itself with some
frequency.

Recommended book on internal family systems (IFS)
Richard C. Schwartz, Introduction to the Internal Family Systems
Model (Trailheads Publications, 2001).
Notes

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Feel free to contact me if you have questions or concerns about the course. It is easy for me to send you the syllabus (without class-by-class assignments, but with due dates regarding the case study. My email is easiest: L-riskin@law.northwestern.edu

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Taught by Alan Salpeter, Senior Counsel, Arnold & Porter; this course is designed for students interested in commercial litigation. The instructor has 45 years of trial and appellate experience.

This course is a practical, real world discussion of topics such as: (i) picking and developing a theme, (ii) developing a strategy for discovery, (iii) managing litigation risks, (iv) managing troublesome litigation situations (v) negotiating settlements, (vi) understanding the adversarial system, and (vii) being effective with clients. Guest speakers include federal judges, expert witnesses, a jury consultant, general counsel and mediator.

Classroom format is an interactive discussion

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: The course is recommended for 3Ls, but 2Ls may take the course.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the class, students will think more creatively about how to solve litigation problems in the real world. This is not a rules-based course. It is a practical course where we explore how to solve various litigation situations that arise in the day-to-day practice of commercial litigation.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar explores how litigants vindicate federal constitutional rights in the courts. Topics include 42 U.S.C. 1983, which provides the primary cause of action to remedy constitutional violations; defenses and immunities of individuals and municipal governments; and various forms of monetary and injunctive relief. Class instruction is a mix of in-class discussion of doctrinal topics and in-court observation (when scheduling allows) and discussion of actual civil-rights trials, pretrial conferences, and other hearings presided over by Judge Chang.

name: Clinic Practice: Center on Wrongful Convictions

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Students who enroll in the Center on Wrongful Convictions will participate in our trifold mission of representation, education, and reform on a national scale.

Students will partner with faculty and, in many cases, Northwestern alumni from national firms to represent imprisoned clients who were convicted of serious crimes and have compelling claims of innocence and/or major constitutional violations. Our clients' cases unfold at both the state and federal level before tribunals ranging from clemency boards to state trial courts to the federal courts of appeal and, on occasion, the U.S. Supreme Court. Students' case work may include visiting and counseling incarcerated clients, interviewing witnesses and other field investigation, conducting legal or forensic science research, and drafting court documents. Qualifying students may appear in court as permitted by Illinois Supreme Court Rule 711. Students may also participate in the writing of briefs as amicus curiae in high-level appellate cases across the country.

With respect to education, outreach, and reform, interested students will participate in the CWC's strategic reform and policy work. Examples of past student engagement around reform and policy include the creation of reports and/or presentations concerning access to justice and/or needed systemic reforms; working with media outlets to engage public audiences in the urgency of national criminal justice reform work; and co-authoring, with CWC faculty, publications exploring failures in law and practice that too often permit wrongful convictions to go unredressed.

This course emphasizes teamwork, collaboration, and strategic thinking. Students typically work in groups of two or more and meet weekly outside of class on individual cases or projects.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students in IHR Advocacy Clinic will have the opportunity to work on cases or projects using the norms and mechanisms of IHR law. Projects may involve, e.g., State and business accountability for human rights violations; rights of indigenous and other peoples to participate in decisions affecting their lives, lands and livelihoods; rights of migrants to seek asylum and be treated with dignity; and protection of the human rights of LGBTIQ people. Working with local NGOs, students will have the opportunity to conduct fact-finding, prepare complaints to UN human rights mechanisms on behalf of victims, draft reports for human rights mechanisms, and develop strategies for combatting human rights abuses. Students often have the opportunity to travel to conduct fact-finding and collaborate with NGO partners in the countries and areas that are the focus of project work, and to participate in human rights advocacy at the UN in Geneva. For information about specific projects and possible travel for the upcoming semester, please contact Prof. Bridget Arimond at b-arimond@law.nortwestern.edu.
