Mintz, Sidney. Sweetness and Power: the Place of Sugar in Modern History.* Penguin Books, 1985 (used from $6.62)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class introduces the fundamentals of dance composition as a thoughtful and critical expression. Primary emphasis is on elements such as time, space, shape, form, dynamics, and design. These will be approached through a rigorous engagement with touch, affect, and kinesthesia (the sense of movement). The class encompasses exercises that can be applied to theatrical performance, screendance, social dance, site-specific/responsive performance, and creative writing.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course we will explore the field of performance studies as it interrogates the relationship between race and performance in a primarily US context. Anchoring each class in the work of artists who engages the medium of performance, we will explore the ways in which race is performed and performative. We will also meditate upon the deployment of performance by black, brown, Asian, and indigenous artists to complicate our understanding and experience of race and racism. Each class will be organized around the work of a single artist alongside a set of key texts drawn from the critical race theory movement, black studies, Latinx studies, Asian American studies, Native American and Indigenous studies, and performance studies. Artists/works studied may include Laura Aguilar, Beyoncé, Nao Bustamante, Theresa Hak Kyung Cha, Rafa Esparza, Felix Gonzalez-Torres, Tseng Kwong Chi and Muna Tseng, Yoko Ono, Tommy Pico, and Adrian Piper. Scholars studied may include Daphne Brooks, Saidiya Hartmann, E Patrick Johnson, Fred Moten, Uri McMilla, Amber Musser, José Muñoz, Patricia Nguyen, Tavia Nyong'o, Ramón Rivera-Servera, Juana María Rodríguez, Sandra Ruiz, Karen Shimakawa, Stephani Nohelani Teves, and Alexandra Vazquez.

name: Topics in Performance Studies
topic: Performance Culture of the Middle East.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar examines shifts and transformations in embodied cultural practices across the Middle East and North Africa, with particular attention to music, dance, theater, and popular culture. Spanning the late nineteenth century to the Arab Spring, students will better understand a cultural history of the region, its role in shaping global modernity, and the politics of gender, sexuality, and ethnoreligious difference. In addition to class discussion and written assignments, students will be asked to develop a creative project to be designed in consultation with the instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goals of this course are to assist students (1) to acquire knowledge about cultural production in the contemporary Middle East and North Africa; (2) to engage in the critical analysis and interpretation of performance as method of research, object of study, and theoretical field of interest; and (3) to develop an ability to express new knowledge and perspectives in writing, oral presentation, and creative work.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, discussion, and participatory activities

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
1. Assignments: 75% of final grade
a. Response papers (25%)
b. In-class Presentation (10%)
c. Field project (10%)
d. Final project (30%)
2. Attendance and participation: 25% of final grade

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: TBD

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class provides conceptual and practical tools to help students devise their performance recital. Through critical essays and performance exercises, the course engages performance as analytic, research method, and event. The course gives students the opportunity to explore elements such as text, space, objects, and storytelling from an aesthetic and critical perspective. What are the issues that are central to studies of performance when bodies are on display or when a story is communicated to an audience? In what ways does a poetic rendition of an ethnographic interview make a statement about the politics of the research process, disrupting notions of linearity and authority that characterize Western epistemology? How do narrative voice choices impact the politics of a performance? The aim of the course is to explore performance as a meaning-making practice, paying close attention to the role of embodied behavior in the production, interpretation, and dissemination of knowledge.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Incoming Performance Studies graduate students (for whom the course is required) need permission numbers to register.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course will introduce you to methodological and theoretical issues
central to the practice of dance ethnography. The course follows two parallel tracks:
1) a critical survey of key texts in dance ethnography and 2) a practical module in
dance ethnography?from basic description and analysis of movement to
participant-observation exercises.

name: Seminar: Problems in Performance Studies
topic: Vocal Sound and Performances of Race

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What, and how, does vocal sound carry? What does it mean to hear a racialized body in a voice? Significantly, for a line of thinkers from W.E.B. DuBois to Paul Gilroy to Daphne Brooks and further, the performativity of racialized life keys an attunement to song. This seminar considers the ways in which singing voices are racialized, by performers and listeners, via discourses and practices of technique, health, embodiment, timbre, space, resistance, and resonance. Special attention is given to performances of race and voice on the musical stage. Readings also include texts by Fred Moten, Nina Sun Eidsheim, Alex Weheliye, Jean-Luc Nancy, Steven Connor, Adriana Cavarero, Ralph Ellison, Licia Fiol-Matta, Shana Redmond, and Alexandra T. Vazquez.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Through lectures, reading assignments, discussions, in-class screenings, and in-class workshops, this course provides a supportive environment where students are encouraged to take risks and experiment as they discover their narrative voice. Students will have opportunities to work both individually and primarily, collaboratively, in small groups. Students will be introduced to the technical and theoretical components necessary for media construction: narrative, sound, image, and editing. Projects will include audio and video assignments and will culminate in the production of group short films.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This first-year seminar for Radio/TV/Film students explores the representation of food and cooking in film and television. Weekly readings and film screenings will provide a framework for conversations about food from critical, cultural, and political perspectives, and we will also explore the role that food has played in our own lives. Screenings will include both fictional texts like Ratatouille, Chef, and The Hundred-Foot Journey, and nonfictional texts like Jiro Dreams of Sushi, Food, Inc, and No Reservation. Students will be assessed through a number of short writing assignments, which will include reading and film response papers, a critical restaurant review, and a personal food essay. The final project will be a proposal for a food-based media project.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to the study and structure of film, television, and other audiovisual media. We will define and examine the expressive and aesthetic power of the basic elements of the moving image. Specifically, the course will investigate, across a variety of different media, modes, and historical periods, the fundamentals of cinematography, especially the shot and its composition; editing; set design, costume, and acting styles; and sound. We will also discuss narrative, genre, documentary, animation, and experimental film. The goal of the course is to acquaint students with a vocabulary specific to cinema and media analysis, and to provide students with the critical tools required for the accurate description and formal analysis of the moving image.

Students will learn how core concepts of character, structure, plot, theme, and tone work together on the page to create narrative. Students will explore these concepts and their practice in film, as well as how they might utilize these concepts to express their personal voice and vision.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Designed to provide students with a detailed understanding of the key conventions, themes, and stylistic traits of the modern American horror film, this course will ask students to engage with well-known horror screen presences like Leatherface, Freddy Krueger, and Hannibal Lecter from the perspectives of both fans and scholars. Focusing on topics including hicksploitation horror, serial killer movies, slasher films, body horror, paranormal horror, and self-reflexive contemporary horror, this course will allow students to explore the variety of ways that horror films not only thrill us, but engage with important social, gender, and cultural issues, as well. Through weekly lectures, film screenings, discussions, quizzes and short writing assignments, students will have a chance to voice their ideas regarding the horror genre's importance to the cinematic arts, hone their critical analysis skills, and gain a deeper knowledge of how American horror cinema works to examine themes and concepts that may not only frighten us as individuals, but as a nation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
While there is no required textbook for this course, students are required to print and have hard copies of course readings posted to Canvas. Based on library printing rates at 10 cents/page, printing costs for the course should not exceed $80-$100 for the course.

PLEASE NOTE: Thursday sessions will serve as screening periods and based on the length of some films, some Thursday sessions may run until 5 p.m. Students are encouraged to stay for the entire length of the film screening on Thursdays whenever possible.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, we will review major films of Tarkovsky and of Russian and non-Russian directors whose work is related to his (Eisenstein, Wenders, Bergman, Kurosawa).

name: Radio/Television/Film Genre
topic: Musical Media: Music Videos, Film Musicals, and Mu

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Popular music has been in dialogue with visual media since the birth of the cinema. This course explores that dialogue through the history and aesthetics of three genres of musical media: music video; the film musical; and music- and dance-based digital games. In each of these cases, music's central role has stimulated innovative and influential approaches to audiovisual style, modes of storytelling, and forms of media interaction. Musical genres provide a distinctive perspective on media history. For example, music videos helped to define the media culture of the 1980s, launched the careers of many influential directors, and have taken on new importance as we increasingly encounter music via digital screens. The film musical was an early site of media industry synergy, and the compilation soundtrack has played an important role in recent strategies of film promotion. Digital games that center on music and dance foreground the role of performing bodies in media interaction, and one of our goals will be to sharpen our skills at cultural critique as we investigate the politics of representation, cultural borrowing, and authenticity in genres of musical media.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- Analyze and describe the style of various forms of musical media;

- Understand the relationship between media genres and their social, cultural and historical context;

- Work with primary and secondary research materials to develop an original argument about media genres;

- Think critically and comparatively about the politics of representation, cultural borrowing, and authenticity in genres of musical media.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be assessed through: 1) short written assignments at the end of each of three Units (on music video, film musicals, and music games); 2) two in-class group presentations, one on a recent music video discussed in our readings, and one on a music- or dance- based digital game.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Stephen Shaviro, Digital Music Videos (Rutgers University Press, 2017)
Steven Cohan, ed. The Hollywood Musicals Reader. (Routledge 2001)
Kiri Miller, Playable Bodies (Oxford University Press, 2017)

Other required readings and screenings available via Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, students will consider the biographical film or "biopic," as a genre, and proceed from the assertion that this class of motion picture carries a distinct significance for African American audiences. What sorts of aesthetic, historical and political questions and problems arise given the issues of scarcity and distortion that routinely affect black representations in mainstream media texts? How does the popularity of biopics intersect with the desire for a more complete and accurate rendering of American history that results from such longstanding diminishment? Likewise, given the significance of biopics as consistent?yet intermittent?sources of employment for underemployed African American actors, how can we map these movies onto the emergence of significant black stars, and within larger movements of black film or American film more broadly?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will consider three major categories of popular biopic that chronicle the lives of African American 1) entertainers; 2) sports figures; and 3) political figures/activists. We will also explore the ways that biopics are typically called upon by African American audiences to fulfill both the cultural imperative to participate in a deeply rooted black oral tradition of storytelling, and the counter-cultural imperative to tell a story that complicates and challenges oppressive or bowdlerized versions of black life stories.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An examination of the elements of "the procedural," (defined primarily as police, lawyer and medical scripts) with a primary focus on thinking outside of the box of this long-standing go-to for writers. By analyzing structure, characters and location, students will dive into the history of the procedural while working within a contemporary storytelling style. Students will respond to essays, watch video examples, outline, write and workshop a full-length procedural script, coming away with the skills necessary to work within the genre's compelling framework.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, in-class writing exercises, television treatment and thirty page teleplay.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: All script examples will be available via CANVAS and all video examples will be shown in class or be available for viewing online via CANVAS.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: A popular style of modern television writing (Transparent, High Maintenance, Atlanta), the "dramedy," has the strong character components of a comedy while combining the engaging story components of a drama. In this class, we will respond to essays, watch video examples and study the art and craft of the dram-com approach. Students will also examine the process of developing, outlining, and writing a dramedy television series, building their own dynamic characters and locations through the making of a final original script.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, in-class writing exercises, television treatment and thirty page teleplay.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: All script examples will be available via CANVAS and all video examples will be shown in class or be available for viewing online via CANVAS.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In this course, we will watch movie/TV clips and read passages from plays, and investigate
together: How do we use dialogue to structure scenes, to propel the plot and deepen the tone? To
what extent can dialogue represent reality? To what extent can dialogue create (a particular)
reality? How do we design dialogue that is influenced by our understanding of our characters'
psychologies? How do we use not just what people say, but how they say it? What's the
relationship of visuals, sound fx/music, and dialogue? What's the relationship of power,
momentum and dialogue? Is there a secret to writing quotable dialogue? How do we create
comic oppositions with dialogue? What are effective uses of voice over? In what circumstances
do we want to include meaningless "chitchat"? In what circumstances, do we want to include
"speeches" or monologues? In what circumstances do we want to erase dialogue as we revise our
scripts? When is silence (ironically) the best dialogue? Finally, we'll investigate plots centering
on dialogue, i.e. characters who learn to speak or who lose the ability to speak. A substantial
amount of time will be spent on the mistakes beginning (and seasoned!) writers make
with dialogue, as well as spotlighting fantastic dialogue. Can't wait!

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Through the viewing and analysis of short films and scenes and sequences from features and
television shows, as well as the reading and analysis of passages from plays, students will learn
how the above concepts are utilized to express personal vision. With the goal of writing and
revising their own short screenplay/teleplay/play, emphasis throughout will be placed on mastery
of aspects of the art and craft of dialogue.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Lectures, reading assignments, discussion, in-class viewing of short films and selected film/TV
clips, in-class reading and analysis of plays, and workshop of student assignments. Above all
else, the environment will be a supportive one and students will be encouraged to participate in a
community marked by an atmosphere of collaboration.
Writing assignments are arranged to mirror our in-class discussions, culminating in the
successful completion of a 20-30 page screenplay, teleplay, or play, which illustrates an
understanding of those concepts.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Grades will be based on the breakdown below (although I reserve the right to adjust this over the
summer as the syllabus is developed).

OBJECTIVE
Attendance 10%
Professionalism 10%
Progress 5%
ANALYSES
4 1-page papers analyzing a particular concept of dialogue 5% each for 20%
1-page notes for one of the reading assignments for the class. 5%
SCREENWRITING/TELEPLAY/PLAY WRITING
2 short screenplays/teleplays (3-10 page range TBD) 10% each for 20%
Final 20-30 page screenplay/play/teleplay 30%

descriptions.value: This course will focus on how to sell yourself as a writer and how to talk about your ideas by doing hands on practice sessions, talking to various professionals in the industry, and putting together a strong pitch package that students can use as they transition to the professional world.

Through a combination of lectures, weekly written assignments, selected readings of scripts and film study, we will examine our writing from the point of view of production (e.g. casting, scale, schedule, budget, camera, etc.) In addition to weekly writing assignments students will be required to complete a short screenplay (between 21-28 pages) as their final project.

descriptions.value: This course is a writing workshop focused on Action as a genre and "writing action" as a skill for all genres. Through a combination of lectures, weekly written assignments, selected readings of scripts and film study, we will discuss the evolution of the Action Film and explore the challenges of writing within this genre. descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Part discussion, part writer's workshop, the class examines the interconnection between character and story, emphasizing the primary function of character to drive authentic action. Analyzing examples from film, television, theatre and short fiction, students will learn different strategies for using character to further and deepen story. The primacy of structure as a tool for criticism will be examined with an eye to loosening the grip of plot on creativity. In the writer's workshop portion of the class, new skills will be applied to students' short films, television scripts or a one-act plays. We will move both "forwards and backwards" in our writer's workshop using character to both create structure and to solve problems with an existing structure.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Foundations of Screenwriting completed

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:

Students will be able to use techniques from the class to refine their own work.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In dystopian stories the ills of society run riot. As a film genre, dystopian owes much to satire, science fiction, and fantasy and yet is distinct from them. Examples include: The Hunger Games, Children of Men, Mad Max, and The Handmaid's Tale. In this class, we will view and discuss examples of dystopian films in order to understand the conventions of the genre, the anxieties it explores, and why these stories captivate today's audiences. Class meetings will include discussions of concepts pertinent to the genre and analysis of films viewed outside of class, as well as workshopping student material. Assignments will be arranged to mirror a writer's creative process starting with ideas and culminating in the successful completion of a plot outline and a minimum of 30 pages of an original feature-length screenplay.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: The prerequisite for this class is RTVF 260.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To learn effective writing strategies and become familiar with the elements of the dystopian genre in order to create stories that resonate with a contemporary audience.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendance, written assignments, and class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Handouts & articles given in class on specific topics and the work generated by classmates.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Students must come to the first class with a story premise in mind.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

name: Introduction to Acting for the Screen

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This lab-oriented course will address practices for acting on camera, as well as the more technical concerns of how actors place themselves in relationship to the camera for the most effective appearance onscreen. Prioritizing hands-on work, both in and out of class, and placing special emphasis on the actor-director relationship, you will perform in and direct a number of exercises to build acting skills in projects designed to focus on cinematic storytelling achieved primarily through performance rather than primarily through directorial technique, cinematography, editing, and sound design. Students will be exposed to a range of performance methods employed by screen actors and directors.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Completion of RTVF 190 and Permission number for students in RTVF and Theatre. The course is required for completion of the Acting for Screen Module.

NOTE: These production courses are enrollment by permission number only.
368-1 Sec. 20 Introduction to Acting for the Screen, Spencer Parsons, TTh 11-1 (combined with THEATRE 376-0-20)
*NOTE: Enrollment by permission of instructor. Email Prof. Parsons, s-parsons@northwestern.edu.
In your email, you must indicate your class year and the quarters in which you completed the
prerequisites: RTVF 190 and an acting class (TH 143-0/171-0 or TH 243-1/273-1).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will perform a number of exercises to build skills in scene analysis and different performance styles, with a goal of beginning to develop their own practice for relating and performing to camera in both shooting and audition settings. Students will also learn and demonstrate practices in camerawork and editing to best capture and modulate performance.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: This class will function as a sort of performance-driven workshop, contending with a few different processes for performance and direction. It will involve reading and discussion of acting and cinema theory to help focus our work, but it will always chiefly concern hands-on performance for camera, and shooting for performance.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on class participation and execution of assigned short films and in-class performances, as well as on discussion and critique of one another's work. Particular attention will be paid to storytelling focus and the student's development of personal strategies for screen performance.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings, screening material, and audio media will be provided by instructor via canvas. Students will be responsible for simple props, costumes, and other basic supplies necessary for production of shooting assignments.

name: Topics in Acting for the Screen

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This production course will explore what "based on a true story" can mean for screen actors, whether making stories based on their own lives (as Lena Dunham worked with her real mother and sister in Tiny Furniture, and Mike Birbiglia did in Sleepwalk With Me); based on historical figures and events (David Oyelowo as MLK in Selma or Olivia Coleman as Queen Anne in The Favourite), or on the lives of less publicly known figures involved in extraordinary events (John David Washington in Blackkklansman or Lili Taylor in I Shot Andy Warhol).mWe will use this particular problem of basing performance on actual events to focus on developing the actor's skills using personal experience in their work: drawing on the actor's own life experience and from the live and present experience of performance itself to play either versions of themselves or versions of real people very different from themselves.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Completion of RTVF 190 and Permission number for students in RTVF and Theatre. The course counts as an elective toward completion of the Acting for Screen Module.
369-0 Topics in Acting for Screen
Sec. 20 Performance Based on Actual Events, Spencer Parsons, M 3-5, W 3-6 (combined with THEATRE 377-0-21)
*NOTE: Enrollment by permission of instructor. Email Prof. Parsons, s-parsons@northwestern.edu.
Your email must indicate your class year and the quarter in which you completed RTVF 190.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Skills emphasized and evaluated will be regular performance practice and dramatic
analysis focused on the experience of performing and appearance of the performer on camera. Students will also exercise skills in research of story and character information for dramatic construction and selection of events, traits, and behavior for clear storytelling and dramatic emphasis. Students will complete on-camera exercises culminating in a final short film that they will write and perform.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The course will focus on in-class workshopping and performance exercises, balanced with critique of projects shot outside class. Additionally, students will screen, research, and critique screen performances based on actual events for film and television.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on class participation and execution of assigned short films and in-class presentation, as well as on discussion and critique of one another's work. Particular attention will be paid to storytelling focus and the student's development of personal strategies for performance.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings, screening material, and audio media will be provided by instructor via canvas. Students will be responsible for simple props, costumes, and other basic supplies necessary for production of shooting assignments.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This class will focus on the comedic mode of film acting, extending from television and sketch comedy to cinema. Scene study from the history of comedy performance and in-class scene work will lead to a final original comedy project.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, in-class scene work, out-of-class film projects

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is a seminar that systematically explores sources of inspiration, and the structures that give form to those ideas. Each week, through lectures, screenings, readings, discussion, presentations, and critiques of student work, one theme of inspiration will be analyzed. This could include dream, myth, memory, music, math, appropriation, and adaptation. Students will generate weekly projects on these themes by creating prototypes that will include both a written and an image component to be critiqued by the class.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite 190 or permission of instructor

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the quarter, students should have a strong working knowledge of their own personal voice, an ability to revise and expand their ideas, and to develop them in a systematic way. They should leave class with an understanding of several strategies to draw inspiration from, and specific ways to develop those strategies. They should also be adept at thinking visually and creating iconic images for their ideas, storyboarding these ideas, and disseminating these ideas into a compact, one-page format that gets to the essence of what they are trying to do. Finally, students should be able to identify the underlying structures and inspirational sources of films, and to critique peer work in a heuristic way.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureSeminarReadingsProblem setsClass participationCase studiesWriting assignmentsListening exercisesFilms / videosPresentationsObservationDiscussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: PresentationsClass participationFilms / videosProject, finalReadingsWriting assignments

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Students will need a sketchbook for daily use, and something to draw with (pen, pencil, charcoal).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
"When I start cutting a move, I always cut with ambivalence. I have a definite intention, a definite starting point: the dramatic function of the scene, the psychology of the characters, etc. But when I become absorbed in the material, I suddenly see all the possibilities the material contains. ? it is in the ambivalence, in the collision between the general strategy and the pleasant distractions along the way that constitutes editing as art; the true life of the film." - Dede Allen, Film Editor

This course will introduce students to the fundamentals of digital non-linear editing. The emphasis of the course will be hands-on practice through a series of projects. There will be several in-class screenings, readings, and a significant amount of time spent editing to develop your abilities. Finally, this class is the first step to finding your own "voice" as an editor.
The projects in the class will offer experience with several different editing strategies and techniques. They are designed to develop conceptual and technical proficiency, as well as the working skills, strategies, and discipline necessary to provide a foundation for further exploration. Students will be graded according to their ability to satisfactorily complete these projects in the time frame allotted, as well as through: attendance, discussion and participation.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Critical Making course is designed for filmmakers, artists, engineers, media theorists, and students who want to work with media in unconventional methods. Class participants will build interactive art, video pieces and products that use sensors for creating metaphorical meaning, humor, and emotion that expands beyond the push toward consumerism. This course is designed for beginners. No electronics or coding knowledge is required.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The course will introduce methods to take interaction out of the computer screen and embody it through Physical Computing tools such as Arduino and simple sensors. In this production course, we will think about the process of invention. The products we consume in our daily life serve to a certain ideology such as optimization, efficiency, social norms, productivity, and consumer-oriented culture. Class participants will create tangible, three dimensional, and interactive design projects that question these embedded ideologies. The course will progress via a series of readings, examples from media arts, interactive video, games, do it yourself movement, and hands on assignments. The tutorials about Arduino and simple sensors, mold making, bio art, digital fabrication, sculptural process will enable students to develop an insight about design terminology such as speculative fiction, prototyping, user scenarios, reverse engineering, hacking, feminist design, and repairability.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Each student will need an Arduino Kit ($50). Instructor of the course will apply for production grant and
may be able to purchase one kit per student. In this case, the cost for students will be zero.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will teach basic drawing and design skills for storytellers. Participants will practice with both analog tools (drawing and collage) and digital tools (Photoshop and Illustrator) and learn to combine analog and digital tools to create static images for telling stories. Course will be particularly useful for participants who would like to follow a path in animation, comics-graphic novels, design, photography, or cinematography. Participants will keep a journal, make weekly design and drawing assignments, participate in critique sessions, and make an individual presentation about a design work. The capstone project may include a comics story or a storyboard. No drawing or software skills required for taking this course but participants must be willing to practice drawing through a range of assignments.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a workshop for understanding the cultural context of video games through practical use of introductory game creation tools. The course aims to distinguish between how video games extend traditions of artistic exchange and how they offer novel and unexplored modes of communication unique to the medium. The course is designed to engender an active and critical perspective on what games are and how they relate to other cultural texts through analysis, discussion, production, and play. Students will have the opportunity to conceptualize their own game projects and select from a menu of approaches in order to resolve them. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and unit projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior game making experience, although students with experience are welcome to enroll.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the quarter students should have a strong understanding of contemporary developments in game production. Students should also have a working understanding of different tools for game creation as well as how to choose an effective and meaningful tool to resolves a particular concept.

Readings will be provided as pdf or web documents.

SketchUp (provided on computers in lab)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class explores the possibility of creating sound designs for media projects based on algorithmic procedures, using the multimedia programming language Max. We will learn approaches to sound design across a range of conceptual areas, including basic sound synthesis, audio signal processing, generative musical structures, software instrument design, and controller-based interaction. No previous programming experience is required.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, four incremental assignments of increasing complexity, and final project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Students must procure a method for data backup from week to week such as a thumb-drive or other external drive.
Enrollment Requirements:
Open to all SAI students, RTVF students have a prerequisite of RTVF 190, students outside RTVF require instructor permission.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This class will introduce you to the art and skill of color timing, AKA color correction. The class will be a challenging mixture of artistic and technical, with a deeply hands-on workshop-type of approach.
Using Davinci Resolve, you will learn the fundamentals in primary, secondary, and effects color correction, as well as stabilizing and tracking. While the focus of the class will be on DaVinci Resolve, we will also explore the color grading capabilities in Adobe Premiere. You'll be evaluated through several in-class exercises and one main project. There will be a final exam that takes the form of a practical exam. We will attempt to visit a post-production facility each quarter and may host a masterclass with a Chicago-based professional colorist.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbooks or equipment is necessary.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is one of the cornerstone classes of your production experience in the film department at NU. You'll be introduced to Super 16mm film via the Arri SRII. You'll master the bulk of the lighting and grip equipment in the cage.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
You'll learn about light, color, lenses, emulsion, and film stocks. As well, you'll review the Panasonic HPX.
In addition to the technical side of cinematography, you will begin to explore the artistic side of this art. You will expand on your work in 190 by examining framing and composition, light and shadow, and color as they apply to the moving image. You will work rigorously on your ability to translate meaning, story, and idea into image. As well, you will gain more experience in the collaborative process which is critical in the filmmaking arts.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to the theories and principles of basic sound production. Through demos, lectures, readings, screenings and exercises, students will be exposed to all of the basics of sound recording technology: the physical properties of sound, microphone design and technique, recording technology, basic mixing and effects, playback and output, and relevant techniques for working in diverse environments for different types of sound recording. Students will practice various forms of active listening, both to develop troubleshooting techniques and a more sophisticated approach to sound production. Students will need access to a computer to complete some of the assignments and readings will be posted on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Generally describe the class here. Include assignment and project information, if desired.

An introduction to the art of animation, with a specific focus on 2 dimensional character animation. In conjunction with weekly screenings, demonstrations, lectures and discussion, students will complete several assignments designed to develop their skills in character animation. They will also complete all aspects of production on a short animation project of their choosing. This will include treatment/script, storyboards, character model sheets, animatic, backgrounds, layout, animation, editing, titles and sound.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: 190 prerequisite or permission of instructor

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students should complete the course with a basic understanding of character design, timing for animation, storyboards, layout, character animation, backgrounds, lip sync for animation as well as basic character locomotion. The course will work primarily with Adobe After Effects software, so students should complete the class with a fair understanding of the software.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce fundamental concepts in 3D modeling and animation as digital extensions of drawing and moving image media. Students will respond to a series of conceptual challenges by practically demonstrating techniques learned in lecture, discussion, and workshop. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and unit projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior 3D modeling and animation experience, although students with experience are welcome to enroll.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the quarter students should have a strong understanding of the field of 3D modeling and animation. Students should also have a working understanding of fundamental 3D modeling and animation techniques as well as how to choose an effective and meaningful approach to resolve a particular concept.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Readings will be provided as pdf or web documents.
Maya (provided on computers in lab)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is a two-quarter sequence in which each student focuses on directing a short film of greater ambition and scale than is normally feasible to complete in a single quarter. The student will demonstrate the ability to conceive, plan and execute the overall storytelling (e.g. screenplay development, directing actors, implementing audiovisual design, editing, etc.) required for the project and continue to develop their own personal methods and practices of filmmaking to develop their voice as an artist as well as engage in constructive critique of their classmates' work.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Admission to this class is through a submission process only. Juniors who are interested in the Senior Directing sequence should apply in the spring quarter.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Through in-class presentations and critiques, as well as one-on-one consultations with the instructor, the following will be emphasized: screenplay development, audio-visual design, directing (especially working with actors) and pre-production preparation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: At least one portable hard drive is required for storage of footage. Two or even three harddrives as backups are recommended. One textbook, Judith Weston's Directing Actors: Creating Memorable Performances for Film & Television. Michael Wiese Productions, 1999 is required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the relationship between literary fiction and media criticism. The primary work of seminar will be to discuss assigned stories and novels that attempt to capture the social, political, and cultural implications of historical media. Authors for the term will include Henry James, Nathanial West, J.G. Ballard, Joan Didion, as well as several contemporary writers focusing on media culture.

descriptions.name: Overview of Class
descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This class examines historical and contemporary attempts to engage issues of style and narration in audio-visual media.
We will examine techniques of both formal and cultural analysis, from early debates over "film language" to contemporary interest in transmedial narrative. While textual analysis cannot be taught as a science, participants in this seminar can expect to cultivate and/or improve their interpretive skills across all audio-visual media.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course aims to provide students with the tools necessary to pitch, develop, and write a pilot episode of an original half- hour single camera comedy. Current television pilots and series will be analyzed.

The class will replicate as much as possible the atmosphere of the "writers' room" on a sitcom during production. As with a real sitcom staff, the class will offer constructive criticism of each other's work. The various roles in the writer's room will also be explored. Students will pitch an idea for a half hour single camera show and then go through the process of developing that idea into a pilot script. One of those scripts will then be chosen by a professional panel to be produced in the spring.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
o How To Write For Television - Madeline Dimaggio
o Inside The Room: Writing Television with the Pros? - Linda Venis

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: How is story structure related to the construction of meaning for documentary filmmakers? How do aesthetic concerns and stylistic choices reinforce meaning created by story structure? How do documentary filmmakers design, create and explore with practical narrative storytelling techniques in mind? Students will analyze, unpack and study the narrative structure of film forms across the broad spectrum of documentary filmmaking practice and its relationship to basic visual design components. Particular attention will be paid to structural analysis from a creative practitioner's point-of-view, and how structural design plays out in all stages of documentary practice, from pre-production through editing. The class will take a formalist approach to relating style to meaning production, but issues regarding representation, cultural inflection/bias, and an expansive approach to narrativity will be considered so students have a broad understanding of the complex intersection of form, content, directorial intention and viewer reception.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- Identify basic visual components and understand how they interrelate with narrative structure
- Understand various narrative approaches to doc filmmaking, especially regarding short form
- Demonstrate control over visual components and structure via: outlining the narrative structure of a short documentary; breaking down the visual arc of a scene in a feature; and presenting a proposal for a short documentary including visual design plan

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
- The Visual Story: Seeing the Structure of Film, TV, and New Media (2nd Ed). Focal Press, 2008. Block, Bruce. ISBN-13: 978-0-240-80779-9

- Additional readings posted to Canvas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students will be introduced to the technical and theoretical components necessary for media construction: narrative, sound, image, and editing. Projects will include audio and video exercises and will culminate in the production of group short films.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will have a working knowledge of the core components, both technical and theoretical, of creating media.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, discussion, lab, and screenings.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Projects will be evaluated on technical achievement (videography, sound, editing, lighting, and production design) as well as their ability to convey narrative. There will also be written and practical exams.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
CAGE/EQUIPMENT DEPOSIT: $50 (refundable)

USB 3.0 portable external hard drive (at least 500 GB recommended)

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
Students in this course will learn and use the C-100 camcorder, a Zoom audio recorder and microphones, a basic lighting kit, and editing.

Students must pay a $50 refundable equipment deposit to the equipment cage in Louis Hall by week 2 of the quarter. This is a pre-requisite for checking out the required equipment for class, as well as using the editing lab.

name: Seminar: Studies in Film and Video Prod

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is focused on expanding students' foundational knowledge of cinematography, sound recording, lighting, and editing specifically for documentary projects. Initially using the Canon C100 camera, students will learn to master the technical and aesthetic challenges and opportunities of shooting non-fiction. Using Adobe Premiere Pro CC software, the editing portion of the course will cover theoretical, organizational, and practical aspects of documentary post-production. The exercises and assignments in this course will build practical skills, while also allowing for aesthetic exploration. Class time will be devoted to the introduction of concepts and various technologies, in-class exercises, viewing relevant documentaries, discussion of techniques, and providing feedback for students' work.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Registration is reserved for MFA in Documentary Media students.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will acquire technical skills along with a deeper understanding of aesthetic considerations in documentary production.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on the following: hands-on production and editing exercises and assignments in and outside of class, written assignments, in-class presentations, completed readings, and class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Introduction to Cinematography: Learning Through Practice (1st ed). Hoser, Tania. Focal Press/Routledge, 2018
ISBN 978-1-138-23514-4 Approx $55 for paperback; e-book version available at a lower cost.

External USB 3.0 hard-drive for editing. Recommended minimum size: 1 TB. Cost approximately $60 - $120.The hard drive can be used for other classes and assignments as well.

Refundable Cage equipment deposit card must be on file: $50

name: Seminar: Studies in Film and Video Prod

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course we will dive more deeply into cinematography topics introduced in 380. The course will focus on concepts and techniques in areas like camera movement, coverage, lighting techniques, working with two cameras, and / or green screen and motion control. We will also look at films and clips in and out of class to discuss how storytelling can benefit from the visual language of cinematography.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The course will use the Canon C300 and C500 cameras and their associated post-production workflows. We'll explore more advanced lighting equipment as we work to further expand your skills and vision as cinematographers and filmmakers. While the class will work with more advanced equipment, the focus of the class will be on the concepts and techniques discussed, not the gear. All students who have taken 190 and 380 are welcome regardless of their familiarity with equipment.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Students will work in small groups on two projects and 2-3 smaller exercises. Students will take a practical exam at the end of the course to demonstrate their proficiency with the equipment.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbooks are needed, but students would benefit from a large-capacity portable hard drive and the optional purchase of a $25 BNC cable (not needed for the first week of class; instructor will provide details).

name: Foundations of Writing for Screen & Stage

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Students in this intensive workshop will learn transportable storytelling concepts
fundamental to artistic expression on the screen and stage. They will learn how core
concepts of character, structure, plot, theme and tone apply within existing media and
how, in a rapidly-expanding technological universe, they will continue to apply to all
media yet-to-come.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Through the viewing and analysis of short films and scenes and sequences from features,
students will learn how the above concepts are utilized to express personal vision. With
the goal of writing and revising their own short film screenplay, emphasis throughout will
be placed on mastery of all aspects of the art and craft of screenwriting. In conjunction
with RTVF 475 (and/or other courses), students will be supplied with tools to expand and
enrich their appreciation of all aspects of filmmaking and screenwriting in particular.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Lectures, reading assignments, discussion, in-class viewing of short films and selected
film clips, and in-class workshop of student assignments. Above all else, the environment
will be a supportive one and students will be encouraged to participate in a community
marked by an atmosphere of collaboration.
Writing assignments are arranged to mirror a writer's creative process starting with ideas
and culminating in the successful completion of a 10-page screenplay and a 20-30 page
screenplay (or 2 additional 10-page screenplays) for a short "film" (the experience not the
shooting medium).

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Grades will be based on the breakdown below (although I reserve the right to adjust this
over the summer as the syllabus developed):
OBJECTIVE
Attendance 10%
Professionalism 10% energy, commitment, doing the work on time, work looks perfect as
we flip through your pages, xeroxed, no printer problems, etc. Also no recreational
computer work, cell phones, texting, etc.
2
Progress 5%
ANALYSES
1-page paper - visual development (How is the story told in images, actions, ideas as
opposed to dialogue) 5%
1-page paper - structural analysis (Scene, Sequence or Acts) 5%
Character Map 5%
1-2 page paper - mythic journey 5%
1-2 page paper - book report on an assigned book (McKee, Aristotle, Campbell) +
verbal presentation about that book to the class. 5%
SCREENWRITING
Final synopsis for character-based film or "wordless"/no talking film 10%
Final 10 page screenplay 10%
Final 20-30 page screenplay (or 2 10 page screenplays) 30%
Grading of screenwriting is based on to what extent did you accomplish the goals
emphasized by the course (i.e. structural twists, strong beginning and ending, echoes,
etc.)? To what extent did you follow through what was set up in the beginning? Is the
script whole, feel complete? Does it represent a coherent vision? Is there a question
that's answered? If sloppy, does it have fire and originality, a strong voice that can't be
ignored?
REQUIRED BACKGROUND ASSIGNMENTS: 10 page plays for competitions
(more in class).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is the first in a sequence of three workshop courses that second year MFA students in Writing for the Screen and Stage will complete during the 2019-2020 academic year. After completion of all three courses, each student will have created, revised, and presented at least one full-length project for film, theatre or television.

Please note that students should come to RTVF 564 with a rough draft of a new full-length screenplay, play, or pilot script already completed.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Working computer, internet access, NU email/account, screenwriting or word processing program, xeroxing of materials required for workshops and class discussions.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In recent years, scholars have grown increasingly reflective about framing triggering classroom material in light of #MeToo and other paradigm-shifts in attitudes toward questionable works, artists and intellectuals. Yet as this debate around the ethics of pedagogy has grown, there has been much less discussion about how we treat these same works in research contexts. What does it mean to feel conflicted about picking a novel, theorist, story, play, film, image or song for a syllabus, but unconflicted about focusing on that same material in an article or talk? This class starts with the premise that this rift is not new, but has always been a part of critique itself; the question of how to engage "unethical objects" motivates critical interventions constantly, just as these interventions have, in turn, reorganized the very category of the problematic.

To gain perspective on this dialectic, our class will look at case studies in ideology critique, aesthetic distance, visual violence, privilege, intellectual disgrace, and representing racialized bodies. Theorists we read will include: Chinua Achebe, Theodor Adorno, G.E.M. Anscombe, Judith Butler, Jacques Derrida, Georges Didi-Huberman, Immanuel Kant, José Esteban Muñoz, Plato, Edward Said, Sherry Turkle and Linda Williams. Artists, writers and filmmakers will include: Amiri Baraka, Sophie Calle, Walker Evans, Jane Gilloly, Yael Hersonski, Alfred Hitchcock, Errol Morris, Leïla Slimani and Lars von Trier. Students will also present objects from their own research they find ethically challenging. Some questions will include: What ethical approach is fitting for research? If there are objects that require more study, then are there also objects that should be studied less? How does what we choose to research reflect privilege? Where does the legitimacy of the researcher come from, how is it recognized? What sort of moral and affective economies emerge in our relationship with our research objects, and how are these themselves culturally contingent?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: This course is open to all PhD students in Screen Cultures and Comparative Literary Studies. Students in other programs should contact the instructor to obtain permission.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Our goals are to: (1) deepen and complicate our thinking about ethical approaches to research (2) learn more about the way critical debates emerge and unfold, and (3) work in a peer-to-peer way to craft more sophisticated approaches to our own research objects.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Evaluation
Participation 25 %
Presentation 25 %
Term Paper 50 %

descriptions.value:
Theodor Adorno, The Psychological Technique of Martin Luther Thomas' Radio Addresses
Sophie Calle, Suite Vénitienne
Immanuel Kant, Groundwork for the Metaphysic of Morals
Jacques Derrida, Of Spirit: Heidegger and the Question
Georges Didi-Huberman, Images in Spite of All
Susie Linfield, The Cruel Radiance

Other readings will be available in a Box folder.

name: Topics in Sound Studies
topic: Musical Media: Music Videos, Film Musicals, and Mu

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Popular music has been in dialogue with visual media since the birth of the cinema. This course explores that dialogue through the history and aesthetics of three genres of musical media: music video; the film musical; and music- and dance-based digital games. In each of these cases, the central role played by music has stimulated innovative and influential approaches to audiovisual style, modes of storytelling, and forms of media interaction. Musical genres provide a distinctive perspective on media history. For example, music videos helped to define the media culture of the 1980s, launched the careers of many influential directors, and have taken on new importance as we increasingly encounter music via computer screens. The film musical was an early site of media industry synergy, and the compilation soundtrack has played an important role in recent strategies of film promotion. Digital games show how music and dance foreground the role of performing bodies in media interaction, and one of our goals will be to sharpen our skills at cultural critique as we investigate the politics of representation, cultural borrowing, and authenticity in genres of musical media.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
• Analyze and describe the style of various forms of musical media;

  • Understand the relationship between media genres and their social, cultural and historical context;

  • Work with primary and secondary research materials to develop an original argument about media genres;

  • Think critically and comparatively about the politics of representation, cultural borrowing, and authenticity in genres of musical media

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Students will be assessed through:

  1. short written assignments at the end of each of three Units (on music video, film musical, music games);

  2. two in-class group presentations, one on a recent music video from our readings, and one on a music- or dance- based digital game.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Stephen Shaviro, Digital Music Videos (Rutgers University Press, 2017)
Steven Cohan, ed. The Hollywood Musicals Reader. (Routledge 2001)
Kiri Miller, Playable Bodies (Oxford University Press, 2017)

Other required readings and screenings available via Canvas.

name: Topics in Sound Studies
topic: Vocal Sound and Performances of Race

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What, and how, does vocal sound carry? What does it mean to hear a racialized body in a voice? Significantly, for a line of thinkers from W.E.B. DuBois to Paul Gilroy to Daphne Brooks and further, the performativity of racialized life keys an attunement to song. This seminar considers the ways in which singing voices are racialized, by performers and listeners, via discourses and practices of technique, health, embodiment, timbre, space, resistance, and resonance. Special attention is given to performances of race and voice on the musical stage. Readings also include texts by Fred Moten, Nina Sun Eidsheim, Alex Weheliye, Jean-Luc Nancy, Steven Connor, Adriana Cavarero, Ralph Ellison, Licia Fiol-Matta, Shana Redmond, and Alexandra T. Vazquez.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will encourage you to think critically about the role of sound in narrative film and re-introduce you to cinema from a sound-first perspective. Through case studies of sound across film genres and practical applications of sound design techniques you will gain confidence in your ability to communicate and create sonically. You will create soundscapes in the style of specific genres, present on the work of chosen sound designers, and get an introduction to various post-production and recording techniques.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Audio storytelling insinuates itself into the day-to-day unlike other narrative forms. People listen to podcasts while they do the dishes, drive to work, or lie in bed at night. This course will explore the unique opportunities that this intimate relationship with an audience affords the storyteller, while immersing students in the contemporary podcast landscape. Through hands-on assignments, students will learn the nuts-and-bolts of crafting a podcast - from story choice to sound design. Listening and reading assignments will draw from the documentary tradition, as well as from audio fiction, oral history, and location-based experiences. Students will complete several short audio exercises and one podcast pilot project.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will become familiar with the fast-growing world of narrative audio storytelling and its opportunities; practice new modes of critical listening and analysis; and develop basic podcast production skills including story choice, interviewing, narrative structure and sound design.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, weekly audio responses, and final podcast pilot project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Abel, Jessica. <cite>Out on the Wire: The Storytelling Secrets of the New Masters of Radio</cite>

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: We will be using the Slack platform to share audio, readings, and communicate between classes.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course offers a grounding in Sound Studies designed for sound professionals. Sound Studies draws on social, cultural and historical approaches to auditory experience, bringing together research that analyzes sound as a creative practice, a powerful form of cultural expression, and as a sensory mode integral to our lives. Students take this course at the same time as the production course SAI 501. As a result, students are prompted to simultaneously learn how sound works and how sound means, an interplay that is unique to our program. Students will be introduced to a range of sound-based industries and learn how they work together. Key works of sound art and design will demonstrate the aesthetics sound, for example, the expressive ways in which sounds are combined with images in media culture, and how mediated sounds facilitate new encounters with the lived environment. Students will gain an understanding of how sound mediates identity and provides a medium for cultural expression in various industries. Considerations of the history of auditory work will be used to indicate future trends in sound and to understand how listening has changed in the era of digital media.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers the central concepts and vocabulary used by sound professionals working across a variety of audio-related professions. The class will be divided into three main sections: 1) acoustics and psychoacoustics, 2) analog audio technology, and 3) digital audio technology. In each section, learning will be reinforced by hands-on demonstrations in the studio and the classroom, and in projects to be completed both in and outside of class.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: This class is exclusively for students enrolled in the Sound Arts and Industries MA program.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
• to lay the groundwork for a solid understanding of the central concepts of acoustics and audio production

  • where possible, to connect these concepts to the cultural, historical, and scientific contexts where they originated, and where they are found today.

  • to establish a familiarity with the dominant tools of audio production, in software and hardware, in the studio, in the editing suite, and in the field.

  • to familiarize students with the operation and application of all available audio facilities and resources in the Department of Radio, Television, and Film, and beyond.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, several small projects, 3 mini-exams, and a final project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: Portable hard drive for storing and transporting class-related data. Deposits are required for studio access and equipment checkout.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Theatre is diverse in every sense: its practices range from prehistory to the present on every inhabited continent, its forms and styles offer astonishing variety and ingenuity, and it incorporates cultures' technology and literary artistry with equal voracity. This course introduces students to some of this variety while undertaking to expand understanding of who makes theatre and how, the ways it has been and is governed by cultural and industry norms, how inclusivity expands both the conception of what theatre can be and how it is made relevant, and ways that it connects people across places and times. Whatever one thinks theatre is, and what it will be in the future, will be challenged and expanded by reading, listening, and participating in the topics addressed by this course.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Purchase of some readings materials may be required, along with ticket price to one production. Maximum $50.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Overview of class

The focus of this class is on the development of vocal technique for the performer through work on relaxation, body alignment, breathing, vocal placement, resonance and exploration of the sounds of English using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet). Individual vocal problems are analyzed and remedial work prescribed. As vocal skills develop the focus will include connecting the speaking voice to the sounds of English and their relationship to meaning through the use of poetry and selected text. Final will consists on bringing all the elements covered in the class together for a group performance of selected poetry performed on the stage.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Overview of class

The focus of this class is on the development of vocal technique for the performer through work on relaxation, body alignment, breathing, vocal placement, resonance and exploration of the sounds of English using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet). descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Using exercises, outside assignments, observation of life, and improvisation you will be introduced to basic principles of acting. You will learn the fundamentals of creating character and a simple method to turn the written word into action. Finally, you will apply these principles toward scene work using simple "content-less" scenes and a scene from a play.

Although there are written components to the course, the essence of the class is in the DOING. You must come ready to risk, to play, to work, and to question. You must also spend significant time outside of the class working with scene partners.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Register through CAESAR

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
In this course you will learn how:

To INCREASE ATTENTION to human behavior and the world around you
To LISTEN and RESPOND spontaneously
To recognize how CIRCUMSTANCES influence your actions
To identify GOALS that will form the basis for clear ACTION
To apply the above skills to the analysis of dramatic literature and to the creation of CHARACTER

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Character improvisation, paired scene work

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Presentation of Scene Work

descriptions.value: You will be required to purchase one play (TBA).

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: If you are an athlete whose sport is in season, please check your game schedule carefully before enrolling, as there is an attendance policy in this class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is designed to introduce students to the principals and techniques of stage direction. Students will develop and hone their individual creative impulses, learn essential text analysis and dramaturgical skills, and get practical experience in a rehearsal laboratory. Particular emphasis will be placed on the development of specific language skills to have command and clarity of ideas when speaking to actors and designers about their work. Students will have the opportunity to expand their awareness of contemporary plays, playwrights, and professional directors while examining practices in the field today. Most importantly, student directors will articulate their unique individual points of view on a selection of contemporary plays as they discover what a play means to them and how that translates to the art they make.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course students will learn the skills and techniques of basic stage makeup application and design, including natural enhancement of the face, character makeup, ageing, deconstruction, and basic prosthetics. The course balances the practical and technical elements of Stage Makeup with creativity and exploration. Materials for the course include a Ben Nye Makeup Kit - available in the NU bookstore in various skin colors, and a $10 materials fee. Other necessary items will be introduced in the syllabus.

name: Modern & Contemp Theatre: Contemporary
topic: Contemporary Performance Between the Middle East a

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course looks at the work of contemporary artists whose practice emerges from the transregional space between the Middle East and Europe. Many contemporary artists work between these two "regions," producing work that posits a joint analytic field and elucidates the politics of culture in multiple sites. In this course we attempt to think with artists, the particular ideas animated by their work, and the institutions that support them. Our focus is on performance-based media, including (but not limited to): theatre, performance art, lectures, and film/video art. With each work and each artist, we consider their particular uses of performance, and attempt to expand upon the artist?s project through an extended engagement with their ideas and aesthetics. Possible artists include: Rabih Mroue, Omar Ghayatt, and Jumana Manna. For further information, please contact the instructor.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: A general overview of the playwriting craft. Students read plays from the canon as well as contemporary plays, complete exercises that flex different writing muscles, and ultimately craft the beginning of an original full-length play. Open to students from all department and any writing background. This course is a pre-requisite for both the Playwriting Module and the Advanced Playwriting Sequence.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Are you a leader or do you want to enhance your leadership, management and communication skills? Introduction to Stage Management identifies and examines the stage management process. As part of this course, you will stage manage or assistant stage manage a Wirtz production for a professional director or professional MFA directors in the making. You will also be mentored during the entire production process by alumni, professional stage mangers and the instructor. You may stage manage or assistant stage manage during the quarter that you are enrolled in the course or the quarter following the course. This course is open to every NU student and it is the first course in the Theatre Management Module.

For more information and instructors consent, please contact Barbara Butts at b-butts@northwestern.edu

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Why must we gouge out Gloucester's eyes in front of the audience? Do we really have to use all this blood onstage in Macbeth? What is lost by cutting Henry V's rallying cry before Harfleur? In this course, students will analyze the Shakespearean text for performance, with a special focus on plays that expose the darker side of human nature. Using key interpretive works like David Ball's Backwards & Forwards, we will analyze how sinister and warlike moments function dramaturgically in Shakespeare's text and how we can stage them. Over the quarter, we will mine Shakespeare's text to uncover typical Renaissance production problems as well as the special performance challenges posed by plays like King Lear, Macbeth, and Henry V. Students will create both scenework and a dramaturgical casebook.

The course will examine the current renaissance of the art of storytelling, and will empower the participants to discover their own distinct voices, as they become tellers of stories. The class is experiential by nature with the student developing 4 stories during the course of the quarter.
