descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course familiarizes students with the basic principles of macroeconomics including the role of the government, the role of banks, the importance of interest rates, and the effects of policies involving trade, tax, and other concepts. The course covers a variety of economic topics, including why auction markets are so common, why countries would desire to trade with one another, how currencies are valued and traded, why shortages and surpluses occur, and why some people earn high incomes while others earn low incomes. Also, the class with have a couple interactive online opportunities to learn from different economic situations. Topics include: supply and demand, competition vs. monopoly, inflation, unemployment, recessions, booms and recessions, fiscal and monetary policy, budget deficits, international trade, and exchange rates.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: A basic understanding of descriptive statistics, while helpful, is not required. While this course does not require difficult mathematics, mathematical notation is used during lectures and to explain certain concepts. Familiarity with reading the kinds of charts and graphs one might find in the Economist or the Financial Times is valuable. Though microeconomics is not a prerequisite, students who have already taken microeconomics may have an advantage in understanding these concepts.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
- To be able to explain concepts like interest rates or unemployment rates and speak intelligently about what a change in these rates might mean for the economy generally.
- To have the vocabulary and historical knowledg e to explain major schools of economic thought, or to be able to answer questions like, "What would a liberal think about this policy?"
- To confidently read and digest charts and graphs showing basic aspects of economic activity and to draw reasonable conclusions about what these data are and what they might mean.
- To understand the differences between two countries' policies and to be able to describewhy divergent economic policies exist.
- To work with and apply concepts like comparative advantage and treaty-tariff systems; the student will be able to understand why countries' policies may be influenced by the policies of other countries.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: To be announced.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course takes an in-depth look into the economic aspects of the American medical care system. The United States medical system is very complex and involves both a variety of players and very different economic issues that cannot be simply address through basic economics. We will carefully study and economically evaluate the overall health care system as well as the different players within the healthcare market including the consumers of health care, hospitals, health insurance firms, government provided insurance (Medicare and Medicaid), physicians, subsidiary medical staff, pharmaceutical firms, legal firms, nonprofit and for-profit organizations; and medical technology providers. We will also look at alternatives to the current system and the consequences of the same.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, debate, group analysis and discussion.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers macroeconomics and monetary policy and the behavior of the economy as a whole, with an emphasis on the current economic crisis in the US and Europe. Topics include income, inflation, unemployment, and growth; consumption, investment, and rate of interest; monetary and fiscal policy. The class is lecture based, with a midterm and final. There will be weekly quizzes and homework.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: ECON 201, 202. Basic algebra and graphing.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will be expected to understand how the interaction of the goods market and the money/asset markets can lead to possible multiple equilibria in macroeconomics, how the economy can get stuck in bad ones, and how it may be possible to make matters better...or worse. Students will understand the measurement of price level changes, labor market variables, productivity, and the macroeconomic imbalances that can exist with the government budget and for assets and trade flows between nations in world markets. Students will understand the monetary and financial systems and how they contributed to our current situation, both in the US and Europe. Students will also understand the determinants of long run economic growth, and the resulting implications.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures, some class participation, in-class quizzes, out of class homework, readings from texts and articles.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Midterm (30% of class grade), Final (45%), weekly quizzes (10%) and homework (15%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Materials will be available online.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
You will be expected to follow the economic news because this class covers events that are unfolding in real time.
Further information about the class can be found on my webpage:
https://sites.google.com/site/markwitteeconomics/home/economics-311-intermediate-macroeconomics

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Protest: The Language that Moves Us.

From civil rights and black power movements to women's liberation and gay rights judicial activism, Americans have participated in social movements to protest precarious conditions and achieve a more livable life. We'll study documents from The Declaration of Independence to the signs carried in the March For Our Lives. You will choose your own topics for the three writing assignments and two presentations. This course introduces students to the study of social movements from a rhetorical perspective and explores ways that social media has transformed American political participation by democratizing access to information, disrupting old models of power distribution, and allowing for rapid, broad coalition building and immediate moments of multimodal protest.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: ENGLISH 110 or equivalent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will focus on the kind of academic writing that uses information drawn from research to shape convincing arguments.
Students will become comfortable with the variable relationships between writer, reader, and subject in the context of academic research and argumentation.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
I look at writing as a process, not a product. So you will write at least one draft and get feedback from your peers and me. You will then be able to revise it and submit it for the grade. I will lecture a little but most of this class will be class discussions on the readings and workshops on your writing.

Class Participation
Writing Assignments
Presentations
Class Discussions
Guest Speaker
Lecture
Readings
Research Project

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Introduction to the vocabulary, techniques, and pleasures of literature through close study and discussion of poems, plays, short stories, and novels. Short critical papers develop ability to analyze and interpret literature. Learning objectives for the course include the student's ability to do the following:

Understand the distinctive characteristics of the major literary genres - fiction, drama and poetry - as well as an area of the humanities; recognize the basic elements of each genre and understand how they are integrated in particular works within each genre; understand standard literary terminology and use it correctly in the analysis of specific works of each genre; understand a variety of styles within each literary genre and be able to analyze their differences; develop critical skills and standards to evaluate individual works; appreciate and find personal value in literature.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: ENGLISH 111 or equivalent.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The course will be conducted through lectures, discussions and the use of other appropriate media. Students will read a variety of short stories and novels and demonstrate competence through papers, quizzes and discussions.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Course practices will include reading, writing and testing. A minimum of three critical essays of at least 750 words each, written outside of class will be required.

Evaluation methods include grading of student essays and in-class writings, as well as considering in-class participation in discussion.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is designed for students who have experience with college-level writing but who want to sharpen their writing and communication skills. Students learn to apply measures of excellence in business writing and communication. Assignments relate to business environments, including audience analysis, persuasive writing, verbal and interpersonal communication, and document design and graphics. Writers gain experience writing in collaborative environments, producing multiple drafts and receive feedback from their peers and the instructor.

This hybrid course combines in-class lecture and discussion on campus with online sessions. For the lecture and discussion components, this course is paired with another session of the BLP program, and the in-class meetings are on alternate Saturdays: 9/28, 10/12, 10/26, 11/9, and 11/23. Attendance is strongly encouraged for all sessions. Homework will be due in-class and online.

This course is part of the Business Leadership year one cohort.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: ENGLISH 111 or equivalent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will learn:

-The goals of effective business writing:
Address particular readers
Reflect an organization's goals and culture
Help readers solve problems
Use design to increase readability
Work collaboratively
Choose the medium of words or graphics or both

Recognize and implement writing and communication strategies and relate them to business environments, including audience analysis, persuasive writing, verbal and interpersonal communication, document design and graphics.

Independently and proactively, identify current and potential professional challenges; devise a plan and write documents that address those challenges.

Relate to colleagues, gaining experience writing in collaborative environments; appreciate the value of both colleague review of writing and consulting colleagues during the research phase of projects;

Develop and select writing and communication strategies integral to professional development.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Readings, writing assignments, class participation, discussion, online work, group work, presentations.

Assignments relate to business environments, including audience analysis, persuasive writing, verbal and interpersonal communication, and document design and graphics. descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is for students who want to improve their writing skills and explore the fundamentals of creative nonfiction. Creative nonfiction borrows techniques from fiction?strong characters, captivating narration, and compelling scenes?and bears a certain allegiance to journalistic practices?a faithfulness to "the facts," sharp descriptions, and dialogue that rings true. By learning the craft of creative nonfiction, you'll discover how to interest, amuse, entertain, move, persuade, and instruct your readers.

In this course, you'll take your writing to a new level. The focus will be on three forms of creative nonfiction: the personal essay, think pieces (which is most of the nonfiction you encounter on the internet), and the lyric essay. You'll discover how to read as writers, learning from the old masters and new voices. Each week, you'll experiment with a new form and submit a written assignment. All classes will be conducted in seminar and workshop formats.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: This class may not be audited or taken P/N. Advanced composition class and strong basic writing skills highly recommended.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
identify key subgenres of creative nonfiction and its place in American literature;
describe how cultural dimensions?such as ability, ethnicity, and race?appear in the genre of creative nonfiction;
use a precise critical vocabulary to analyze works of literature;
offer verbal and written analyses of students' writing;
practice seminar and workshop behavior (including class discussion, active listening, participation) to communicate ideas;
practice independent intellectual and creative inquiry;
demonstrate an enhanced working knowledge of the processes of revision, editing, and proofreading.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Though sometimes called the age of reason and the age of Johnson, the eighteenth century might more aptly be described as the age of satire, the age of wit, or even the age of the outlandish, as we'll see in our examination of some of the most rollicking, rambunctious novels of the period. In addition to focusing on the way authors like Henry Fielding and Maria Edgeworth used humor in their novels to skewer the follies, vices and pretensions of their society, we'll also be viewing some of the films based on these novels, and discussing how the respective writers/directors presented their own modern visions of this exuberant time. Meets the pre-1830 literature requirement for English Writing majors.

Fall 2019

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Previous literature course strongly recommended. Students should have fulfilled the SPS writing requirement or completed equivalent writing courses prior to enrolling.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students should leave the course with a good knowledge of some of the best long fiction of the 18th century, an understanding of the history of the novel, and a basic introduction to screenwriting.

FILMS: Tom Jones (Richardson, 1963), A Cock and Bull Story (Winterbottom, 2006), The Adventures of Baron Munchausen (Gilliam, 1988).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Geoffrey Chaucer was a "renaissance man" before the concept was conceived. In the second half of the 14th century, Chaucer served as courtier, diplomat, civil servant, husband, father and spy under three successive English kings: Edward III, Richard II, and Henry IV. However, it is for his poetry that Chaucer is remembered. His Canterbury Tales ranks as one of the greatest poetic works in English. These tales, told in order to win a bet among fictional pilgrims traveling to the shrine of St. Thomas a Becket in Canterbury, represent a summa of medieval literary genres and themes. This course is essentially a "survey" of these tales in which we will discover the richness of Chaucer's literary creation offering various medieval genres: epic, chivalric narrative, fabliaux, allegories, and homilies-and medieval themes-fate and providence; marriage; the role of women in society; sexuality and sin; patientia; and love. The tales will be read in Chaucer's dialect of Middle English, that of the City of London, from which the forms of Modern English are derived. Participants will have the opportunity of discussing the tales as a class and of researching independently the literature, history and culture of Ricardian England.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Previous literature course strongly recommended. Students should have fulfilled the SPS writing requirement or taken equivalent writing courses.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Define the genres in which the tales are expressed.
Describe the common motifs of the tales.
Read the texts in Middle English.
Read texts critically and in depth for meaning.
Express clearly and effectively your opinions on literary topics.
Write a convincing and well-developed argument based on research.
Enjoy reading Chaucer (Yes! I'm a delusional romantic at times!).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: An introductory course covering the basic concepts and models used in finance. Explores the mathematics and spreadsheet modeling techniques used in evaluating various financial assets, including stocks and bonds. Also surveys the risk-return tradeoff in financial markets and how investors gauge risk, as well as the basic concepts of Markowitz's mean-variance portfolio theory. The nature and impact of interest-rate risk on financial institutions is considered, and the duration of a financial asset is introduced in this context. Introduces the efficient market hypothesis and its implications for personal investing and corporate finance. Carries business credit.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: MATH 101, STAT 202, or college algebra, statistics, financial accounting, microeconomics, and macroeconomics, or equivalents.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture/discussion. Emphasis in the lectures will be on the use of M.S. Excel to facilitate the valuation of different kinds of financial and real assets. Discussion will primarily be online during those weeks in which the class does not meet. Discussion will cover assigned reading from the textbook and/or from the additional reading assignments regarding the role of finance in the world economy and the financial crisis of 2007-2009.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Fundamentals of Corporate Finance By Stephen Ross and Randolph Westerfield and Bradford Jordan
12th Edition ISBN: 1259918955 (Rental Option)
eBook option is available
McGraw-Hill Irwin
Students should buy/rent the ebook version of this text, which is less expensive than the rental version and also enables them to have access to CONNECT

The Psychology of Investing by John Nofsinger. ISBN 0-13-093024-5 (This is an earlier edition. It is no longer in print, but you might find used copies available online If not, you will have to have access to a later edition.)

Additional Material: Students must have access to McGraw-Hill's CONNECT website

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course examines the theory underlying the construction of a financial assets portfolio with the objective of maximizing expected return for a specified tolerable level of risk. Topics covered include, among others, risk aversion and utility functions; diversification; theMarkowitz Mean-Variance Portfolio Theory; the Black-Litterman variation of this model; the Capital Asset Pricing Model; index models; multifactor models of risk and return, including the Arbitrage Pricing Theory Model; the efficient market hypothesis; and behavioral finance. Although some of these topics are covered briefly in FINANCE 202, the focus in this course is on a more in-depth analysis of the underlying assumptions of these models.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: FINANCE 202 or its equivalent. Highly motivated students may be able to handle this course material while simultaneously taking FINANCE 202.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
The Markowitz Mean-Variance Portfolio Theory -its implications and underlying assumptions.
The Black-Litterman modification of the Markowitz model and how it compensates for the weaknesses of that model.
The CAPM Model and its underlying assumptions.
Strengths and weaknesses of various proxies to the Market Portfolio.
The basic approach and underlying assumptions to the Index Model.
The Arbitrage Pricing Theory Model and other Multi-Factor Pricing Models
The Efficient Market Hypothesis -implications and critiques.
Behavioral Finance's critiques of the assumptions underlying these models. Prospect Theory. Implications for the lay investor.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The focus of this class will be the financing of new companies. How do entrepreneurs formulate and formalize their ideas to get on their feet financially? Once on their feet how do they continue to sustain themselves? What are the metrics of new companies internally and for investors? What types of capital are available to entrepreneurs?

While some finance theory is presented, this course focuses on practical application of concepts and theory to starting a new business. Students will be challenged to conceptualize and develop a new business idea. Once conceptualized, the next step is a business plan. With this in place, the entrepreneur will be ready to identify and reach out to investors. Once funded, the entrepreneur will have the tools for managing the company from day-to-day and to guide the company through further rounds of financing.

This course is also listed as ORG BEH 391 Topics in Management: Entrepreneurial Finance.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: FINANCE 202 or equivalent. While the math of entrepreneurial finance is not all that complicated by today's standards, basic algebra, an understanding of exponents, and the use of fractions are a necessary component of the class. (After all, you will need to know how to split up the profits of your new company when it goes public!)

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Conceptualize an idea from its kernel, develop it, and evaluate its probability of success.
Draft a compelling business plan.
Recognize available capital sources to fledgling enterprises.
Explain how to access and exploit these forms of capital.
Read and understand the financial statements of a new company
Explain metrics used to develop and support a value for the enterprise.
Develop a proposal that highlights this value to investors.
Develop and hone your pitching skills in a compelling presentation.
Anticipate and manage the evolving financial challenges of the company.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
French 101-A is the first quarter of a three-quarter sequence of Elementary French. The aim of the course is to build skills in speaking, understanding, writing and reading French through class activities, practice, and study. A variety of class activities are designed to help students acquire knowledge of the basic French vocabulary and structures along with the ability to use what they have learned in situations of communication. It uses a multimedia approach that incorporates texts, songs, videos, and the internet and helps students acquire linguistic as well as cultural competence. Classes include a variety of activities designed to help students acquire knowledge of basic French vocabulary and structures along with the ability to use what they have learned in situations of communication. By the end of the three-quarter sequence, students will be able to create with the language to talk about familiar topics related to daily life and to express personal meaning.

Schedule note: this is a hybrid course, which meets once every week for two hours (6:15-8:15 pm) on campus, and requires a weekly one-hour online session that students can complete on their own time. An online workbook manual will be used for homework.

Carries humanities credit (two-course limit for language courses).

This course may be audited. Students enrolled to audit FRENCH 101-A must meet participation and assessment requirements as outlined in the course syllabus.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: This course is for students with less than two years of high school French or with no previous study of French. If you have studied French for more than one year in high school in the last three years and please contact the course instructor to see if this course is right for you.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Classes will be conducted exclusively in French except when explanation of administrative information may necessitate the use of English. Students are expected to study and practice regularly throughout the week (between classes), prepare for the next week's lesson, to participate actively in class activities, to speak only French in class, and to work independently with the En Avant! Video and listening program and the En Avant! Internet activities. The instructor will not teach grammar explicitly, instead we will practice grammar in communicative class activities. Please note: any elaborate grammatical explanations in English will be saved for instructors' office hours.

This course is for students with less than two recent years of high school French.

name: Global History: Early Modern to Modern Transition

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Between approximately 1500 and 1850, the foundations of today's modern globalized societies were laid by markedly increased interactions - through trade, military conquest, slavery, the exchange of ideas, and more - between populations of Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Americas. These interactions spurred innovations in technology, politics, cultural values, and social systems that would have a transformative impact on the lives of people across the globe. This course traces the origins of key innovations in global history, including the industrial revolution, the rise of global capitalism, and the emergence of empires and nation-states. We will investigate the material consequences of these innovations, such as increased global wealth and inequality, environmental change, and urbanization. We will also examine how intellectuals across the world reacted to these changes by thinking anew about identity, politics, and even the foundations of knowledge itself. By asking both why these global transformations occurred and how people thought about them at the time, we are well-positioned to assess the impact of this period - for good and for ill - on the world in which we live today.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1) Compare political, geographic, economic, social, cultural, religious, and intellectual institutions, structures and processes across the range of historical periods and cultures in the early modern era.

2) Draw on historical events in patterns during the early modern period to evaluate recent global history.

3) Analyze a variety of historical sources, and create reasoned and evidence-based arguments grounded in source materials.

***All other materials posted to course Canvas site***

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: After the Second World War and during the Cold War, the U.S. had a clear and coherent foreign policy: fighting communism. With military supremacy, sufficient nuclear capacity, and a willingness to fight proxy wars at the drop of a hammer and sickle, American foreign policy had a raison d'etre, though its execution was often short sighted (Iran) or a flat-out failure (Vietnam). Since the collapse of Communism U.S. foreign policy has made fits and starts into the realm of humanitarianism, human rights, and, later, anti-terrorism (which sometimes masked Anti-Islam). Yet at the present moment, one might argue that there are no discernible principles of U.S. Strategy in the world, an absence that is accompanied by the turning of the U.S. military into what some call a "giant Walmart." As we approach 2020, neither our allies nor our enemies seem to know what U.S. strategy consists of vis-à-vis their countries and regions. This course will seek to make some sense of how this problem came into being, how it is manifested, and what might be done. We will begin with Daniel Immerwahr's recent book How to Hide an Empire: A History of the Greater United States for historical background. We will continue with works by Andrew Bacevich, John Mearsheimer, and Rosa Brooks. While these texts will provide both theoretical and concrete examples of the good and bad of American strategy, within the course, we will be keeping an eye on events which are breaking as we study. This course is also listed as POLI SCI 378 America and the World in CAESAR.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Blogs have revolutionized contemporary media. It seems as if everyone is a blogger these days. Part column, part personal essay, part aggregator and part disseminator of news and information?blogs are clearly influencing public discourse and commerce. But they run the gamut from great to, well, you know the flipside. Part of this disparity stems from the fact that blogs are like the Wild West?there are no hard and fast rules governing the blogosphere.

But, reminiscent of a judge's famous words, "You'll know a good blog when you see it." Or at least you will by the end of this course, which will explore the elements that make a blog engaging to readers. You'll examine different blog formats, hear from real bloggers and learn how to be a blogger yourself. You'll choose a topic or theme you're passionate about and experiment for the next 10 weeks writing different kinds of blogs on that subject.

The internet is a busy place, so to capture audience attention amid all the noise and chatter, we start from the premise, "Content is king." The course will focus on good writing techniques?clarity, brevity, strong verbs and vivid details?and give students plenty of practice writing and rewriting. Be prepared to sharpen your research skills, too. Your blogs should be rooted in real observations and facts, linking to sources when possible. Over the quarter, you'll have an opportunity to hone your blog writing skills, find your own voice and connect with a target audience on a specific subject area. In the end, my hope is that you will leave the course as a prolific blogger with an online series that reflects your own personal "brand" and attracts hordes of followers.

Previous journalism or HTML coding experience is not required.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is intended to provide basic Algebra review and introduction to fundamental mathematical models of graphs, linear, quadratic, polynomials, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions, system of equations and matrices.

Recommended for students who would benefit from reviewing high school algebra. This course does not count for credit if taken after any higher mathematics course. May not be audited.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Understand the meaning of a function and its graphs.
2. Solve a linear equation and its applications.
3. Solve linear inequalities.
4, Understand the algebra of functions.
5. Understand complex numbers.
6. Solve quadratic equations, functions and models.
7. Solve rational and radical equations.
8. Understand polynomial functions and models,
9. Exponential and logarithmic functions,
10. Property of logarithmic functions.
11. Solve system of equations and matrices

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The method of instruction is tailored to best meet the needs of the class as a whole. Each class begins with a problem solving session which focuses on problem areas indicated by students. The primary method of instruction employed is the transition lecture. Technology is utilized.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
This course will be considered complete if a minimum average of 60% has been achieved. Chapter tests will be given and the final grade will be based on the average of the chapters test.

A: 90% or greater
B: 80-89%
C: 70-79%
D: 60-69%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Texts may include the following. Visit the campus bookstore or its website to confirm materials for the course:

College Algebra, 5th Edition, by Beecher, Penna, and Bittinger, Pearson Publishing Co.

Calculator.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers the following: limits; differentiation; linear approximation and related rates; extreme value theorem, mean value theorem, and curve-sketching; optimization. This course was formerly MATH 220-CN.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers the following: vectors, vector functions, partial derivatives, and optimization. Prerequisite: MATH 220-B. This course was formerly MATH 230-CN.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course covers: groups and their structure; polynomial rings; algebraic field extensions; introduction to Galois theory. The ultimate goal of the course is the proof of the insolubility of the quintic equation in radicals. Considerable emphasis will be put on examples, computations, and the historical development of the subject.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Math 300 or a similar course dealing with foundational mathematics, or consent of the instructor.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Marketing structure and processes whereby products proceed from the place of production to final use or consumption. Sales management, retailing, foreign trade, advertising, channels of distribution for marketing different types of products, activities of wholesale and retail middlemen and other important marketing institutions, cooperative marketing, market risk, sources of marketing information, price determination, governmental activity related to marketing, cost of marketing, and general critique of market structure.

This course is conducted completely online. A technology fee will be added to tuition.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: There are no prerequisites for this course. This course assumes a basic understanding or the satisfactory completed of at least one introductory economics course or an accounting course.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, you will be able to:

Apply basic marketing principles to different industries and customer types.
Define the terminology and concepts of organizational marketing principles and procedures while describing their applications.
Apply the "Marketing Orientation" to business problems to create effective marketing strategies and tactics.
Describe the key elements that contribute to a business or not-for-profit organization's operational and market situation.
Position and differentiate products using Product, Place, Price, and Promotion to create the most value for both the consumer and the company.
Compare and contrast marketing analysis elements from other sources with his or her own analysis.
Analyze the marketing of a team-chosen organization by describing and justifying a concise Situation Analysis and SWOT Issues Analysis. Prescribe Key Strategies and Tactical Support to address the organization's issues.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
We will be using the 16th edition of the Principles of Marketing book. Other editions have have slight variations in the content.

Kotler, P. and Armstrong, G. (2015). Principles of Marketing. New Jersey: Pearson Education. ISBN-13: 978-0-13-379502-8

Assigned readings posted on Canvas, including timely news articles and academic research that you will read in order to complete some assignments and participate in discussion forums.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Integrated marketing communications provides students with an opportunity to understand and apply IMC strategic concepts and methods. We will cover the main functions of marketing and marketing communications including product strategy, branding, pricing strategy, distribution, retailing, service marketing, advertising, promotion and media. This course was formerly MKTG 390-CN: Topics in Marketing: Integrated Marketing Communications

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine both international marketing and the effort to market to various cultures within the United States. In both cases, we need to understand what is unique about each market and how the market is influenced by local culture and values. Effective marketing plans and advertising campaigns need to be built upon such understanding. Perceiving cultural differences both in foreign countries and in the American market is particularly important for managers in charge of managing global business or developing a global brand.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Basic knowledge of marketing is highly recommended

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will be able to analyze and classify different cultures around the world and inside US; they will be able to adapt a marketing plan to the specific local culture and to create an effective communication plan both for the content and the formal point of view.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Case studies and presentations, prepared in small groups
Class participation
Discussions
Videos: we will see a lot of commercials from around the world (some not P.C.)
Lectures
Readings
Video project: at the end of the course each group will prepare a commercial for a product (same product) to be aired in 2 different countries, adapting the communication style and the content to the specific values of each country.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: final exam, presentations, class participation, video project

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Textbook:
Global Marketing and Advertising: Understanding Cultural Paradoxes
by Marieke de Mooij (Author) Third or following editions
ISBN-13: 978-1412970419
ISBN-10: 1412970415

Powerpoint presentations given in class

descriptions.value: Participation to all the classes is mandatory to get a positive result at the end of the class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Our contemporary lives are shaped by participation in commercial, social, and government organizations. This course uses social science research to explicate the dimensions of formal organizations and show how they influence our public and private behavior. The course will investigate sources of organizational success (positive function) and failure. Students will learn how to address organizational dysfunction through applying research-based solutions. Exercises include case study scenarios, role-play videos, simulations, and path-dependent decision making. By the end of the course, students will be able to diagnose organizational problems and devise targeted remedies.

This course is conducted completely online. A technology fee will be added to tuition.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, you will be able to:

Assess how personal career goals may be facilitated or constrained by organizational access structures.
Explain how an organization's culture affects the power of leaders and lower-level participants.
Solve organizational problems through the application of organizational behavior theoretical models.
Select an effective team structure for a specified organizational task or outcome.
Design a strategy for a change in organizational leadership (or ownership).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Robbins, S.P. & Judge, T.A. (2019). Organizational behavior (18th ed.). New York, NY: Pearson Education. (Textbook.)

Required Course Reserves Readings

Additional required readings and media are posted on Canvas, including timely news articles, academic research, and videos that you will review in order to complete some assignments and participate in discussion forums.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces the theory and practice of leadership: the capacity to mobilize group resources to affect fundamental change in organizations. Topics include understanding organizations as complex social systems; the difference between leadership and authority; navigating the politics of competing factions within organizations to achieve shared goals; emotional intelligence and the emerging neuroscience of leadership; the role of personal presence in establishing trust in leader-follower relationships; and the role of leadership in creating an environment in which risk-taking and innovative solutions are encouraged. The classroom, as well as students' experiences, become case studies in leadership. First class attendance is mandatory. This course combines classroom lecture and discussion with an online component. For the lecture and discussion components, this course is paired with the morning session of BLP/ORG ENGLSISH 205-CN taught by Leslie Fischer, and the in-class meetings are on alternate Saturdays: 9/28, 10/12, 10/26, 11/9, and 11/23.This course is part of the Business Leadership year one cohort.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, students achieve a working knowledge of conflict theory and its application to negotiations; learn about their own conflict resolution style, understand how group membership can impact conflict. The class is structured in a blended format, with alternating weeks of in-class meetings and online participation. In-person meeting days are: 9/26, 10/10, 10/24, 11/7 and 11/21.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The focus of this class will be the financing of new companies. How do entrepreneurs formulate and formalize their ideas to get on their feet financially? Once on their feet how do they continue to sustain themselves? What are the metrics of new companies internally and for investors? What types of capital are available to entrepreneurs?

While some finance theory is presented, this course focuses on practical application of concepts and theory to starting a new business. Students will be challenged to conceptualize and develop a new business idea. Once conceptualized, the next step is a business plan. With this in place, the entrepreneur will be ready to identify and reach out to investors. Once funded, the entrepreneur will have the tools for managing the company from day-to-day and to guide the company through further rounds of financing. This course is also listed in CAESAR as FINANCE 390 Special Topics: Entrepreneurial Finance.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: FINANCE 202 or equivalent. While the math of entrepreneurial finance is not all that complicated by today's standards, basic algebra, an understanding of exponents, and the use of fractions are a necessary component of the class. (After all, you will need to know how to split up the profits of your new company when it goes public!)

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Conceptualize an idea from its kernel, develop it, and evaluate its probability of success.
Draft a compelling business plan.
Recognize available capital sources to fledgling enterprises.
Explain how to access and exploit these forms of capital.
Read and understand the financial statements of a new company
Explain metrics used to develop and support a value for the enterprise.
Develop a proposal that highlights this value to investors.
Develop and hone your pitching skills in a compelling presentation.
Anticipate and manage the evolving financial challenges of the company.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, discussion, group project

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly Discussion Questions, Quiz, Group Project, Midterm Exam, Final Exam

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required Text (Available at NU Bookstore)
Entrepreneurial Finance: Finance and Business Strategies for the Serious Entrepreneur
Steven Rogers
Third Edition
ISBN-10: 9780071825399


Popular Press Text (Available at NU Bookstore)
We will read, analyze, and discuss the following book:
Venture Deals: Be Smarter than your Lawyer and Venture Capitalist
Feld and Mendelson
4th Edition
ISBN-10: 1119594820

descriptions.name: Overview of class

This course is only open to students in the Organization Behavior: Business Leadership Program first-year cohort and will meet during the lunch hour between the morning and afternoon cohort classes (ORG BEH 307 and ENGLISH 205). This course combines classroom discussion with an online component. The in-class meetings are on alternate Saturdays: 9/28, 10/12, 10/26, 11/9, and 11/23. For the online component, students must have ready access to the internet.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is the first quarter of a three-quarter algebra-based physics course with lecture and laboratory. Physics is the most basic of the sciences, dealing with the behavior and structure of matter. Lectures and labs illustrate physical principles: mechanics, motion, momentum and energy, and fluids. Continues in winter and spring quarters as PHYSICS 130-B, C. Requires concurrent enrollment in the PHYSICS 131-A lab. Lab times are Tuesdays 8-9:50 pm; Wednesdays 9-10:50 am; Saturdays 12-1:50 pm; or Saturdays 2-3:50 pm. Labs will meet for the first time after the first lecture session. Actual demonstrations of many physical principles will be shown in the lecture when ever possible. Weekly homework assignments emphasize problem solving.

Topics:
1. Motion in One Dimension
2. Vectors
3. Motion in a Plane
4. Particle Dynamics
5. Work and Energy
6. Conservation of Energy
7. Conservation of Linear Momentum
8. Collisions
9. Rotational Kinematics
10. Rotational Dynamics and Conservation of Angular Momentum
11. Oscillations
12. Fluids

Laboratory Exercises:
1. Kinematics I: Uniform Acceleration. The study of an object sliding down a frictionless incline.
2. Kinematics II: Acceleration-deceleration. The study of the interrelation between displacement, velocity, and acceleration for an object with changing acceleration.
3. Newton's 2nd Law. Study of the relationship of mass and acceleration
4. Conservation of Energy. Study of the transformation of energy from one form to another.
5. Conservation of Momentum. Conservation of momentum and energy is verified for an elastic collision.
6. Conservation of Momentum in 2-D. Conservation of momentum and energy is verified for an elastic collision in a plane.
7. Rotation of a Rigid Body around a Fixed Axis I. Study of the relationship between torque, force, and moment of inertia.
8. The Pendulum. The simple pendulum and the physical pendulum are compared.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prereq: Basic knowledge of college algebra/trigonometry

This course requires concurrent enrollment in PHYSICS 131-A, physics lab.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal of the course is for the student to gain an understanding of the nature of the physical principles which govern the world around us and the universe beyond, through models which draw on our everyday experiences. The student is expected to take away an understand principles of Kinematics and Dynamics of Physics and apply them to problem solving.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture with demonstration. The instructor will draw on the large assortment of lecture demonstrations from the Lecture Demonstration Collection of the Department of Physics and Astronomy at Northwestern University Evanston campus. Class participation is encouraged through use of personal response polling system, and questions are always welcome. Each class begins with a question and answer session for the problem set assigned the previous class

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades for this course are based on a two one hour in-class midterms, final exam, and completion of homework assignments.

We will use Turningpoint Clickers

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The goal of this course is to introduce key concepts, debates, and theories in the study of modern international relations. The course surveys important case studies and puzzles in world politics with the aim of developing a diverse ?toolkit' for critical thinking and analysis of international problems. The first part of the course focuses on international security and causes of war and peace. We will discuss specific events, such as the World Wars and the Cold War, but more broadly the purpose is to understand why states resort to violent conflicts in some cases and manage to avoid them in others. The second part focuses on international political economy. We will learn how politics shapes global economic institutions, regimes, and modes of cooperation. Students will also learn about different approaches for understanding economic "globalization," and we will discuss pressing contemporary questions, such as trade wars and the rise of China as a global economic power. The final part of the course focuses on problems of collective action and cooperation. Political actors often fail to cooperate even when they share common interests. We will discuss examples, such as efforts to collectively confront global climate change and humanitarian crises.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will gain solid familiarity with key theoretical approaches and concepts in IR.
Students will be able to use diverse analytical tools for understanding issues and events in international relations.
Students will develop their ability to think critically about issues in global politics.
Students will be prepared to take more advanced classes in international relations.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course examines the consistent pattern of political inequality in the United States, from early colonization to the present era. To understand inequality in rights, wealth, representation, and policy outputs, we must center on how political power operates?who holds it, what do these actors want, and how actor decisions made in the past continue to influence American politics. We will trace how political actors construct new ideas and institutions to serve as vessels for dominant groups to exert power over subordinate groups. Importantly, which groups are dominant or subordinate is not static, and this course will interrogate why there were advances for some groups and not others, and how historical legacies of state-sponsored ascriptive hierarchy still play out in contemporary American politics. Special attention is devoted to the role of race, ethnicity, gender, class, health status, culture, geography, and nativity in stratifying the polity. Upon completion of the course, participants will hold a nuanced understanding of how the U.S. has simultaneously expanded rights over time while maintaining stable political hierarchy and inequality.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: No prerequisites, but familiarity with political science and American history will prove useful throughout the course. However, no prior knowledge of the subject is expected of class participants.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Understand the nature of inequality in a political context.
Trace the historical development of political inequality in the United States.
Diagnose and assess various sources of political inequality using major theoretical frameworks.
Understand how sources of inequality may affect some groups and not others, and the nature of these group disparities.
Utilize social science research to make persuasive arguments.
Examine and imagine solutions to the durable problems of political inequality.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Lecture
Seminar
Discussion
Class participation
Readings
Simulation
Writing assignments
Case studies
Comparative methodology
Historical and contemporary analysis
Theory testing

descriptions.value:
Text recommended for purchase available at Norris Bookstore and elsewhere:

Texts that are optional for purchase, also available at the Norris Bookstore and elsewhere:

Key, V. O. 1949. Southern Politics in State and Nation. New York: A. A. Knopf. ISBN: 978-0870494352

Schattschneider, E. E. 1960. The Semisovereign People: A Realist's View of Democracy in America. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. ISBN: 978-0030133664

Gaventa, John. 1982. Power and Powerlessness: Quiescence and Rebellion in an Appalachian Valley. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. ISBN: 978-0252009853

All assigned readings except the Keyssar text are available on the course's Canvas site.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: The class format is as follows: in the first hour, we will go around the room and share our thoughts and weekly response assignments on the readings of that class. In the second hour, I will lecture about the week's topics, providing historical background, theoretical and analytical frameworks to understand the topic, and contemporary connections of the material. Finally, in the third hour we will reconvene as a group to synthesize the material and debrief on what it all means.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Prohealth Proseminar I will meet during the first fall quarter of the students' pre-health program to prepare students to succeed in the professional health careers program. This proseminar series will be completed by PROHLTH 396-B: Prohealth Proseminar II in the students' final spring quarter. This non-credit course covers topics including adjusting to life as a science student, academic resources, extracurricular resources, and preparing for the professional/medical school application process. There is no tuition charged for this course.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: This course is by permission only and available only to students in the professional health careers certificate program. Please email erin.cable@northwestern.edu for a permission number.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of Proseminar I, students will be able to:
1. Apply strategies to effectively prioritize and manage their time
2. Identify academic and professional success resources including academic and career advising, faculty, tutoring, and web resources
3. Identify appropriate campus and off-campus resources and opportunities to build their clinical resumes
4. Develop skills to build positive relationships with peers, faculty, and the community
5. Create a personalized MCAT preparation and medical school application timeline

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of this course is to present an overview of the field of psychology. Among the topics we will cover are: history of the field, methods in psychological research, biological bases of behavior, perception, learning, memory, motivation, emotion, social influences on behavior, and psychological disorders. Class lectures, readings, and discussions will convey a sense of some of the foundational questions and methods of the science of psychology. Ultimately, the goal of this course is to impart an initial understanding of some fundamentals of human nature and behavior, as well as instill a deeper appreciation for the science of psychology. The class will have weekly quizzes and a comprehensive final exam. Carries social science credit.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will learn some of the most fundamental theories of psychology and the types of empirical support for them.

Students will learn how research is conducted on psychological topics.

Students will understand some of the practical applications of psychology.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Gazzaniga, M. (2018). Psychological Science,6th edition. W.W. Norton, Publisher. ISBN: 9780393640366. A loose-leaf version of the textbook is available. The ISBN for that version is 9780393674392. The 6th edition of the textbook is preferable and the version stocked by the bookstore. You can also use the 5th edition of the textbook if necessary. You should not use an edition prior to the 5th though, since there are more substantial differences.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores techniques for describing the real world with numbers and for making educated guesses about how the world works by manipulating these numbers. Students acquire a knowledge of how to execute statistical tests, but more importantly when and why to execute these tests. Emphasis is placed on understanding and interpreting data as well as on techniques of statistical analysis. A secondary goal of this course is to provide a framework from which to think critically about statistical evidence presented in the media and research reports from journals in psychology. Classes will consist of lecture and problem-based group work. The assessments include in-class quizzes, exams, a series of in-class "team" problem sets, take home problem sets, and a short paper (1-2 pages) analyzing the use of statistical information in the media. May not be audited. Carries social science or science credit.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: PSYCH 110 and comfort with high school algebra.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: After completing this course, you will be able to summarize datasets using a variety of descriptive statistics, test for relationships between variables, and make group comparisons using inferential statistics. You will also be able to understand scientific notation that you may encounter when reading journal articles in other courses and in your own research.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Class participation, discussion, group work, problem sets, readings, writing assignments

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Midterm and final exam
Group work (8 in-class problem sets)
Homework (6 take-home problem sets)
Quizzes (6 in-class short quizzes)
Writing assignment (one 1-2 page paper)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Materials may include the following:

Scientific calculator.

Glenberg, A. & Andrzejewski, M. (2008). Learning from Data: An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning (3rd Edition) Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum. ISBN: 0 -8058-4921-1.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This course is not designed to: (1) scare you; (2) create intense amounts of math anxiety; or (3) turn you off to the field of psychology. I will do my best to ensure that, at the end of the course, you will find yourself reflecting, "Wow, that wasn't all that bad!"

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to cognitive psychology. It will cover topics related to memory, reasoning, problem solving, human development, and language. Students will learn about major historical and contemporary theoretical milestones in the field via a combination of textbook readings and scientific articles. Each class will be divided into a lecture and group discussion section, where students will be expected to discuss topics related to that week's assigned reading. Grades will be determined by participation, weekly discussion posts, two exams, and a final paper. When finished with the course, students should be able to critically read and extract the core points of a scientific psychology article and be able to recognize how cognitive themes apply to behavior encountered in everyday life. Carries science or social science credit.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: PSYCH 110 or equivalent.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course focuses on examining and understanding the mind of the terrorist in today's world. It will identify and explore the historical roots of terrorism, its geopolitical nature, and especially look closely at the prominent factors involved in the presence of terrorism today. Further, world leaders of terrorism will be studied, e.g., the course will exhaustively critically assess ISIS in the operations of terrorism in the world. Emphasis will be placed on both student contributions as well as involvement in the class and the use of external resources in the class. In this latter connection, an FBI agent will present on current realities regarding domestic and international terrorism. Carries social science credit.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: PSYCH 110 or equivalent

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the term the student will be expected to know the following: (1) the psychological dimensions of the terrorist mind (2) a definitional understanding of terrorism (3 the history of terrorism (4) psychological patterns in the general experience of terrorism (5) a clear picture of ISIS (6) the future of and responses to
terrorism.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The primary goal of this course is to provide an overview of scientific research on close relationships, focusing almost exclusively on romantic relationships. This class will chart the time-course of a relationship, from the initial spark of attraction to when and why relationships break up. Each week, we will attempt to answer specific questions about relationships (e.g., what makes us fall in love? Is it ever good to fight?). The course will end with broader considerations of how relationships differ (or not) across diverse groups of people, and how relationships and marriage have changed throughout history.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: PSYCH 110 or equivalent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, students should be knowledgeable about theory and research on romantic relationships and be able to think more deeply about relationships. They should also be able to evaluate media claims more critically and notice how principles from relationship science show up in the world around them.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The course will consist of a combination of lecture and discussion based on the week's readings. The lectures will also include illustrations of key materials (e.g., with videos from popular movies or TV shows). We may also have one or two guest speakers come to class to talk about their own research on relationships (details TBD).

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: There will be a mid-term exam and a final exam (non-cumulative). Students will also complete a journal project - each week, they will write briefly about something they've noticed in everyday life and how it illustrates a theory, finding, or idea from the course that week. Finally, students will submit questions about the week's reading in order to facilitate discussion - a portion of students' final grades will also reflect attendance and participation in discussions.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There will be no textbook for the class; all readings will be available on the Canvas website.

name: Special Topics in Cognition/Neuroscience
topic: Brain and Behavior in the Era of Digital Technolog

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will look at digital technologies and devices from the neuroscientific, psychological, and cognitive points of view. We will discuss how modern digital technologies affect our everyday life, behavior, mood and cognition. Our discussions will include how internet, email, social networking, and other digital activities from mobile devices influence our everyday living. The second part of the course will be focused on technological advances in neuroscience and mental health practice. It will introduce methods and techniques aimed to investigate brain functionality and assist a person in improving psychological well-being as well as modifying undesired behaviors. Through demonstrations and practice exercises, students will get first-hand experiences. Carries science or social science credit.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: PSYCH 110 or equivalent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn about how digital technologies and devices we use every day affect our lives. They will also get familiarized with how modern technologies help in understanding how the brain works as well as how to use digital devices and software to improve cognitive and emotional wellbeing.

Demonstrations

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will provide an introduction to the analysis of film, television, and other audiovisual media. We will define and examine the moving image's foundational elements and their expressive power; specifically, students will develop language to discuss cinematography and shot composition, editing, set and costume design, acting, sound, and narrative. We will also engage film and media history via topics such as production, exhibition, genre, documentary, animation, and experimentation. Close analysis of assigned films is a major component of the course. This introduction to film and media studies should appeal to majors and movie lovers alike. Carries humanities credit.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Acquaint students with a vocabulary specific to film and other moving-image media.
2. Provide students with the critical tools required for analysis of the moving image, connecting formal elements to themes and cultural issues.
3. Enable students to develop skills in writing and argumentation for humanistic inquiry.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores the logic and methods of social research, qualitative and quantitative analysis of social data, and ethical, political, and policy issues in social research, and provides foundation for further work in social research. This course combines classroom lecture and discussion with an online component. In-class sessions will be held 9/28, 10/12, 10/26, 11/9, and 11/23. This course is part of the Business Leadership year two cohort. First class attendance is mandatory.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: There are no formal prerequisites for this course. While some students might have taken a social science course in the past (e.g., sociology, anthropology, political science, communication studies, African-American studies, etc.), it is designed for students without any previous exposure to social science. The course is also designed to be math anxiety-friendly: We will be discussing the merits of different types of quantitative data (i.e., statistics), but we won't actually be calculating any statistics ourselves.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, you will be able to:

Determine the best research methods for answering a particular type of question.
Explain the benefits of quantitative vs. qualitative data.
Summarize what different social research methods can and can't tell us about society.
Design a hypothetical social science research study that answers a question relevant to your interests or career goals.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required Readings
*In both cases, electronic versions of the text are acceptable.

Loseke, D. R. (2017). Methodological thinking: Basic principles of social research design (2nd ed.). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications. ISBN-13: 978-1506304717; ISBN-10: 1506304710
Best, J. (2008). Stat-spotting: A field guide to identifying dubious data. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press. ISBN-13: 978-0520279988; ISBN-10: 0520279980
Any additional reading will be posted to Canvas a week before it's due.

Note that you also will be finding your own course reading each week by seeking out research findings that appear in news articles and that reflect issues raised by the readings in Stat-Spotting for that week.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Like many other actions, economic action is just another form of social action. Economic sociology provides us with a different perspective on economic actions, and as such, it is helpful both academically and in our daily lives. This course will explore the foundations of economic sociological theory, as well as current research relevant for today's economic social issues such as political consumerism, debt and recent changes in the economy. We will engage with research in the course readings as well as in class. The course will have several components such as a short lecture, discussion, group work and guided readings.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the quarter students are expected to display a high level of literacy with theoretical concepts taught in class.
In addition, students will be expected to implement key economic-sociological concepts and theories into everyday economy, understand and analyze economic choice in markets, and engaging critically both with the class readings and case studies from the "real world".

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Class will be taught as a seminar. There will be a short lecture, and most of the class time will be dedicated to discussion and in class exercises. Each week we will discuss the readings, connect them to case studies and have group work. The structure of the class will incorporate in-class readings and group assignments to promote student engagement with the course materials. There will be no tests in this course but rather weekly short writing assignments, and three essays of varying length. Class participation is expected and will be a part of the final grade.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Evaluation is based on several criteria:
20% Attendance and class participation
15% Weekly assignments
20% Essay number 1
20% Essay number 2
25% Final essay

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Texts or materials may include the following:
Fourcade, Marion. 2007. Theories of Markets, Theories of Society." American Behavioral Scientist 50(8):1015-1034.
Polanyi, Karl. 1944. Societies and Economic Systems." Pp. 45-58 in The Great
Transformation.
Granovetter, Mark. 1985. Economic Action and Social Structure: The Problem of
Embeddedness." American Journal of Sociology 91(3):481-510.

All can be found online. A full list of readings will be provided in the Syllabus.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This class is designed with the perspective of problem solving and economic action as social action in mind. If you wish to learn about economic action from a different perspective, this class is for you.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is part one of a three-quarter sequence based on the competency (or "can do") and the communicative approaches. The course is designed for adults who wish to learn Spanish in a dynamic way and it is designed to help students achieve pragmatic, linguistic and cultural competencies adequate for a beginning level. This is a student-centered course in which the student will learn how to interact in the target language in basic real-life situations, both orally and in writing, as well as to develop the necessary skills to become an independent learner outside of the classroom. The intercultural nature of all the activities and tasks to be completed by the student will also help the student to become more aware of the rich and varied cultures within the Spanish-speaking world. The topics and textbook are aligned with the interests of adult learners. Carries humanities credit (two-course limit for language courses). This course may be audited. Students enrolled to audit SPANISH 101-A must meet participation and assessment requirements as outlined in the course syllabus.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Only students who have never taken Spanish before should enroll in this course. Students with previous Spanish experience (high school or college, studied abroad, etc), should enroll in SPANISH 102. Students with questions prior to registering should contact the instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
-Gaining a basic understanding of cultural issues that define Spanish-speaking countries.
-Developing basic oral and written skills to give and request personal information (name, age, address, profession/occupation, phone numbers, marital status, family...), describe something's or someone's physical appearance and personality (descriptive adjectives, as well as clothing)
-Talking about actions in the present and daily routines
-Expressing likes/dislikes/general preferences
-Giving (and asking for) directions (and talk about transportation, location, frequency
-Expressing obligation
-Reading about current events and cultural topics in Spanish-speaking countries.
-Writing basic sentences, paragraphs and compositions in Spanish on all the various topics mentioned above.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: This is a highly interactive class in which you will be working in pairs and in groups most of the time. The class time will be used mostly to interact with the instructor as well as the classmates. Students will be watching, outside of class time, an online video program (weekly) and two movies (throughout the quarter) and will also be expected to spend 2-3 hours (weekly) on homework assignments.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)

Textbook: Campus Sur (Libro del alumno, A1-B1), Rosales, Francisco et al., Ed. Difusión Madrid, 2017

Workbook: Campus Sur (Cuaderno de ejercicios, A1-B1), Rosales, Francisco et al., Ed. Difusión Madrid, 2017

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts of statistics. Throughout the course, students will learn to: summarize data using graphs and tables; explain/calculate descriptive statistics, confidence intervals, correlation, regression, and probability; and explain tests of significance and data-production including sampling and experiments. Basic knowledge of algebra is recommended.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Basic knowledge of algebra, such as MATH 101, is recommended.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Data analysis in the modern age requires familiarity of many concepts and methods from statistics. This course provides an introduction to the basics as well as exposure to some of the most advanced techniques. The emphasis will be on practical problems from physics and astronomy, rather than on theory or on statistical methods from other fields. Prior knowledge of statistics is not required. Homework assignments will require some numerical work on a computer.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Students should be able to write elementary computer programs
in python, C++, or C.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will be expected to understand what a probability density function is
and how to evaluate point estimators and confidence intervals. They should understand Bayes' Theorem
and grasp a variety of frequentist and Bayesian methods. They should be able to perform linear,
nonlinear, and multidimensional regression (e.g. curve fitting), and they should be comfortable with
Maximum Likelihood and Least Squares methods. They should understand hypothesis testing and
model selection.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Lectures two or three times per week, with extensive worked problems
as homework.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Homework scores, one in-class midterm exam, and a final written project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
There is one required textbook.

1. G. Cowan, Statistical Data Analysis, Oxford Science Publications, 1998
ISBN-13: 978-0198501558

Previous Editions: There is only one edition
Online/eBook available: No
Price Range: $39.49- $59.66
Other Purchases: None

ISBN-13: 978-981-256-795-6

3. Edward Robinson, Data Analysis for Scientists and Engineers, Princeton University Press, 2016
ISBN: 978-0-691-16992-7
