descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The World of Homer

What do we know of the world inhabited by the heroes of Homer's epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey? Do the poems describe a largely imaginary realm created by their author, or do they reflect a particular period of ancient Greek history?and if so, which one? This course explores the society, economy, and culture of Iron Age Greece with special emphasis on the Geometric and early Archaic periods, emphasizing what scholars have learned through archaeological discoveries along with study of the poems themselves. Topics include the excavations at Troy, Athens, and other sites; contacts with Egypt and the Near East and colonization in the Mediterranean world; trade, exchange, and the technology of travel; literacy and oral tradition; political communities and warfare; religion, burial practices, and the art of ritual and commemoration.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
The Odyssey, trans. Emily Wilson. New York: W. W. Norton and Co., 2018. ISBN: 9780393356250

The Iliad, trans. Stanley Lombardo. Indianapolis: Hackett Publishing Co., 1997. ISBN: 9780872203525

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Note: This class is only open to first-year students accepted into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program.

EMPIRE

In this exciting course?taught by an historian, a cultural anthropologist of science, and an English professor?we will ask about empire, one of the most important forms of global connection in the modern age. We'll approach our topic in an interdisciplinary way, looking at culture, history, literature, and even science?and we'll examine a rich array of texts and objects from different periods of history and parts of the globe. Some of the questions we'll consider: What are empires? How do they get formed? How do they become objects of representation, and in what media? How do they regulate the circulation of people, goods, ideas, genes, languages, and germs? How do they shape our most fundamental experiences, and how are they contested or destroyed?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: By permission; this class is only open to first-year students accepted into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Texts and films to be explored:

Shakespeare, The Tempest
Maran, Batouala
Gandhi, Hind Swaraj
Battle of Algiers and Bamako (films)
Fanon, Concerning Violence
Nelson, Social Life of DNA
Smith, Wealth of Nations
Said, Orientalism
Conrad, Heart of Darkness
Hochschild, King Leopold's Ghost

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This class is only open to first-year students accepted into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Ancient Rome in Chicago

Although the ancient Romans never made it to the new world, their legacy in Chicago is reflected in architecture, the visual arts, and sites devoted to recreation, education, politics, and business. This class will journey to Chicago's financial district, political and commercial core, cultural institutions, hotels, theaters, parks, schools, cemeteries, and ethnic neighborhoods. By walking the city, you will learn to "read" the streets, buildings, and monuments that showcase Chicago's engagement with the classical past. You will also learn how to use digital tools and practices?such as video editing, data analysis, and digital mapping?to produce an innovative and collaborative virtual walking tour mapping Chicago's ongoing dialogue with Roman antiquity.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The aim of this advanced research seminar is to train students to take ownership of their learning through knowledge creation. Students' work will be divided among class discussions and workshops, in- and out-of class labs, and individual and collaborative research. Students will meet with the instructor for two hours and a half every week in a traditional classroom setting where they will discuss assigned readings, do task-based exercises, report on the progress of their research, showcase their projects and receive feedback from the instructor and their classmates. Weekly labs will complement the regular sessions and will provide students with a dedicated time and space to familiarize themselves with digital technologies. Labs will be run by members of the Center for Scholarly Communication & Digital Curation and the Media and Design Studio (MADS) at Northwestern in collaboration with the instructor.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Daily assignments; individual and group projects; participation in class discussion and labs

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All the readings for this class will be posted on Canvas

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Attendance at first class is mandatory. No P/N option.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Race and the American Presidency

How did Lyndon B. Johnson, a product of the Jim Crow South, become the standard bearer of presidential liberalism?

In this study of the man and his times, students will thus trace the arc of Lyndon Johnson's political career through the lens of American race relations. This course takes as its starting point Johnson's modest Texas origins and continues in a study of his political labors, after he assumed the presidency, which resulted in the passage of historic civil rights legislation and produced the Great Society program that was designed to address the problem of poverty. In the final weeks of the semester, we will consider Johnson's fall, in the wake of Vietnam, and consider his political legacy and his relevance to the contemporary electoral cycle.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendence, Class Participation, Midterm and Final Examinations.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Tentative:

Todd Purdum, An Idea Whose Time Has Come: Two Presidents, Two Parties, and the Battle for the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 978-1250062468

Gary May, Bending Toward Justice: The Voting Rights Act and the Transformation of American Democracy, 978-0822359272

Julian Zelizer, The Fierce Urgency of Now: Lyndon Johnson, Congress, and the Battle for the Great Society, 978-0143128014

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Race in the American Midwest

This seminar explores the role of race and Indigeneity in histories of the American Midwest. Despite popular narratives of the Midwest as purely a heartland of white homogeneity and normativity, racialized communities of color have long shaped politics, culture, and society in the region. This course emphasizes the fluid nature of ideas about race, and their interplay with the construction of place in a settler colonial society. The course materials cover a wide range of topics that are crucial for understanding both midwestern and U.S. history writ large. From the multi-ethnic world of the fur trade, to contemporary housing inequalities, this course highlights the making of a U.S. region, and confronts mythologies of the Midwest in the American imagination.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two to three short papers, and one final research paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: Reading list TBD

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Race/Gender/Sex & Science: Making Identities & Differences

NOTE: This course was previously offered as HUM 395.

How do scientific claims and technological developments help transform cultural understandings of race, gender, and sexuality? Conversely, how do cultural beliefs about race, gender, and sexuality influence scientific knowledge and medical practice? This class will take up a series of controversies from the recent past and present to explore the dynamic interplay between expert findings, social identities, and political arguments.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: In-class midterm, 2 short critical summaries of readings, 10-page research paper, class presentation, class attendance and participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Articles and book chapters such as the following:

Almeling, Rene. 2011. Sex Cells: The Medical Market for Eggs and Sperm.
Epstein, Steven. 2007. Inclusion: The Politics of Difference in Medical Research.
Fausto-Sterling, Anne. 1993. "The Five Sexes: Why Male and Female Are Not Enough."
Kahn, Jonathan. 2012. "Forensic DNA and the Inertial Power of Race in American Legal Practice."
Loe, Meika. 2004. The Rise of Viagra: How the Little Blue Pill Changed Sex in America.
Morning, Ann. 2008. "Reconstructing Race in Science and Society: Biology Textbooks, 1952-2002."
Murphy, Marie. 2016. "Hiding in Plain Sight: The Production of Heteronormativity in Medical Education."
Nelson, Alondra. 2011. Body and Soul: The Black Panther Party and the Fight against Medical Discrimination.
Panofsky, Aaron, and Joan Donovan. 2017. "When Genetics Challenges a Racist's Identity: Genetic Ancestry Testing among White Nationalists."
Richardson, Sarah. 2012. "Sexing the X: How the X became the ?Female Chromosome.'"
Roth, Wendy D., and Biorn Ivermark. 2018. "Genetic Options: The Impact of Genetic Ancestry Testing on Consumers' Racial and Ethnic Identities."
Terry, Jennifer. 2000. "?Unnatural Acts' in Nature: The Scientific Fascination with Queer Animals."

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Why College?

This seminar will give undergraduates the opportunity to reflect critically, thoughtfully, and together with peers, on the question: why go to college? There are many expectations that parents and society place on the college experience. Now that we are in college, how shall we think about it? Is it an experience or is it an education? Is it a ticket to a job or is it the pursuit of knowledge? What do professors do? How is contemporary culture reflected in the university? We address various facets of college life, such as diversity and justice; sex and sexism; the "party pathway"; technology; the value of the humanities; the role that wealth plays in admissions; and we relate our present experience to the history of the university.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1) We will learn how to read texts for their arguments, content, and as interlocutors for our personal and academic reflections.
2) We will practice thesis-based writing.
3) We will learn how to actively participate in discussions of the assigned readings and our written documents.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Seminar: Twice a week.
Readings: Readings for every class.
Group work: This is a seminar. We will work together as a group.
Class participation: Absolutely
Writing assignments: Writing assignments on a weekly basis.
Discussion: This class is conducted as a seminar. Discussions are mandatory.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Class participation: 15%
Films / videos: 1 film and questionnaire (5%)
Readings: Preparation study guides (30%)
Writing assignments: Reflections (20%)
Paper, mid-term: Two 5-page papers (30%)

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Elizabeth A. Armstrong and Laura T. Hamilton, Paying for the Party: How College Maintains Inequality. Harvard UP 2013. ISBN: 978-0674088023. $20.00.
William Deresiewicz, Excellent Sheep: The Miseducation of the American Elite. Free Press, 2014. ISBN: 978-1476702728. $17.00.

Andrew Delbanco, College, What it was, What it is, and What it Should Be: Update Edition. Princeton University Press, 2014. ISBN: 978-0691165516. $17.95.

Ron Stodghill, Where Everybody Looks Like Me: At the Crossroads of America's Black Colleges and Culture. Amistad Press, 2015: ISBN: 978-0062323231. $26.99.

Sherry Turkle, Reclaiming Conversation: The Power of Talk in a Digital Age. Penguin 2016. ISBN: 978-0143109792. $18.00.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: Please bring your curiosity, your enthusiasm, and your willingness to dedicate a few hours a week during the quarter to focus on the question of "Why college?"

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Be prepared to discuss.

name: Special Topics in the Humanities
topic: Integrity and the Politics of Corruption

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Integrity and the Politics of Corruption

If all seasoned politicians in a fragile democracy are implicated in wide-scale corruption, but if the country is facing an acute economic crisis requiring experience at the helm, what should be done about the corrupt, and who should decide? What compromises, if any, are appropriate when considering kleptocrats who are effectively holding their people hostage - for instance, rulers who systematically abuse loans from foreign creditors, but who rely on the fact that their vulnerable population will suffer if loans are cut off entirely? What compromises, if any, are morally appropriate when dealing with dictators who threaten to unleash violence unless they are guaranteed an amnesty by the democratic forces trying to replace them?

This upper-level course delves into such fraught political problems, revolving around different kinds of corruption and abuse of political power. In order to grapple with these problems, we examine in detail two ideas related to "the people." The first is the idea of the sovereign people as the owner of public property, often stolen by corrupt politicians. The second is the idea of the people as an agent with its own moral integrity - an integrity that might bear on intricate policy dilemmas surrounding the proper response to corruption. In the process of examining both of these ideas, students will acquire familiarity with prominent philosophical treatments of integrity, property, and - more generally - public policy.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: The People's Duty: Collective Agency and the Morality of Public Policy by Shmuel Nili - ISBN 9781108480925.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Postcolonial Noir

Crime fiction is where questions of law, justice, and community are investigated, but only rarely resolved. This course will explore this problem in a transnational context, so as to expose the fundamental issues of power and difference that have underlain the classic detective novel, and then work our way through texts produced in colonial and postcolonial settings in the Middle East and North Africa. Surveying over 150 years of detection, we will use these texts to understand the relationship between criminal investigation and literary interpretation, between history and the present, and between literary style and political authority.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Short paper, group presentation, final essay.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Arthur Conan Doyle, The Sign of Four;
Didier Daeninckx, Murder in Memoriam;
Sonallah Ibrahim, That Smell;
Donia Maher/Ganzeer, The Apartment in Bab al-Louk

Texts will be available at Norris.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This course is combined with Comp Lit 301 and Humanities 370-6.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Contemporary Middle Eastern Performance

This seminar examines shifts and transformations in embodied cultural practices across the Middle East and North Africa, with particular attention to music, dance, theater, and popular culture. Spanning the late nineteenth century to the Arab Spring, students will better understand a cultural history of the region, its role in shaping global modernity, and the politics of gender, sexuality, and ethnoreligious difference. In addition to class discussion and written assignments, students will be asked to develop a creative project to be designed in consultation with the instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goals of this course are to assist students (1) to acquire knowledge about cultural production in the contemporary Middle East and North Africa; (2) to engage in the critical analysis and interpretation of performance as method of research, object of study, and theoretical field of interest; and (3) to develop an ability to express new knowledge and perspectives in writing, oral presentation, and creative work.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, discussion, and participatory activities.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
1. Assignments: 75% of final grade

a. Response papers (25%)
b. In-class Presentation (10%)
c. Field project (10%)
d. Final project (30%)

2. Attendance and participation: 25% of final grade

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: TBD.

name: Exhibiting Antiquity: The Culture and Politics of Display

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Exhibiting Antiquity

How do institutions such as museums, along with other created contexts such as websites and archaeological sites developed as tourist destinations, shape and construct our notions of the past? How are these institutions enmeshed with broader cultural and political agendas regarding cultural identity and otherness, the formation of artistic canons, and even the concept of ancient art? This course explores modern strategies of collecting, classification, and display of material culture from ancient Egypt, the Middle East, Greece, and Rome, both in Europe and the United States and in their present-day homelands.

By analyzing programs of collecting and display, it seeks to understand both the development of modern scholarship in ancient art and the intersection of institutional and scholarly programs. Topics examined include the historical development of modern displays devoted to ancient civilizations in public and private museums, notions of authenticity and identity, issues of cultural heritage and patrimony, temporary and "blockbuster" shows, virtual exhibitions and museums, and the archaeological site as a locus of display.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All assigned readings will be available on CANVAS.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Note: This course is only open to Franke Undergraduate Fellows of the Alice Kaplan Humanities Institute.

This course is designed to provide humanities project support and mentorship for seniors who have been selected as Franke Undergraduate Fellows in the Kaplan Humanities Institute. Students will receive faculty guidance through fall and winter quarters as they research, prepare and write an innovative humanities research project of their own topic. Students will enrich their research capabilities through weekly meetings and discussion with faculty mentors about research approaches, narrative shaping and fostering project progress.

Working within the cohort of other Franke Fellows, students will participate in weekly lunch colloquia within the interdisciplinary community of the Kaplan Humanities Institute, create a collaborative means of sharing their research with a broader community, and present their work at the annual Future Directions Forum.

By the end of the course, students will have made significant progress towards completion of their research project. They will have gained experience in research design and writing, and will have developed skills of critical analysis, constructive critique and creative presentation.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
It isn't easy being a superpower. For the past 50 years, U.S. policymakers have struggled to define America's role in an ever more complex world where threats multiply and challenges morph and endure. The period beginning with the Vietnam War traces an arc that reaches from Soviet nuclear arsenals to Islamic suicide bombers, from a fear of falling dominoes in Southeast Asia to hopes for a wave of democracy in the Middle East. And now the rise of right-wing populists in Europe, a newly activist Russia and the presidency of Donald Trump. This course uses an engaging set of examples and materials to chart one of the most intriguing stretches of international engagement in U.S. history. We will work collaboratively to understand why decisions were made, how policies were implemented and sold, and what it all may mean in the end. Assessing sources from presidential speeches and critics' rejoinders to film documentaries and media accounts, we will study goals and motivations, ends and means, in an array of case studies. As the course progresses, we will pay particular attention to the foreign policy choices of President Trump and the domestic debate about those choices.

This is not a class where you are expected to produce journalism, and no prior experience with journalism or Medill is required.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Used textbook: American Foreign Policy Since World War II. Hook & Spanier. Plus a course pack. Total: Less than $50.

name: Special Topics in International Studies
topic: The Russian Writer and the State

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The Russian Writer and the State, from Stalin to Putin

Independent-minded writers have always had an uneasy relationship with the Russian regime, but before the Revolution, writers like Tolstoy and Pushkin were seen by the Russian people as the conscience of society. In their works, many questioned the prevailing regime, which expected intellectuals to support the State. While the Tsars sought to place limits on Tolstoy, Pushkin, and others, their privileged place in society prevented the regime from massively repressing them and their works.

This all changed when Stalin came to the Kremlin. His regime expected the writer not just to enlighten the masses, but to mobilize them to accomplish the goals of the State. Using an extensive system of repression and rewards, the Stalinist regime either coopted writers, or silenced them altogether. Even after the death of Stalin, the regime forced writers either to put their talents at the service of the State, or to go underground. Nevertheless, starting during the "Thaw" in the sixties, the USSR saw the resurrection of the idea of the independent-minded writer as the conscience of society - but not without consequences to the writers themselves. They circulated hand-typed manuscripts ("samizdat"), or smuggled them for publication abroad ("tamizdat"). Repressive measures against dissident writers continued until the late eighties, when Gorbachev began to allow more free debate ("glasnost"). Finally, under Putin, repression returns, as the regime again instituted measures to reward those who support the State, and intimidate and even silence those who don't.

We will examine this relationship of the Russian writer to the State, and discuss how successive rulers have alternated between "thaw" and "freeze," seeking to find what they saw as the proper balance in their efforts to ensure the survival of the regime.

Week One
Stalin (I): The Regimentation of Literature
Lecture on Stalin's attempts to force writers to support the regime, with particular focus on the importance of the first Writers Congress in 1934.
Discussion of stories TBD from Babel's Red Cavalry
Week Two
Stalin (II): Russian Writers and the Great Terror
Lecture on how Stalin destroyed independent literary and journalistic voices, using repressive methods like arrest and execution, and a system of rewards for writers who served the regime's goals.
Discussion of stories TBD from Red Cavalry
Week Three
The Last of the Old Regime's Intellectuals: Boris Pasternak (I)
Lecture on the place of Pasternak in Russian/Soviet intellectual history.
Discussion of Part One of Doctor Zhivago.
Week Four
Pasternak (II)
Lecture on Pasternak's efforts to publish Doctor Zhivago abroad, and the Khrushchev regime's harsh reaction to the awarding of the Nobel Prize.
Discussion of Part Two of novel, and on why did the regime react so strongly to the novel.
Week Five
The Nationalist Dissident: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn
Lecture on the biography of Solzhenitsyn and his place in Russian history.
Discussion of his writings, particularly One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich.
Week Six
Helsinki and the Emergence of an Underground Civil Society
Lecture on the West's efforts to break down information barriers and promote freedom of expression, culminating in the Helsinki Final Act. The development of groups to hold the USSR to its Helsinki promises, and their use of samizdat to inform society on the abuses of the regime and call it to account.
Discussion on readings TBD
Week Seven
Andrey Sakharov, Glasnost, and the Rise and Fall of Gorbachev
Lecture on Sakharov's efforts to open up Soviet science and society to liberal ideas, despite repressive measures against him, and on Gorbachev and his attempts to loosen control over writers ("glasnost").
Discussion of his Nobel Prize speech and other writings TBD. Other readings TBD on openness vs. censorship. Did "glasnost" inevitably and fatally undermine the regime?
Week Eight
Putin (2000-2014): Publish and Perish (I)
Lecture on Putin's use of intimidation, even violence, against investigative journalists who attempt to expose his regime. The case of Anna Politkovskaya and Novaya Gazeta.
Discussion of selected chapters from Politkovskaya's Putin's Russia
Week Nine
Putin (2014-present): Publish and Perish (II)
Lecture on Putin's attempts to intimidate, marginalize, and even silence politicians who publish exposes the corruption of Putin's regime. The cases of Boris Nemtsov and Aleksey Navalny.
Discussion of Nemtsov's expose of Putin's war on Ukraine ("War. Putin")

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on class participation (30%), a midterm book review (20%), and a final paper (50%) discussing whether the Soviet political system could have survived, or whether Putin's regime could survive, without repressing free expression. Other final-paper themes regarding the relationship of the Russian writer to the State will be considered.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required readings:

Red Cavalry, by Isaak Babel
Doctor Zhivago, by Boris Pasternak
One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich, by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn
Putin's Russia, by Anna Politkovskaya
OthersTBD

name: Integrating Project Seminar
topic: Race and International Politics in the (Post-)Colo

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: How have race and colonialism shaped and affected international politics? How and why do they matter for international politics today? In this project seminar we will examine the ways in which race and colonialism have been and are central to the study and practice of international politics from an interdisciplinary perspective, drawing from a number fields, including political science and international relations, social and political theory, history, and literature. We will engage with works in postcolonial studies, critical race theory, and decolonial thought in order to gain an understanding of both race and colonialism, and to see how insights from such works have been and can be incorporated into research on international politics on subjects such as international law and human rights, security, political economy, and international relations theory. This seminar will also enable students to design and execute their own research projects by helping them develop the necessary research skills to write research papers on a topic of their choosing. In this, we will consider issues such as how to think about and work with concepts like race and colonialism, how to make sense of and interpret social and political phenomena, and how to conduct research with an awareness of our own positions as researchers.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
The aim of this seminar is to enable students to:
? Develop an understanding of the role and place of race and colonialism in international politics
? Gain a strong familiarity with postcolonial and critical race studies, the claims they make, and the issues they raise
? Productively engage and work with perspectives from a variety of disciplines
? Effectively discuss their ideas, as well as the ideas of others in a collegial and interdisciplinary environment
? Develop key research skills for designing and executing research projects
? Practise communicating their research in an effective manner, both verbally and in writing
? Write a compelling, coherent, and engaging research paper on a topic of interest to them

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Short lectures, seminar-style and in-depth discussions of readings, writing and peer-review workshops.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Seminar participation, presentations, and papers.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Things Fall Apart (Chinua Achebe). All other readings will be made available on Canvas.

name: Integrating Project Seminar
topic: Everyday Life in Global and Comparative Perspectiv

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: How can we make sense of the daily, the mundane, the ordinary, in a complex and changing world? In this integrating project seminar, we will capture the complexity and heterogeneity of everyday life across societies, and uncover the cultural, demographic, social, economic, legal, political, and institutional forces that shape it. For these purposes, we will borrow from several theoretical, disciplinary, and interdisciplinary perspectives (including sociology, history, anthropology, cultural studies, health sciences, economics, law, and political science). We will investigate the tensions between the individual and the group; the idiosyncratic and the shared; the local and the global; the national, transnational, and international; the context-bound and the universal. We will identify - and learn how to avoid - such common pitfalls as stigmatization, stereotyping, miserabilism, romanticization, and exoticization. All along, students will develop research skills and pursue their own research paper addressing issues of everyday life. This paper will comply with rigorous standards of research, and involve passion, creativity, and personal meaningfulness. I hope you will enjoy the journey!

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
You should expect to come away with:
-A (scholarly!) understanding of everyday life
-Key research skills
-An understanding of the ways in which the global and the local shape each other
-Critical and intercultural reading, thinking, discussing, and writing skills
-Practice with an interdisciplinary approach to international studies
-Practice with reading diverse genres in the global humanities and social sciences
-Intellectual and professional collegiality with your fellow IS majors
-Intellectual tools for lifelong learning and professional development on international issues
-A rigorous, proud, and publishable research paper

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Memos (24%) / Rough draft (25%) / Peer reviews (4%) / Final paper (35%) / Active and engaged participation in class (4%) / Position & reflection paragraphs and attendance (8%)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: A beginning course in Italian language and culture, Elementary Italian develops the four basic language skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) while introducing students to Italy and its people. At the end of full-year Italian 101 sequence, students will be able to ask and answer simple questions in Italian, write grammatically correct sentences, and follow the drift of simple conversations. Students will gain knowledge of fundamental aspects of Italian culture, history, and geography. This course is the first in a three-part sequence for beginning students of Italian. Classes are conducted almost entirely in Italian and are very lively, with lots of give-and-take among participants. Students with some experience in Italian may take the online placement test to place out of any or all of the first-year sequence.

descriptions.value: None.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Intermediate Italian continues and completes the two-year sequence in Italian language. At the end of the full 102 sequence (102-1,2,3), students will be able to create with the language, talk about familiar topics, comprehend the main ideas and some supporting details of articles, stories, and other texts dealing with topics of a concrete nature, and write grammatically correct paragraphs. Students will significantly increase their knowledge of Italy's history and culture. Having completed the entire sequence of Italian 102, students will be eligible to study in Italy and will be ready to embark on the minor or major in Italian. The second-year Italian course sequence completes the two-year WCAS language requirement. The classroom is very lively, with lots of conversation, partnering, and small group exercises. Students will be nurtured toward independence, posing and solving language problems on their own and in collaboration with classmates. While speaking and listening continue as the center of class activity, they will focus more intensively on reading and writing Italian.

descriptions.value:
Prerequisite: 101-3 or equivalent.
Students with some background in Italian can take the online placement test

At the end of the full 102 sequence (102-1,2,3), students will be able to create with the language, talk about familiar topics, comprehend the main ideas and some supporting details of articles, stories, and other texts dealing with topics of a concrete nature, and write grammatically correct paragraphs. Students will significantly increase their knowledge of Italy's history and culture. Having completed the entire sequence of Italian 102, students will be eligible to study in Italy and will be ready to embark on the minor or major in Italian. The second-year Italian course sequence completes the two-year WCAS language requirement. The classroom is very lively, with lots of conversation, partnering, and small group exercises. Students will be nurtured toward independence, posing and solving language problems on their own and in collaboration with classmates. While speaking and listening continue as the center of class activity, they will focus more intensively on reading and writing Italian.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Italian 133/134 is an intensive double course which covers two years of Italian in one academic year. It is designed for students who wish to fulfill the language requirement in one year, for those who speak another Romance language, or for those interested in music, art history or other fields of studies that require a reading knowledge of Italian. During the year students attend field trips to opera performances, art exhibits, and screenings at the Chicago International Film festival and the Gene Siskel Film Center. In the classroom we will explore Italian language and culture through short stories, arias, film, and art works. After completing Italian 133/134, students will be eligible to study in Italy and will be prepared to embark on a minor or major in Italian. This class is highly immersive and interactive, and will be scheduled to meet at the same time throughout the year-long course of study.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course examines linguistic and cultural aspects that characterize Italian media in the 21st century. By exploring a variety of different texts -news, TV shows, movies, songs, ads, emails, text messages, tweets- students will investigate the strategies and ways each medium uses to convey messages. Also, they will explore the multiple roles that media play in the life of Italians.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: 2019-2020 Japanese I (JAPANESE 111-1, 2 and 3) is a yearlong course that covers the first half of college level elementary Japanese. In Japanese I, students will build a solid foundation while developing the four skills of speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Students will also learn various aspects of Japanese culture and society through in-class activities, written assignments, and video viewing. Students are encouraged to identify and self-correct errors in their language use to become independent learners. The instructor will assist in this learning process through oral and written feedback. Careful and thorough review and preparation for each class session are required.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Except for JAPANESE 111-1, students must pass the preceding course with C- or above, or must be placed into the course by the departmental placement test.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal of Japanese I is to bring students' overall Japanese proficiency to the Intermediate-Low level defined by the American Council on Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL) proficiency guidelines. Upon the satisfactory completion of the course, the students will be able to greet, introduce themselves, describe their families and friends, discuss their daily routines and experiences, and write letters to teachers and friends. ??

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: This course is conducted mostly in Japanese, and class hours are spent mainly on oral proficiency development. Written assignments are given for reading and writing proficiency development. ??

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation and performance; assignments; quizzes; oral and written examinations??

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: 2019-2020 Japanese II (JAPANESE 121-1, 2 and 3) is a yearlong course that covers the second half of college level elementary Japanese and prepares students for intermediate Japanese (JAPANESE 211). In this course, students continue developing the four skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing) through readings, video viewing, written assignments, and in-class activities. The emphasis will be on developing the skills necessary to use auxiliary verbs and complex sentences to express subtle differences in meaning and accuracy appropriate to the given contexts. Student will also practice describing their experiences and summarizing a story that they heard, read, or watched in an organized manner. Careful and thorough review and preparation for each class session are required.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students must pass the preceding course with C- or above, or must be placed into the course by the departmental placement test.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Upon the satisfactory completion of the course, students will be able to handle various types of more complex daily conversational situations and passages. The year-end proficiency goal of Japanese II is for the students to reach the Intermediate-Mid level defined by the American Council on Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL) proficiency guidelines.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: This course is conducted mostly in Japanese. Class hours are spent mainly on oral proficiency development, and written assignments are given for reading and writing skills development. Useful expressions in daily life and social and cultural aspects in modern Japan are introduced through a series of videos.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation and performance, assignments, quizzes, oral and written examinations, and essays

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: 2019-2020 Japanese III (JAPANESE 211-1, 2, 3) is a yearlong course, sequel to Japanese II (JAPANESE 121-1, 2, 3), that covers college-level intermediate Japanese. In Japanese III, students will continue developing the four skills of speaking, listening, reading, and writing, and learning various aspects of Japanese culture and society through class discussions, written assignments, TV drama viewing, and a research-based interview project. The casual speech and formal writing styles are introduced, and students will become familiarized with different language use for different settings. With consistent oral and written feedback from the instructor, the students will also continue learning to identify and self-correct errors in their language use to become independent learners.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students must pass the preceding course with C- or above, or must be placed into the course by the departmental placement test.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Upon the satisfactory completion of the course, the students will be able to 1) describe and narrate daily events and personal experiences in an organized manner, 2) summarize the main points of what is read, seen, or heard, 3) use approximately 500 basic kanji characters in context, 4) comfortably and appropriately handle daily situations 5) use various speech and written styles, and 6) communicate with native speakers on familiar topics in informal settings. The students are also expected to 7) deepen their understanding of customs, culture, and social phenomena of contemporary Japan, and 8) learn to study independently. The year-end proficiency goal of Japanese III is for the students to reach the Intermediate-High level defined by the American Council on Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL) proficiency guidelines.

name: Japanese IV: Special Topics in Reading Japanese Literature in Japanese

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is an advanced course in reading and translation of modern Japanese, focusing on representations of the city of Tokyo in materials from the early to mid-20th century. We will examine a range of different genres (short stories, essays, urban sociology) to ask what literary and linguistic forms have been used to render the social and sensory complexity of Tokyo's different neighborhoods. Emphasis is on gaining facility in different literary styles and linguistic registers, and on developing techniques for parsing texts that demand rich contextual knowledge. Primary readings are in Japanese with discussion and theoretical readings in English.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students must have completed JAPANESE 211-3 with C- or above, or must be placed into the class by the departmental placement test.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students who complete this course are expected to be able to do the following:
? Accurately parse and interpret authentic prose writing from the early to mid-20th century.
? Analyze and compare different literary styles, linguistic registers, and expressive choices as a basis for literary translation.
? Produce translations that reflect not only a literal understanding of linguistic meaning but an awareness of style, register, tone, theme, and other literary or stylistic concerns.
? Use reference sources for self-learning and independent reading, both for linguistic understanding (grammar references and dictionaries) and historical context (encyclopedias and other research tools).
? Describe conceptual problems surrounding the translation of cultural texts, and explain how their choices as translator address those problems.
? Describe the social and cultural associations surrounding different neighborhoods of modern Tokyo.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion, Workshop

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Attendance and participation, weekly writing assignments, midterm exam, final project

name: First-Year Seminar
topic: A Rabbi and a Priest walk into a bar to talk about

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: A Rabbi and a Priest walk into a bar to talk about God.

As the course title suggests, when Jews and Christians get together we expect them to be joking around about practices like wearing prayer shawls, not eating pork, or abstaining from sex. But what happens when Jews and Christians try to talk together in a serious way about the Bible? Or what happens when we die? Or even about the nature of God? In this class, we will consider whether it is possible for people from different faith traditions to learn from one another in a way that is constructive and meaningful while still respecting the differences between them. We will begin with a historical example of an interfaith dialogue gone awry and then turn to examples of contemporary religious thinkers trying to understand the purpose and possibility of interfaith dialogue. While our focus will be on Jews and Christians, our texts will include some Muslim writers as well. In short: this course is a chance to think about how to talk about our highest values and commitments with those who don't share them.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
? familiarity with an example of dialogue as a rhetorical technique in ancient settings
? familiarity with Martin Buber's philosophy of dialogue
? familiarity with a phenomenological approach to human experience of dialogue with others
? familiarity with Scriptural Reasoning model of interfaith dialogue
? familiarity with at least one other model of interfaith dialogue

? in addition, students will develop their analytical skills and gain practice in talking about values and commitments

name: Topics in Jewish Studies
topic: Ottoman Jews in the Age of Nationalism

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Ottoman Jews in the Age of Nationalism

The Ottoman Empire was home to a large number of Jewish communities that were scattered over a vast area from the Balkans to the Arab lands. They spoke a diverse range of languages: Greek, Ladino, Yiddish, Arabic, Kurdish, and Turkish, but after the 1590s the influx of refugees from Spain and Portugal made the Sephardic Jewish community the largest one in the empire. Even though they were nominally under the authority of the Grand Rabbinate in the imperial center just like the other major confessional groups of the empire, like the Greek Orthodox, and the Armenians, the functioning of Jewish communities did not conform to a uniform pattern and was far more heterogeneous in practice. During the nineteenth century, as the Ottoman Empire was shaken up by the influence of nationalist movements on the one hand, and the conflicting agendas of the Great Powers on the other, its Jewish communities also had to devise strategies to deal with these forces and engage with the question of modernization. After the demise of the Ottoman Empire they found themselves separated by the boundaries of different nation-states. This seminar will analyze the impact of competing forms of nationalism on the Ottoman Sephardim who eventually became "minorities" in these successor states. We will read and discuss scholarly works in the field and also work with primary source material.

name: Topics in Modern Jewish Culture
topic: Tales of Love and Darkness: Eros and Isolation in

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topic: Tales of Love and Darkness: Eros and Isolation in Modern Hebrew Literature.

The course aims to explore the poetic, the ideological and the gender implications of the interwoven themes of eros and isolation in Hebrew Literature from the turn of the 19th century to the present day. In doing so, we shall study the migration of these themes along with Hebrew Literature itself from Europe to Palestine and ultimately the State of Israel. Has the rebuilding of the national "Home" brought the uprooted man his long lost masculinity? And how did the female writer incorporate/become incorporated by the "Talush" narrative? How do we account for the longevity of this sad and pathetic figure? This course provides an excellent introduction to Modern Hebrew Literature per se: we shall read classic texts by M.Y. Berdichevsky, Y.H. Brenner, S.Y. Agnon, alongside excerpts from contemporary bestselling Israeli novels by Amos Oz, Ya'akov Shabtai and others.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: 2019-2020 This is a year-long first-year course designed for beginning learners without previous knowledge in Korean language. The course aims to develop students' all-around communicative ability in speaking, reading, listening and writing with the most emphasis on speaking. The goal of this course is to achieve oral proficiency at the Intermediate Low level of the ACTFL guideline by the end of year as well as to achieve the competency in interpersonal, presentational and interpretive communication and culture in conjunction with the National Standards.

descriptions.value: Students will learn the basic elements of Korean language such as pronunciation, vocabulary, grammar, and sentence structure. In this student-centered class, students will actively participate in speaking, reading, writing and listening activities. Related supplemental materials such as video clips and reading texts will be incorporated to enhance students' listening and reading skills as well as the cultural understanding.

descriptions.value: 2019-2020 This is a year-long first-year course designed for beginning learners without previous knowledge in Korean language. descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: COURSE DESCRIPTION: Elementary Latin is a year-long course designed to provide students with the basic skills for reading, understanding, and translating both Latin prose and poetry. It helps lay the foundation for further study of western culture, as well as Medieval Latin, Renaissance Latin, and other Romance languages. In the first quarter of the sequence students acquire knowledge of the essential grammar of the Latin language and basic Latin vocabulary, and develop an ability to read, understand, and translate simple passages in both adapted and unadapted Latin. In addition, the course provides an introduction to Roman culture, civilization, and history.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: PREREQUISITES: None. Students who have studied Latin prior to Northwestern must take a Latin placement exam. For further information, contact the Director of Latin Instruction Francesca Tataranni (f-tataranni@northwestern.edu)

Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays will be devoted to grammar explanations, syntax and translation exercises, and Mondays to the weekly quiz and eight translation exercises.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
F19 - Professor Tataranni

Writing Rome: Topography, Landscape and the Idea of the City

"The city of Rome is built not only of bricks and marble but also of the words of its writers. For the ancient inhabitant or visitor, the buildings of Rome, the public spaces of the city, were crowded with meanings and associations. These meanings were generated partly through activities associated with particular places, but Rome also took on meanings from literature written about the city: stories of its foundation, praise of its splendid buildings, laments composed by those obliged to leave it." [Edwards, Catharine. Writing Rome: textual approaches to the city. Cambridge University Press, 1996.]

By bringing together a wide range of texts, this course explores how ancient writers like Cicero, Catullus, Livy, Vergil, Ovid, Propertius, and many others made use of the material city - its geographical position, landforms, and built environment - to explore the complexities of Roman history, power and identity.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Course Longer Title: Positionality, Community Histories, & Academic Knowledges


This course will explore Chicago's heterogeneous Latina/o/x histories and experiences through an ethnic studies framework. The central goal of the course is to provide an understanding on how power (re)shapes academic and community knowledges in deep and uneven ways. Moreover, the course will highlight how scholars, activists, artists, and students narrate their histories and experiences on their own terms. We will study Latinx migration histories, identities, the (trans) formation of communities, and activism. We will discuss how Latinx Chicago scholarship has shaped the field of Latina/o/x Studies.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the course you should be able to:
1. Read, analyze, engage, and think more critically about the histories and experiences of Latinas/os/xs in Chicago as well as theoretical concepts raised in the course;
2. Use the course material and other scholarly materials to craft arguments related to Latina/o/x Chicago; and
3. Articulate the multiple ways scholarship on Latina/o/x Chicago has impacted the field of Latina/o/x Studies.

name: Introduction to Latina and Latino Literature

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce students to major authors, genres, and movements in Latinx literary history. We will take a historical approach, examining how Latinx writers from various communities (Puerto Rican, Mexican American, Cuban American, Central American) have understood their relationship to the United States from the nineteenth century up to the present. We will also put some pressure on the category of Latinx. How do the experiences and histories of the various groups described under that label benefit from and/or resist identification as a single ethnicity? Most importantly, we will ask what literature has to offer as a way of understanding Latinx experiences. What kinds of knowledges and experiences do novels, poems, stories, and plays produce that are different from other kinds of discourses?

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces students to documentary storytelling as a site of/for knowledge production and analysis. We will explore different forms of non-fiction storytelling as students put into practice the skills of visual storytelling. The course is structured around hands-on weekly assignments, classroom exercises and workshops, supplemented with readings, screenings, and discussion to critically discuss issues of representation, ethics and social responsibility, positionality, truth and reality, and what is the work documentary storytelling does and can do within a broader sociopolitical context. The course covers basic technical aspects for documentary filmmaking, such as operating a camera, editing, composition and framing, light and sound, and how meaning is created through narrative structures. Students will produce 2-3 minute documentary projects based on assigned prompts, as well as a 6-9 minute documentary for their final project.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: 1) To develop a deeper appreciation for how film serves as a medium for critically engaging with society at large. 2) To gain a critical understanding of how film serves as a tool for social critique. 3). To more deeply understand the implications of how historically marginalized communities are mis/represented in documentary film. 3). To develop a deeper understanding of how positionality informs narrative structure in film. 4) To develop an appreciation for the possibilities film(making) can offer as a tool for critical analysis and critically engaged research, as well as for organizing and activism. 5) To learn, through hands-on experience, basic technical skills for producing documentary film.

name: Topics in Latina and Latino Text and Representation

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
The Latinx Theatre Special Topics class is a hybrid scene study-history/lit/crit course designed to explore the richness of contemporary Latinx theatre in the United States. Half of the quarter is spent on the close reading of a spectrum of Latinx plays, discussion about their relevance in the broader American Theatre, and skype conversations with some of the playwrights.
The second half of the quarter is all scene study and monologue work from a cross section of the plays read. In addition, each student is required to present on one play, and write a two-page reflection paper at the end of the quarter.

There will generally be one play assigned per class, with each play assigned one student presenter. The student presenters are responsible for introducing the play in class, initiating discussions, capturing thematic issues, and identifying pivotal scenes, which will generally be read in class. The professor will support the student presenters as needed but it is the student presenters' responsibility to organize the discussions and readings as they see fit, according to how their particular play moves them and impacts their imaginations. The class will culminate in final scene and monologue performances, and a critical/creative paper that engages a shared theme across two plays from the reading list of the students' choice.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The objective of this course is to introduce students of all cultural and ethnic backgrounds to the wealth of contemporary Latinx plays in the United States and to provide them the opportunity as students/actors to live inside a culture that is possibly different from their own. The goal of this class is to have the student gain a considerable knowledge of the state of contemporary Latinx theatre in the United States by investigating a cross-section of plays that represent the diversity of communities and experiences represented under the term "Latinx". Through the reading, analyzing and discussion of plays, and the rehearsal and performance of monologues, the student actor will have the opportunity of exploring the diversity of Latinx culture within a safe and inclusive creative space. While acting experience is not required and "talent" is viewed as relative, 100% investment is always an expectation.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Instruction will come from a combination of lecture, designed to complement the leadership and initiative of the student presenters assigned to each play, along with some cold reading of the dramatic literature. Student presenters will also be responsible for some general biographical information on the playwrights and brief production history, both of which should be easily available on-line and complimented by the professor. Students will be responsible for selecting monologues and scenes, although the professor reserves the right to make suggestions. Final scenes and monologues will be fully memorized and staged. In order to provide as broad a spectrum of material as possible, some critical articles may also be assigned prior to class, and portions of plays may be read out loud in class.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
1. Attendance and Participation 25% Please note that each absence above 2 absences will lower your final grade by a letter grade. Being tardy 3 times will count as one absence.

2. Special Topic Research and Presentation 25% Students will sign up on the first day of class to prepare a detailed presentation on a specific topic or theme in one of the plays for the class. Students will make an 8-10 minute presentation in class about the topic or theme in their chosen play. The student is also required to lead the class discussion about the play for that day.

3. Scene and Monologue Performance 25% Each student is required to perform one scene and one monologue from a play read in class. Monologues and scenes will be performed toward the end of the quarter, and are expected to be memorized and fully blocked.

4. Final Paper 25% All students are required to write a final paper, 2-4 pages in length that involves two plays from the course. For your final paper, comparing and contrasting at least two of the plays that we read, I would like you to reflect on at least two of the following questions: What is Latinx Theatre? Is it just plays with characters that have Spanish surnames? I know it seems like a very broad question, but why is it appropriate, if at all, to group these plays together? Are they just for Latinx audiences? Is there, in your opinion, one Latinx audience that would appreciate all of these plays? Please be specific in comparing and contrasting themes that support your point of view.
Papers are due via email to the professor by the last class of class.

Grading/Assessment/Evaluation
All students will be graded according to their level of commitment, participation, discipline, growth/progress and attendance. In this class students are encouraged to take risks and maintain a willingness to fail because only through risk-taking and failure can a student truly learn and grow. Attendance is strictly enforced and is a representation of your commitment to learning.

-Some additional biographical material, historical background, and related articles may be provided by the professor during the course of the session.

name: Topics in Latina and Latino Text and Representation

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course we will investigate the rich archive of Latinx writing from the early twentieth century, from poems and crónicas published in Spanish-language newspapers to such landmark works as Salomón de la Selva's Tropical Town (1918), Julia de Burgos's Song of the Simple Truth (1938), and Américo Paredes's George Washington Gómez (1940). What experiences of modernity do their works describe, and how are those experiences linked to histories of colonization, migration, and exploitation? We will pay particular attention to the idea of latinoamericanismo (Latin Americanism) as a "spiritualized" critique of American materialism. How did latinoamericanismo respond to the increasing racialization of Latinx people in the early twentieth century? What possibilities for enchantment and abundance did Latinx modernism afford to communities in the face of difficult living and working conditions?

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Law is everywhere. Law permits, prohibits, enables, legitimates, protects, and prosecutes. Law shapes our day-to-day lives in countless ways. This course examines the connections and relationships of law and society using an interdisciplinary social science approach. As one of the founders of the Law and Society movement observed, "law is too important to leave to lawyers." Accordingly, this course will borrow from several theoretical, disciplinary, and interdisciplinary perspectives (such as sociology, history, anthropology, political science, critical studies, and psychology) in order to explore the sociology of law and law's role primarily in the American context (but with some attention to international law and global human rights efforts). The thematic topics to be discussed include law and social control; law's role in social change; and law's capacity to reach into complex social relations and intervene in existing normative institutions and organizational structures.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of this course students will be expected to know how to read and brief a judicial opinion; will be able to explain basic theories of the relationship between law and society; and will be familiar with how empirical data is and can be integrated into judicial and policy decision making.
