descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Legal_St 305 "American Immigration", Also taught with HISTORY 305
Prof. Shana Bernstein, Fall 2019

This course introduces students to the social, political, legal, and cultural history of immigration in the United States. In addition to exploring the history of southern and eastern European immigrants, it uses a comparative framework to integrate Latin American and Asian migrants into our understanding of immigration since the late nineteenth century. The course is an exploration of major themes in immigration history rather than a comprehensive examination. Issues students will consider include immigration law, acculturation, community, racial formation, victimization vs. agency, the transnational and international context of immigration, and competing notions of citizenship, among others.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: We have five primary objectives in this course: 1) To gain an analytic framework for understanding the processes by which immigrants have helped create and recreate their own and the United States' culture and society. 2) To understand the ways in which law has structured the immigration experience. 3) To understand some central issues both in immigration history and in the historical study of immigration. 4) To foster analytical, reading, discussion and writing skills. 5) To help students think and communicate critically about historical and contemporary society and politics.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Daily discussion; Papers; possible presentations

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Natalia Molina, How Race is Made in America: Immigration, Citizenship, and the Historical Power of Racial Scripts

Mae Ngai, Impossible Subjects: Illegal Aliens and the Making of Modern America

Anzia Yezierska, The Bread Givers

Additional materials to be printed via Canvas.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
LEGAL ST 308 "Sociology of Law", Prof. Robert Nelson, Fall 2019 (Also taught as SOCIOL 318)

This course examines the relationship between law and the distribution of power in society, with a particular emphasis on law and social change in the United States. Readings will be drawn from the social sciences and history, as well as selected court cases that raise critical questions about the role of race, gender, and sexual orientation in American society. Among the material we will examine are the documents made public in the shooting death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri. Students should be aware that some of this material is graphic and disturbing

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The only class meetings are two 90-minute class meetings a week. There are no discussion sections. Class sessions are meant to provide an opportunity for active engagement with assigned readings. Students are expected to come to class prepared to discuss assigned material. Groups of students will be assigned responsibility for leading class discussions on a rotating basis.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Pass/Fail is not allowed. All students must take the course for a grade. Performance will be evaluated based on class participation and attendance and four short writing assignments. These will be weighted as follows: 1) Attendance and class participation: 2 points for each class attended up to a total of 30 points; and up to 20 points for contributing to class discussion. 2) 25 points for each of 4 writing assignments. Assignments are due in class on the day indicated in the schedule, unless I receive advance notice of a good excuse. Late papers automatically will receive reduced points.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
We will read considerable portions of three books: Charles Epp, Making Rights Real: Activists, Bureaucrats, and the Creation of the Legalistic State (U of Chicago Press (2009); Michelle Alexander, The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness (The New Press 2012); and Ellen Berrey, Robert Nelson, and Laura Beth Nielsen, Rights on Trial: How Workplace Discrimination Law Perpetuates Inequality (U of Chicago Press 2017).

The first two books can be ordered through Amazon.com. or accessed through ebooks at the University Library.

Readings from the third book and other required and recommended readings will be included in online materials in Canvas.

*Students are required to bring readings to class, either in print or electronically. This is the only use that may be made of electronics in class.*

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Pass/Fail not allowed. All students must take class for a grade. Attendance on first day is mandatory.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Legal St 332 "Con Law I", (also taught as POLI SCI 332) Prof. Galya Benarieh Ruffer, Fall 2019.

This course investigates the structure of American government as laid out by the Constitution. It will also examine the many controversies over what, exactly, the Constitution means, who gets to decide, and how. We will discuss judicial review, the powers of Congress and the executive branch, and the relationship between the federal government and the states.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Throughout this course, students will develop critical reading, thinking, and writing skills; by the end of the quarter, students should be able to: understand the U.S. Constitution and Supreme Court cases, explain how doctrines of law have changed over time, analyze the assumptions of courts and policy makers, and understand how the Supreme Court responds to political, social, and economic factors.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture & Discussion Sections

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: ? active and informed participation in class & discussion section - 15% ? short in-class quizzes - 10% ? take home midterm exam - 35% ? take home final exam - 40% ? research study participation requirement

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: David M. O'Brien, Constitutional Law and Politics: Struggles for Power and Governmental Accountability, Vol. 1 (W. W. Norton & Company; 9th ed. 2017)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Legal Studies 398-1,2 is a two-quarter sequence required for all Legal Studies majors. This seminar exposes students to a variety of theoretical and methodological approaches to law and legal institutions; over two quarters, students will develop their own research paper on a topic of interest.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Legal Studies Majors only

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Once you complete the Advanced Research Seminar, you should be able to:
o Read and analyze diverse primary legal and political sources carefully and accurately, with attention to the author's perspective, position, and credibility, and to the source's general context.
o Be familiar with research methods and best practices regarding qualitative and quantitative data, written materials, and electronic databases.
o Read, evaluate, summarize, and engage with scholarly works by others, and be able to analyze authors' arguments for evidence, context, strength, and credibility.
o Understand how to work with and situate one's own work within existing scholarship and how to properly cite facts, ideas, and scholarship.
o Generate original research questions regarding the relationship of law and society and devise research strategies for answering research questions.
o Make clearly written and organized arguments that are well supported by primary sources.
o Design and execute an original research project.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar-style discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: research and writing assignments, class participation

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings will be posted on Canvas

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Attendance at first class required, no P/NP option

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: How do children achieve the remarkable feat of acquiring language? Which aspects of the human capacity for language are best understood as biological, as species-wide and species-specific? How do families, schools, and communities help shape children's development as speakers and listeners, and eventually their development as readers and writers? How does learning a first language (or more than one language) interact with learning to think, learning to imagine, and developing a sense of identity? How is early language experience related to opportunities later in life? We will begin exploring these questions by reading I Can Hear You Whisper: An Intimate Journey through the Science of Sound and Language by Lydia Denworth and Why We Cooperate by Michael Tomasello. We will also sample firsthand the topics, methods, and forms of argument characteristic of current scientific research, We will then extend our exploration by considering how children learn to read and write and by reflecting on the role of language in children's development of cultural and individual identity.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on three short essays (3-4 pages), one longer essay (6-8 pages), and participation in seminar discussions. Students will have the opportunity to revise their essays.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Denworth, Lydia, I Can Hear You Whisper: An Intimate Journey through the Science of Sound and Language. Plume (paperback), 2014. ISBN: 978-0142181867.

Tomasello, Michael, Why We Cooperate. MIT Press/Boston Review Books, 2009. ISBN: 978-0262013598.

Additional reading will be distributed in class.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will focus on the study of linguistic variation and change from a variety of perspectives on the social. We'll examine how linguistic variation corresponds to large-scale social categories like age, gender, race/ethnicity, and socioeconomic class, as well as how individual speakers use language to construct identities, portray stances, and achieve interactional goals. We'll explore how language is a social practice that is situated in history, and how language can reflect, reinforce, create, and contest societal power structures. Students will participate in hands-on quantitative research in sociolinguistic variation to examine directly how the social and linguistic are intertwined.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Through successfully completing this course, you will know the difference between descriptive and prescriptive views on language, understand the ways that language can vary, and the social factors that can condition this variation, learn to conduct and present quantitative linguistic variation analysis, and understand the broader implications of sociolinguistic variation and linguistic discrimination.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Assignments (reading responses), project papers

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No required texts (all will be provided by instructor)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Linguistics 250 is an introduction to the sound structure of language. We will learn to describe speech sounds in the three domains of speech: the articulatory domain (how speech sounds are produced in the human vocal tract), the acoustic domain (their form in the acoustic medium), and the perceptual domain (how listeners process the incoming speech signal). We will learn to recognize the ways in which speech sounds pattern in language to convey meaning, and the ways in which these patterns are similar and different across the languages of the world. Finally, we will learn about current speech technology as it applies to computerized speech synthesis and speech recognition. Together Linguistics 250, 270 ("Meaning"), and 260 ("Formal Analysis of Words and Sentences") form a three-course introduction to linguistics, for majors and non-majors alike. Each course may be taken independently of the others and in any sequence. All three courses are prerequisites for the major and minor in Linguistics. Linguistics 250 also satisfies the WCAS Area I Distribution Requirement in Natural Sciences.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
DISCIPLINARY KNOWLEDGE
? To describe the articulatory characteristics of speech sounds
? To identify and measure the acoustic characteristics of human speech in digital speech signals
? To recognize the symbols of the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and their associated speech
sounds
? To describe the sound patterns of individual languages in terms of phonemes, allophones and syllables.
? To analyze sound patterns using formal (symbolic) rules.
? To recognize and describe how phonetic and phonological models of sound structure are applied in the development of computer technologies for speech recognition and speech synthesis.
LEARNING AND COMMUNICATION SKILLS
? To contribute to individual and group learning through meaningful participation in class discussion
? To collaborate with peers in group quizzes, learning activities, and projects:
o Demonstrate effective communication of your ideas and knowledge to peers;
o Demonstrate the ability to learn from peers by attentive listening to the ideas expressed by others
? To articulate your understanding of ideas in written work and in oral communication in class.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures, in-class activities, homework projects

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Homeworks 42% (7 projects, each worth 6%)
In-class quizzes 12% (6 quizzes, each worth 2%)
Test 1 23%
Test 2 23%
Experiment Requirement Not graded, but failure to complete will result in a lowered final course grade
Homeworks. Homework assignments provide opportunities for practice and mastery of material covered in the readings and class lectures. All homework assignments are to be written up and submitted individually. Students are encouraged to discuss course work outside of class, but collaboration is not allowed on homework. Homework assignments are due by the start of class (i.e. 11 am) on the due date. Homework must be submitted online via Canvas, in PDF format. If you need to take a picture of written work (e.g. diagrams or IPA transcriptions) to include in your submission, make sure that the picture is very clear and legible. It is your responsibility to make sure that your work is readable and formatted correctly; come to us in advance of the due date if you are having technological challenges.
In-class quizzes. A total of four 5-question, multiple-choice quizzes will be administered in class (sees
schedule for dates). Quizzes cover readings and lecture content, including material assigned for the date of the quiz. If you read assigned chapters before class, attend to lecture, and review lecture notes after class, you should be adequately prepared for quizzes. The quiz will be taken by each student individually, immediately following which the team will discuss the answers and submit a second answer sheet for the team as a whole. Points are awarded based on the individual's quiz if it scores higher than the team quiz, and otherwise on the average of the individual and team quiz scores.
Tests. Two tests will be administered in class (see schedule for dates). The format for these test will be follow the format of the homework assignments, in-class exercises, and in-class quizzes.
Experiment requirement. By Linguistics Department policy, this course has an experimental requirement.
Students fulfill this requirement by completing 2 experimental credits during the quarter in which they are
enrolled in the class. This may be done by participating in two experiments of 1 hour each, by attending two video presentations of 1 hour each, or participating in one experiment of 1 hour and one video of 1 hour. Don't wait until the end of the quarter to fulfill this requirement! We cannot guarantee availability after reading week, so be sure to sign up early in the quarter. Failure to complete both hours will result in your grade being lowered one step (e.g. B+ ? B). Additional information on this requirement is provided in a separate document.
Grading. In the calculation of final grades, all project and quiz grades are converted to percentages before
entering into the calculation of a weighted average. Letter grades are then assigned as follows:
A = 92.5 - 100
A- = 89.5 - 92.4
B+ = 86.5 - 89.4
B = 82.5 - 86.4
B- = 79.5 - 82.4
C+ = 76.5 - 79.4
C = 72.5 - 76.4
C- = 69.5 - 72.
COURSE POLICIES
1. Keep up with the class. The syllabus, topics, assignments, readings, etc. may change. These changes will be announced in class and posted on Canvas. It is your responsibility to keep up with these changes.
2. Do your work on time. Due dates are firm. If this is a problem, see #3. Out of fairness to the majority of
students who submit projects on time, please note that the following late policy will be strictly enforced.
? 10% deduction for a project submitted within 24 hours of the due date and time (i.e., after the start of
class but before midnight on the due date).
? An additional 10% deduction for each additional class day.
3. If you have a problem, give us sufficient time to help you! If you've tried to do an assignment, but can't
seem to complete it, come to us well before it's due.
4. All written work is to be done by you as an individual. Collaboration is not allowed on written work.
Homework assignments are due at the beginning of class on the due date. No make-up quizzes or late
assignments will be accepted.

descriptions.value:
ACADEMIC INTEGRITY
As with all Northwestern University courses, registration in this course requires adherence to the University's

descriptions.value: Contact the department for further information

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
In the study of sentence processing we try to understand how we understand (comprehend) written or spoken sentences. When we comprehend sentences we utilize "knowledge of language" in a particular way. Therefore to understand the process of sentence comprehension, we want to understand (i) what constitute knowledge of language and (ii) how is knowledge of language put to use. In this course we aim to understand these two points and this course serves as an introduction to the field of sentence processing.
There are three goals in this course:
1. Understand the current state of the field of sentence processing.
- This will be studied through readings and lectures.
2. Understand what type of experiments and analytical skills have been used in the study of sentence processing.
- This will be studied through homework and two exams. You will experience how to
analyze sentences and how to build an experiment to answer specific questions in
sentence processing through short paper assignment and Laboratory requirement
3. Understand what area of sentence processing studies is not well understood well, and in which area we hope to make a significant contribution.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Pre-req: Undergraduate students must have taken LING 260-0 or obtain department permission to register. Linguistics graduate students may register normally.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: One of the goals of psycholinguistics is to understand how language is acquired, how language is produced and how language is comprehended. The course mainly deals with the third question: how is language comprehended. Specifically in this course we discuss how the structure of sentence is built when we comprehend sentenced online.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook. The course notes will be provided.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores the sound patterns that shape the words and phrases of human languages, the mental representation of sound patterns, and how speakers and hearers relate the physical expression of speech (in acoustics and articulation) to its mental representation. These topics will be addressed through the analysis of diverse languages, using formal methods to build phonological grammars as models of the speaker/hearer's knowledge of sound patterns, and using experimental methods and quantitative modeling to examine how speakers and hearers relate the physical, continuous dimensions of speech in its acoustic and articulatory form to their mental representations.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Linguistics 250 or equivalent, or permission from instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
? To recognize and describe sound patterns in diverse languages.
? To understand how phonological theory models sound patterns and the processes that relate speech to its mental representation.
? To analyze phonetic and behavioral data to explore questions in phonology. To evaluate hypotheses and theories about phonological representations, grammars, and cognitive mechanisms for phonological processing.
? To create plans for novel research to advance understanding in phonology

descriptions.value:

Homework (4 @ 8% each) - 32%
Labs (4 @ 8% each) - 32%
Final project (total 26%)
Initial proposals - 3%
Project outline - 3%
Presentation - 5%
Paper - 15%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: E. Zsiga. The Sounds of Language. Wiley-Blackwell. 2013. ISBN: 978-1-4051-9103-6 (paperback) or 978-1-118-34058-5 (E-Text)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The goals of this course are to introduce students to the fundamental principles of theoretical syntax, to place them in a position to pursue more advanced study in syntax, and to provide a foundation for their own research. Students will learn the analytical methods used in syntactic research: how to analyze syntactic data, how to formulate plausible hypotheses to explain the data, and how to compare and evaluate hypotheses. Thus, the main focus of the course is on learning how to do syntax, and secondarily on learning a particular theory of syntax. No textbook will be used, and there will be minimal reading assignments; instead, the course will proceed on the basis of class discussion and weekly written assignments. Although the primary source of linguistic data will be English, examples will also be drawn from other languages both in class and on the assignments.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The past 40 years have seen significant advances in the understanding of the so-called "locality constraints" in syntax. A great number of studies have been devoted to understand the nature of syntactic operations and they have been crucially looking at the interaction of these operations with the locality constraints. However, in this direction of research, the nature of islands has been relatively disregarded for a long time. Although Ross's studies have revealed which domains are islands and which are not, the question why islands are islands and non-islands are not islands has remained unanswered except for a few studies (Chomsky 1986, Lasnik & Saito 1992, Rizzi 1991 and others). Even these attempts are facing serious challenges once we start looking at wide varieties of cross-linguistic data. The aim of this course is to learn the basics of transformational generative grammar by looking at locality constraints. In particular we are concerned with questions of what the nature of island constraints is, and what our current understanding of them is.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No textbook. The reading materials will be provided electronically.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course focuses on developing and improving oral proficiency in spoken English, with an emphasis on the sound structure of American English used in the academic environment. The class will address accuracy in pronunciation, stress patterns, intonation and prosody, linking, reduced sounds, and rhythm, as well as higher-level issues such as sociolinguistic, organizational, and strategic competence. Work on these skills will be helpful to students in a variety of academic contexts, including making class presentations, reporting on research at lab meetings, engaging in job interviews, and presenting papers and posters at conferences and colloquia. It is also applicable to teaching, including giving lectures, leading discussion sections or lab sections, and interacting with American undergraduate students. Active participation and evidence of progress towards proficiency must be demonstrated in order to achieve a satisfactory grade in the course.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Grant, Linda. Well Said (4th edition). Heinle and Heinle, 2016. ISBN-10: 1305641361; ISBN-13: 9781305641365

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Students must complete an online form from English Language Programs in order to be eligible for the class and obtain a permission number. Contact elp@northwestern.edu for specific registration instructions.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The goal of this course is to give students the tools to improve their intelligibility and effectiveness when communicating in English, with an emphasis on oral communication in the American academic context. Students will consider how the academic context may vary across cultures, and become acquainted with American norms and expectations. They will develop key skills for academic interactions, such as making small talk, effective use of email, and formal/informal presentations. Along the way, students will learn about the sound structure of English as they work towards improved pronunciation and fluency. Students will have an opportunity to consider their own oral English proficiency in light of proficiency assessments used at Northwestern, and will receive feedback on Versant test performance and practice sessions.

name: Individual Speech and Language Instruction for Nonnative Speakers of English

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, a trained instructor provides individualized language study for the purpose of increasing nonnative speakers' ability to communicate effectively in English, in both academic and everyday contexts. At the beginning of the term, students will complete an intake assessment, so that the instructor can determine current strengths and weaknesses. Students will also complete a needs assessment to determine which aspects of spoken English are most critical for the student's daily life and should be focused on most during the quarter. These could include work on accent and intelligibility, correcting syntactic errors, sociolinguistic skills, intercultural competence, classroom communication skills, formal and informal writing tasks, and more. Together, the instructor and student will create a set of learning goals to work on over the course of the term. The instructor will then provide appropriate practice in each session to help the student acquire the language and skills needed to improve communicative competence. Instructors may assign additional work to be completed outside of the session if needed. Students will be expected to reflect on their own learning and progress both periodically and at the end of the term. Active participation and evidence of progress towards learning goals must be demonstrated in order to achieve a satisfactory grade in the course.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Instructor consent required.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
? Use data from self-assessments, standardized assessments, and instructor feedback to identify your pre-term level of communicative competence in English, including: linguistic competence, sociolinguistic competence, discourse competence, functional competence, and strategic competence.
? Identify your own critical academic and personal language learning needs.
? Articulate your learning goals for the quarter (in partnership with your tutor). Your goals should address your unique learning needs in effective communication
? Demonstrate progress towards achieving your stated learning goals.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Individual face-to-face instruction, in-session practice activities, suggested homework practice activities.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: At the beginning of the quarter, students will complete an intake assessment with their tutor, and then create individual learning goals for the quarter. Students will be evaluated at the end of the quarter with a self-assessment, recorded speech samples, and documentation of progress towards individual goals by the tutor.

name: Individual Speech and Language Instruction for Nonnative Speakers of English

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, a trained instructor provides individualized language study for the purpose of increasing nonnative speakers' ability to communicate effectively in English, in both academic and everyday contexts. At the beginning of the term, students will complete an intake assessment, so that the instructor can determine current strengths and weaknesses. Students will also complete a needs assessment to determine which aspects of spoken English are most critical for the student's daily life and should be focused on most during the quarter. These could include work on accent and intelligibility, correcting syntactic errors, sociolinguistic skills, intercultural competence, classroom communication skills, formal and informal writing tasks, and more. Together, the instructor and student will create a set of learning goals to work on over the course of the term. The instructor will then provide appropriate practice in each session to help the student acquire the language and skills needed to improve communicative competence. Instructors may assign additional work to be completed outside of the session if needed. Students will be expected to reflect on their own learning and progress both periodically and at the end of the term. Active participation and evidence of progress towards learning goals must be demonstrated in order to achieve a satisfactory grade in the course.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Instructor consent required.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
? Use data from self-assessments, standardized assessments, and instructor feedback to identify your pre-term level of communicative competence in English, including: linguistic competence, sociolinguistic competence, discourse competence, functional competence, and strategic competence.
? Identify your own critical academic and personal language learning needs.
? Articulate your learning goals for the quarter (in partnership with your tutor). Your goals should address your unique learning needs in effective communication
? Demonstrate progress towards achieving your stated learning goals.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Individual face-to-face instruction, in-session practice activities, suggested homework practice activities.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: At the beginning of the quarter, students will complete an intake assessment with their tutor, and then create individual learning goals for the quarter. Students will be evaluated at the end of the quarter with a self-assessment, recorded speech samples, and documentation of progress towards individual goals by the tutor.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Students must complete an online form from English Language Programs in order to be eligible for the class and obtain a permission number. Contact elp@northwestern.edu for specific registration instructions.

name: Supported Online Speech Training for Nonnative Speakers of English

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, a trained instructor provides individualized language study for the purpose of increasing nonnative speakers' ability to communicate effectively in English, in both academic and everyday contexts. At the beginning of the term, students will complete an intake assessment, so that the instructor can determine current strengths and weaknesses. Students will also complete a needs assessment to determine which aspects of spoken English are most critical for the student's daily life and should be focused on most during the quarter. These could include work on accent and intelligibility, correcting syntactic errors, sociolinguistic skills, intercultural competence, classroom communication skills, formal and informal writing tasks, and more. Together, the instructor and student will create a set of learning goals to work on over the course of the term. The instructor will then provide appropriate practice in each session to help the student acquire the language and skills needed to improve communicative competence. Instructors may assign additional work to be completed outside of the session if needed. Students will be expected to reflect on their own learning and progress both periodically and at the end of the term. Active participation and evidence of progress towards learning goals must be demonstrated in order to achieve a satisfactory grade in the course.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Instructor consent required.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of the quarter, you will be expected to:
? Use data from the system's assessment to identify your pre-term level of proficiency in the areas of English pronunciation, grammar, fluency, and word stress.
? Compare your attempts to intelligibly read English sentences with a recording of a native speaker of English producing the same sentence.
? Identify areas in which your production differs from that of a native speaker's.
? Modify your production to better match the native speaker's production.
? Assess whether your attempts to modify your production are successful or not.
? Demonstrate progress towards improved oral English proficiency in the areas in which you have been working over the course of the quarter.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Online exercises in pronunciation, fluency, word stress, and grammar, optional in-person support sessions.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grading is based on completion of an online assessment, meeting of weekly milestones towards usage of the software, and completion of an end of quarter assessment and written end-or-quarter reflection exercise. Students can earn up to 15 additional minutes of active time logged towards their weekly milestone by attending optional drop in help sessions.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Students will be given a software account for use during the quarter.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Students must complete an online form from English Language Programs in order to be eligible for the class and obtain a permission number. Contact elp@northwestern.edu for specific registration instructions.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The Linguistics Department-based face-to-face component will consist of a faculty-led seminar series.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Permission of the instructor is required.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No Textbook Assigned.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What are the similarities between the Rubik's cube, a popular puzzle toy, and square dancing, an offshoot of American folk dancing? Both involve scrambling things using a small number of operations. In one case, plastic pieces are rotated by turning faces of a cube. In the other case, people move from one place to another by executing dance actions. In both cases, it is important to be able to restore the objects to their original unscrambled state. How can we understand this process? In a scrambled state, what patterns persist? In this class, we use mathematical permutation groups to tie together Rubik's cubes and square dancing. Mathematical thinking will allow us to devise and critique both unscrambling strategies and also the ways in which the strategies can be effectively communicated. Prior knowledge is not expected.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Handbook of Cubik Math
Authors: Alexander F. Frey Jr.,? David Singmaster
ISBN-13: 978-0718892098

Students will also need a Rubik's cube. Available in the bookstore or buy one online:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00R1NANC4
("D-FantiX YJ Guanlong Speed Cube 3x3 Smooth Magic Cube Puzzles 56 mm Black")

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Limits. Differentiation. Linear approximation and related rates. Extreme value theorem, mean value theorem, and curve-sketching. Optimization. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 220-1 and any of MATH 211-0 or MATH 218-1 or MATH 218-2.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
"Your calculus course requires access to MyLab Math (also called MyMathLab). MyLab Math is an online platform that serves as an electronic textbook, an enrichment resource, and a homework portal. MyLab Math includes access to an electronic copy of the textbook; you do not need to purchase a paper copy of the book.

You can acquire the course materials in several ways:

MyLab Math Only - Direct
Purchase MyLab Math access directly from the publisher (Pearson) after setting up your account using instructions provided on the course Canvas site. This should cost $80 (+ tax).
MyLab Math Only - Bookstore
Purchase MyLab Math access from the Northwestern Bookstore, and then set up your account using instructions provided on the course Canvas site. This should cost $106.65 (+ tax).
MyLab Math and Looseleaf Book Bundle
Purchase access to MyLab Math bundled with a looseleaf copy of the textbook from the Northwestern Bookstore, and then set up your account using instructions provided on the course Canvas site. This should cost $146.65 (+ tax).
MyLab Math Only and Used Book
Purchase access to MyLab Math using one of the first two options above (setting up your account using instructions provided on the course Canvas site), and acquire a used copy of the book separately.

IMPORTANT: MyLab Math access codes from any source other than Pearson (following the instructions provided on the course Canvas Site) or the Northwestern Bookstore will not work.

The access you purchase for your course this fall can be used across multiple quarters of calculus courses at Northwestern that use the same textbook (MATH 220-1, 220-2, 226-0, 228-1, 228-2, 230-1, 230-2)."

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Topics in Algebra, FQ19:

D-modules in algebra and geometry (various operations, holonomicity, V-filtration, Bernstein-Sato polynomial, resolutions, etc.), followed by a study of connections with Hodge theory, especially the study of the Hodge filtration on D-modules of Hodge theoretic origin. In particular we will be touching on some of the aspects of the theory of mixed Hodge modules and the relationship between all of the above and notions in birational geometry (singularities of pairs, multiplier ideals, vanishing theorems), and some of the recent theory of Hodge ideals.

In terms of background, the course will gradually require more and more knowledge (again, over at least two quarters): first all sorts of algebra and a bit of manifolds, then a decent grasp of algebraic geometry, then basic Hodge theory, and finally a little birational geometry. There will be a webpage containing references, and eventually some notes.

name: First-Year Seminar
topic: We Are What We Eat: Turkish Food Culture & Cuisine

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Food can be a very relatable and intimate way to study the unfamiliar. In this course we will explore the complex relationships between food, culture, and society through the lens of Turkish food from the Middle Ages to the present. Food represents an integral part of livelihood, culture, and identity. Food production, consumption and sharing also have symbolic and ideological meanings. By delving into the culinary traditions, cultural practices, ingredients, recipes, and tools that are essential to Turkish cooking, we will take a close look at the historical and cultural phenomena that make up this diverse culture, and explore global issues such as identity, immigration, international relations, and religion within the context of the modern Middle East. In the classroom we will occasionally try foods from Turkey and the course will conclude with a cooking demo on campus to experience Turkish cuisine first-hand.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Freshman seminars at Northwestern are designed to achieve two primary objectives: to help you further develop your critical thinking and writing skills while, at the same time, focus on a subject and explore all the different ways that subject can be studied and understood. In our case, the subject is "Turkish food culture."
By the end of this course you will:
- Have a broad understanding of Turkish food culture and cuisine, and its historical, political, and geographical origins
- Read and analyze academic scholarship more skillfully and critically
- Articulate and defend your points of view verbally and in writing
- Understand what constitutes research and learn how to conduct research
- Know how to use the resources for research available through NU's library
- Write clearly, concisely and persuasively in a variety of formats (e.g. personal essay, critical analysis/response paper, academic research paper)

name: Introductory Topics in Middle East and North African Studies
topic: Contemporary Theatre Between the Middle East and E

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course looks at the work of contemporary artists whose practice emerges from the transregional space between the Middle East and Europe. Many contemporary artists work between these two "regions," producing work that posits a joint analytic field and elucidates the politics of culture in multiple sites. In this course we attempt to think with artists, the particular ideas animated by their work, and the institutions that support them. Our focus is on performance-based media, including (but not limited to): theatre, performance art, lectures, and film/video art. With each work and each artist, we consider their particular uses of performance, and attempt to expand upon the artist's project through an extended engagement with their ideas and aesthetics. Possible artists include: Rabih Mroue, Omar Ghayatt, and Jumana Manna.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Collaborate in the creation of knowledge in class.
2. Cultivate skills in performance analysis through in-class exercises and short writing assignments.
3. Critique existing scholarly writing, being able to identify, summarize, and contest the argument(s), and evaluate the evidence therein.
4. Develop a structured essay plan, and sustained argument over an extended period.
5. Think about theatre and performance in relation to their material circumstances, and in consideration of the writer's stance as spectator.

name: Seminar in Middle East and North African Studies
topic: Ottoman Jews in the Age of Nationalism

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The Ottoman Empire was home to a large number of Jewish communities that were scattered over a vast area from the Balkans to the Arab lands. They spoke a diverse range of languages: Greek, Ladino, Yiddish, Arabic, Kurdish, and Turkish, but after the 1590s the influx of refugees from Spain and Portugal made the Sephardic Jewish community the largest one in the empire. Even though they were nominally under the authority of the Grand Rabbinate in the imperial center just like the other major confessional groups of the empire, like the Greek Orthodox, and the Armenians, the functioning of Jewish communities did not conform to a uniform pattern and was far more heterogeneous in practice. During the nineteenth century, as the Ottoman Empire was shaken up by the influence of nationalist movements on the one hand, and the conflicting agendas of the Great Powers on the other, its Jewish communities also had to devise strategies to deal with these forces and engage with the question of modernization. After the demise of the Ottoman Empire they found themselves separated by the boundaries of different nation-states. This seminar will analyze the impact of competing forms of nationalism on the Ottoman Sephardim who eventually became "minorities" in these successor states. We will read and discuss scholarly works in the field and also work with primary source material.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: SeminarDiscussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: short essay; final paper; participation to class discussion

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: A course packet will be available from Quartet Digital Printing in Evanston. Sample readings include: Mark Mazower, Salonica, City of Ghosts; Devin Naar, Jewish Salonica: Between the Ottoman Empire and Modern Greece; Julia Philips Cohen, Sephardi Lives: A Documentary History, 1700-1950; Aron Rodrigue, French Jews, Turkish Jews; Marc Baer, The Dönme: Jewish Converts, Muslim Revolutionaries, and Secular Turks; Julia Philips Cohen, Becoming Ottomans: Sephardi Jews and Imperial Citizenship in the Modern Era; and Eli Shaul, From Balat to Bat Yam: Memoirs of Turkish Jews.

name: Advanced Topics in Middle East & North African Studies

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar examines shifts and transformations in embodied cultural practices across the Middle East and North Africa, with particular attention to music, dance, theater, and popular culture. Spanning the late nineteenth century to the Arab Spring, students will better understand a cultural history of the region, its role in shaping global modernity, and the politics of gender, sexuality, and ethnoreligious difference. In addition to class discussion and written assignments, students will be asked to develop a creative project to be designed in consultation with the instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goals of this course are to assist students (1) to acquire knowledge about cultural production in the contemporary Middle East and North Africa; (2) to engage in the critical analysis and interpretation of performance as method of research, object of study, and theoretical field of interest; and (3) to develop an ability to express new knowledge and perspectives in writing, oral presentation, and creative work.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, discussion, and participatory activities.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
1. Assignments: 75% of final grade

a. Response papers (25%)
b. In-class presentation (10%)
c. Field project (10%)
d. Final project (30%)

2. Attendance and participation: 25% of final grade

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
A course packet will be made available for purchase. It will include selections from:

Virginia Danielson, The Voice of Egypt: Umm Kulthum, Arabic Song, and Egyptian Society in the Twentieth Century; Nahid Siamdoust, Soundtrack of the Revolution: The Politics of Music in Iran; Denise Gill, Melancholic Modalities: Affect, Islam, and Turkish Classical Musicians; Nicolas Rowe, Raising Dust: A Cultural History of Dance in Palestine; Heather D. Ward, Egyptian Belly Dance in Transition: The Raqs Sharqi Revolution, 1890-1930; Dina A. Amin, Alfred Farag and Egyptian Theater: The Poetics of Disguise, with four short plays and a monologue; Talinn Grigor, Contemporary Iranian Art: From the Street to the Studio.

name: Pro-Seminar in Middle East and North African Studies
topic: Locating MENA: Space, Power and Mobility

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What is the Middle East and North Africa?or with its abbreviation MENA? What does the Middle East mean to those who live in it and to those who study it? Is the Middle East a disciplinary formation along the trajectory of US area studies alone, or a historically sedimented and contemporaneously lived reality of transimperial, transnational and global connectivity? Could tracking the traffic in people, goods, ideas across territories, help us render tangible those particular connections and disconnections? In this course we seek answers to these, and other, questions through reading anthropological and historical monographs as well as theoretical essays drawn from allied disciplines and social theory more broadly. In probing these questions, our aim is to explore in tandem the disciplinary formation and the socio-political production of the Middle East as a region.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course students will be well-versed in theories of mobility and territory, and able to articulate what an attention to space and the relations of power inscribed in particular processes of territorial production and disciplinary formation can contribute to interdisciplinary inquiry across the MENA region.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: SeminarDiscussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated on the basis of two 7-10 page papers (50%), and class participation (50%)?which includes the submission of 7 reading responses (%25), and co-leading discussion in one class session (%15). Attendance and active participation (%10) are mandatory: undocumented and unexcused absences will affect your grade, as will non-participation in discussion.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The MENA Colloquium is designed to encourage dialogue between students across disciplines who share interests in Middle East and North African Studies, to offer a space to develop extended papers and research reports, and to foster discussion between Northwestern MENA students and faculty. Students begin by enrolling in MENA 412-1 followed by MENA 412-2 as zero credit courses. Upon successful completion of MENA 412-1 and 2 students may enroll in MENA 412-3, completion of which earns one course credit. Students taking the three part MENA 412 sequence must present their work at a MENA colloquium at least one time per academic year, pre-circulate their paper to other members of the seminar, make one formal response, attend all MENA colloquia plus selected invited speakers, and actively participate in breakfasts/lunches with select speakers and faculty. In order to obtain a Certificate in MENA Studies, students must enroll in three quarters of MENA 412 (one course credit) and three quarters of MENA 415 (which meets at the same time as MENA 412, and is otherwise identical, but does not require a public presentation or comment and bears no credit). Attendance at the colloquium is open to the public, although pre-circulated papers are only accessible to students enrolled in the MENA 412 sequence.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Pre-req: MENA 412-1. Open to students in any graduate program at Northwestern whose work intersects with study of the Middle East and/or North Africa. Students affiliated with the MENA Cluster or pursuing a MENA Certificate are automatically eligible. Others may inquire of the MENA Program Director.

15 minute presentation based on the paper, ideally with visuals and/or handouts. One formal five-minute response to another student presentation. Active participation in the colloquium. Note: MENA 412-1, 2, 3 is normally completed in a single academic year, but can also be spread over two academic years, with consent of MENA director. Please note: this is a three quarter long sequence bearing one course credit.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To provide a forum for presenting, developing, and responding to research on the Middle East and North Africa from a variety of disciplinary perspectives; to enable conversations across disciplinary methodologies which both sharpens students' sense of their own discipline and develops ability to communicate across those disciplines; to foster dialogue among graduate students working on MENA studies and members of the faculty.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Presentations, faculty response, and group discussion.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students enrolled for credit are evaluated based on their public presentation, and their responses (both written and oral) to the papers and presentations of other students enrolled in MENA 412 for credit.

descriptions.value: The MENA Colloquium is designed to encourage dialogue between students across disciplines who share interests in Middle East and North African Studies, to offer a space to develop extended papers and research reports, and to foster discussion between Northwestern MENA students and faculty. Students begin by enrolling in MENA 412-1 followed by MENA 412-2 as zero credit courses. Upon successful completion of MENA 412-1 and 2 students may enroll in MENA 412-3, completion of which earns one course credit. Students taking the three part MENA 412 sequence must present their work at a MENA colloquium at least one time per academic year, pre-circulate their paper to other members of the seminar, make one formal response, attend all MENA colloquia plus selected invited speakers, and actively participate in breakfasts/lunches with select speakers and faculty. In order to obtain a Certificate in MENA Studies, students must enroll in three quarters of MENA 412 (one course credit) and three quarters of MENA 415 (which meets at the same time as MENA 412, and is otherwise identical, but does not require a public presentation or comment and bears no credit). Attendance at the colloquium is open to the public, although pre-circulated papers are only accessible to students enrolled in the MENA 412 sequence.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
15 minute presentation based on the paper, ideally with visuals and/or handouts. One formal five-minute response to another student presentation. Active participation in the colloquium. Note: MENA 412-1, 2, 3 is normally completed in a single academic year, but can also be spread over two academic years, with consent of MENA director. Please note: this is a three quarter long sequence bearing one course credit.

Pre-req: MENA 412-1. Open to students in any graduate program at Northwestern whose work intersects with study of the Middle East and/or North Africa. Students affiliated with the MENA Cluster or pursuing a MENA Certificate are automatically eligible. Others may inquire of the MENA Program Director.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: To provide a forum for presenting, developing, and responding to research on the Middle East and North Africa from a variety of disciplinary perspectives; to enable conversations across disciplinary methodologies which both sharpens students' sense of their own discipline and develops ability to communicate across those disciplines; to foster dialogue among graduate students working on MENA studies and members of the faculty.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Presentations, faculty response, and group discussion.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students enrolled for credit are evaluated based on their public presentation, and their responses (both written and oral) to the papers and presentations of other students enrolled in MENA 412 for credit.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: materials will be provided

name: First-Year Seminar
topic: This is Your Brain on College

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this seminar, we will examine recent research on learning and memory through the unique lens of college life. What do we know (or think we know) about how memories are encoded in the brain? How is college a different learning environment than high school? Together, we will review scientific studies on the impact of college life on student academic performance, and correlate those findings with studies of human and animal learning in the laboratory. After taking this course, you will have a foundational understanding of the neurobiological basis of memory, learn how to read scientific literature critically, and develop strategies to improve your study habits and performance here at Northwestern University.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
After taking this course, students will:
1. Be able to describe how the brain is "plastic" and changes with experience
2. Identify brain regions and functional networks associated with learning and memory
3. Read primary scientific literature for understanding, as well as start developing critical thinking skills.
4. Create an effective study plan that incorporates principles of neuroplasticity

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture, discussion, student-led presentations, writing for the sciences

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Attendance and participation = 20%
Journal Club presentation = 20%
Reflection papers (3) = 30%
Study plan draft = 10%
Final study plan =10%
Self-evaluation rubric = 10%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: There is no textbook required for this course. All reading materials will be provided through CANVAS, online resources, or campus libraries, free of charge.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
NEUROSCI 202-0 introduces students to the cellular and molecular processes that allow the nervous system to produce behavior, with a focus on how electrochemical signals are generated, communicated and integrated to transform different sensations into appropriate actions. We all want to know how the mind works in health and what happens when things go wrong in disease. However, first we need to start with the fundamentals, which this course will provide. Learning about neuroscience is like learning a new language, which will require the introduction of new words and the memorization of terminology. Students will be expected to increase their vocabulary so they can begin to appreciate and discuss neuroscience concepts and research in an informed manner. This is not a survey course, rather it is designed to provide a solid foundation for subsequent coursework that delves more deeply into various topics in neuroscience.
Prerequisite: BIOL_SCI 217-0



Course content is divided into three sections. The first third focuses on the ionic and molecular basis for generating electric signals in neurons. The second third focuses on electrical and chemical communication between neurons, how these connections are adjusted, and how they develop. The final third will focus on simple circuits that illustrate the cellular and molecular mechanisms that allow us to taste, smell, see, hear, feel and move at the right time. It is recommended that reading be performed prior to lectures to help students discover and remedy misconceptions before the midterm exams. Information in the textbook will provide context and introduction of material in lectures.

NEUROSCI 202 will be offered during Fall 2019 and Winter 2020.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: BIOL_SCI 217-0 and must be a neuroscience major.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will acquire a deep understanding of:
1) Fundamental neurobiological principles arising from studies of the nervous system at the cellular and molecular level.
2) History and recent developments in neuroscience research.
3) Methods used to study the nervous system, including specific experimental techniques relevant to cellular and molecular neuroscience, the design, analysis and interpretation of experiments using specific techniques, and the strengths and limitations of those techniques.
4) Ethical issues raised by the growing body of information generated by neuroscience research, including the use of animals.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The format of the course will be that of a semi-flipped classroom. Instead of hearing information for the first time in lecture, students will read and assimilate the basic material from the textbook prior to class. Lectures will assume a working knowledge of the general concepts covered in the assigned chapters, and then expand upon them, principally by focusing on the techniques and recent advances in the field. Class time will also be used to solve problems and to answer questions. The idea is that the lectures will not only provide new information, but also allow students to discover and remedy misconceptions prior to the exams.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
The final grade is not curved and will be broken down as follows:
Reading Quizzes 20%
Midterm 1 20%
Midterm 2 30%
Final exam 30%

Reading quizzes will be assessed on Canvas. Exams will be short answer, and are not strictly cumulative since they will focus on specific lectures. However, the questions in later exams will by necessity assume an accumulation of basic facts and concepts raised earlier on.


NEUROSCI 202-0 WILL BE OFFERED DURING FALL 2019 AND WINTER 2020.

descriptions.value: Neuroscience: Exploring the Brain (4th Ed.), ISBN: 9780781778176, List Price: $129.99.

Class Notes
WCAS Distro Area I - Natural Sciences

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Nervous system function requires the generation of a vast number of neuron types and the elaboration of complex interconnections among them. This course will cover the embryological organization and cellular/molecular mechanisms underlying neuronal development. This includes neuroembryology, generation and differentiation of neurons and glia, axon guidance, experience-dependent development and plasticity, human brain development, and sex differences in development and behavior. Diseases resulting from failures of these processes will be discussed. This course will also introduce research methods and technology, and encourage students to develop skills to appreciate historical context and logical rationale of contemporary research.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prerequisites: BIOL_SCI 215-0 and one of the following: NEUROSCI 202-0, NEUROSCI 306-0, NEUROSCI 311-0 or BIOL_SCI 302-0, or BIOL_SCI 311-0.

Enrollment Requirements: At this time, registration is reserved for neuroscience majors only!

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The course is taught with the combination of lectures, laboratory observations/exercises and a writing assignment.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students are required to read relevant chapters in the textbook and assigned papers of contemporary research. Evaluation will be via a midterm, lab exercises, a final exam, and a research paper that is based on evaluation of the primary scientific literature. The final grade will be determined by performance from midterm (25%), research paper (25%), lab exercises (10%) and final exam (40%).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Foundations of Neural Development, 1st Edition (S. Marc Breedlove) ISBN-13: 978-1605355795 cost from $91.16 on Amazon

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce students to the field of animal behavior from the neuroscience perspective. We will focus on biological activities essential for survival, including foraging, communication, migration, predator-prey interactions, mating, and parental care. Neural circuits and the signaling mechanisms underlying these behaviors will be discussed in-depth.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1). Develop an understanding of the diversity of vertebrate behavior and its neurobiological underpinnings.
2). Become adept at reading and critically evaluating primary literature and reviews.
3). Develop an ability to generalize neurobiological principles and mechanisms across systems.
4). Develop novel hypotheses on topics in the area of neurobiology of animal behavior and learn to align them with experimental approaches that can be used to test the proposed ideas.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Hybrid of lecture and in-class discussion. Meets twice a week (2 x 80 minutes).

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: One 7 page long research paper (25%), midterm (25%) and final (35%) exams, class presentations (10%) and participation (5%).

name: Neurobiology of Biological Clocks and Sleep

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will examine the general properties of sleep and circadian rhythms and will analyze how sleep and the circadian clock regulate a number of diverse activities at the level of the cell, the organ, as well as the organism. Special emphasis will be placed on the neural and genetic basis for the generation of sleep and circadian rhythms. The importance of sleep and biological rhythms for human health and disease will be covered in this course mainly through a series of student presentations. Much of this course will involve the analysis and discussion of classic, as well as recent experiments, that have been carried out on the study of biological clocks and sleep.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: NEUROSCI 202-0.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures and discussion of classic and current research being carried out in the field in addition to short student presentations.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

Combination of Class Presentations and Term Paper - 30%
Final Exam - 40%

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: Students must have completed NEUROSCI 202-0 or obtain permission of the instructor to register for this course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: As for any other organ, disease and disordered function of the brain can have effects ranging from subtle to devastating. In this course, students will learn about common human brain disorders, their cellular and molecular causes, and treatments. We will cover a variety of neurodegenerative diseases, ADHD, depression, mental illness, mental retardation, and other disorders. Students will synthesize this information to identify common mechanisms underlying brain diseases. We will discuss how the causes of brain disease were discovered and what we don't yet know. Ethical questions in neural medicine will be addressed. Class format will consist of lectures twice a week plus a third weekly session consisting of student presentation and discussion of primary research articles to develop the skills to read and critique current research in the field.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: NEUROSCI 202-0 and NEUROSCI 206-0: NEUROSCI 311-0 and NEUROSCI 206-0; or BIOL_SCI 302-0. Recommend review of basic genetics and molecular biology.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
A. Define the biological basis of a variety of brain disorders
B. Synthesize material to identify common features, mechanisms, and modulators of diverse brain diseases
C. Link basic research, translational science, and clinical trials and understand the limits of current treatments
D. Critically evaluate the evidence for and against competing hypotheses regarding brain disorders
E. Read, present, and interpret current primary literature relating to a variety of brain disorders
F. Develop an understanding of major ethical issues pertaining to brain disorders and their treatment

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The first two lectures of each week will address topics from the textbook while in the third session, one student group per week will present current primary literature expanding on the week's topics.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: 1 class presentation per student group, participation grade for discussion, 8 weekly microquizzes, 1 midterm, and 1 final.

descriptions.value: Materials will be freely available online.

WCAS Distro Area I - Natural Sciences

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course focuses on the overall organization of the nervous system, relating structure to function with an emphasis on dissection and vertebrate anatomy. Anatomy will be approached from a regional perspective to describe the parts of the nervous system and their connections. Anatomy will also be approached from a functional perspective to describe motor, sensory, and cognitive circuits. Development and evolution will be discussed to provide overall context for how the mature vertebrate nervous system is organized. Clinical significance, injury, and disease will also be discussed. All classes will meet in the Neuroscience Teaching Laboratory (Hogan Hall, Rm 2-112) so that instruction can flexibly shift between lecture and dissection. It may be used as a Neuroscience Group B elective or as an Allied Field in Biology.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: Must have completed NEUROSCI 202-0 and NEUROSCI 206-0.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students completing this course will:
1. Develop anatomical vocabulary
2. Relate the structure of the central and peripheral nervous systems to their function
3. Understand the anatomical basis of common neurological injuries and diseases
