descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Persian 121 is a three-quarter sequence designed to help students develop intermediate competence in oral and written comprehension and expression of the Persian language. Emphasis is on improving listening comprehension, reading, speaking, writing, and cultural and historical knowledge. The course builds on knowledge of the grammatical structures taught in the first three quarters of Persian 111 by introducing more advanced grammar and vocabulary in context. The course also integrates authentic material from available online sources for improving listening comprehension and cultural understanding. The course will continue with the textbook Persian in Use but also integrate articles from Iranian newspapers and magazines to learn about Iran and its socio-political situation.

In the first quarter of second-year Persian, students will learn to talk about events in the past including their own life. Describing the weather, general information of a city (including population, streets, hobbies, professions) will be covered during this quarter as well.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Persian 111-3 or equivalent; or permission of the instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Upon completion of this 3-quarter course sequence, it is expected that students will be able to:
? converse easily in situations referring to daily life and in common social situations;
? write a paragraph length text to state basic needs or explain a problem;
? use basic composition skills to be able to comment on a reading text;
? comprehend short paragraphs from magazines or audio/video material dealing with Iranian celebrities, customs, famous places and cultural and historical facts.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Following the communicative approach, grammatical structures and vocabulary are practiced throughout the course in context. This is an interactive course, and students are expected to come to class prepared to be able to participate in class actively and in a lively and informed fashion.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class attendance, homework assignments, quizzes, midterm and final, journal entries.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
? Persian in Use: An Elementary Textbook of Language and Culture, Anousha Sedighi, Leiden University Press, 2015. (ISBN: 9789087282172) (required)
? Farsi Biamuzim, Volume 2, 3, Hasan Zulfaqari, Mahbud Ghaffari, and Mahmud Bakhtiari, 1381 (not required)

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This class is taught in Persian. It meets three days a week; a minimum of one-hour review is required outside of class for each class session.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Democracy works when people are able to make conscientious, informed decisions about the kind of society they want to live in. Thinkers from antiquity to the present have been concerned with the various ways that this ability can be undermined by propaganda, both in purported democracies and in explicitly authoritarian regimes. On the other hand, many radical thinkers have suggested that propaganda isn't always bad, and is perhaps a necessary component of liberatory social and political movements. In this course we will be asking three central questions: What is propaganda? How does propaganda function in the world today? And finally, how can a just society deal with propaganda's negative effects?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of this course, students will have developed their ability to critically read and respond to a text or argument.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Your grade will be based on the following: - Paper 1, 30%: 4-5 pages. This paper will be graded in 2 stages; first you will hand in a draft and receive feedback, and then, after integrating this feedback, you will hand in a final copy. The grade will be based on the overall quality of the final paper as well as the progress made over the course of the revision process. - Paper 2, 35%: 5-6 pages. Handing in a draft is not mandatory, but is encouraged. - In class participation, 15% - Reading responses, 20%: Before each meeting you will upload to Canvas a 200-250 word response to a given question about the reading for the next class meeting. These will be graded on a coarse-grained scale, receiving either a 0, a 1 or a 2.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All course materials will be made available on Canvas.

name: First-Year Seminar in Philosophy
topic: Is Goodness out of this World?

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: "Goodness" is a concept we cannot seem to escape. This seminar will address several questions about the nature of goodness. For example, is goodness reducible to something seemingly unrelated to goodness? Do we encounter goodness in experience like we encounter solidity in experience? Can we be judged as good or not, even if we cannot fully understand goodness? And what of its source: is it something natural, or supernatural, or something else entirely? The seminar will examine how these questions are addressed in several traditions, with a focus on the work of the novelist and philosopher Iris Murdoch.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Clear articulation of arguments in writing. Clear thinking. Progress on the road to moral perfection.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Writing assignments of various lengths.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Fear and Trembling. Cambridge Texts in the History of Philosophy, Edited by C. Stephen Evans and Sylvia Walsh (Cambridge University Press, 2002) ISBN: 978-0521612692

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this seminar we will examine some of the fundamental ideas and questions behind democracy and provide a reading of their "inventors". Some of the questions are: What is democracy? Is it a form of government, a value, an ideal, a political system, a form of life, a bit of all this? Is democracy always the best political solution (in wartime? general starvation?)? Why should the whole of the people decide and not the specialists in the respective questions? Are all democratically taken decisions automatically legitimate (what about minorities' rights?)? How should all citizens in a democracy participate in politics? By direct self-government of the people or by voting representatives? Is everything democratically decidable or does the individual have unalterable rights? Is tolerance and/or free speech necessary for democracy and how far can it go?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: As a WRITING seminar, this course will teach every student the stepwise development of the general skills needed to write an academic research paper: formulating a claim with clarity, arguing in support of it by using evidence, logical analysis, and commonsense knowledge. It will familiarize the students with critically interpreting sources, anticipating and discussing objections, organizing and formulating the resulting position compellingly. At the conclusion of the course, the student should be able to know what it takes to write a successful research assignment not only in philosophy, but quite generally in academic contexts. As a PHILOSOPHY course, the students will learn the core ideals of major classics of democratic theory from Aristotle to Habermas in a historically guided systematic development of the normative ideal "democratic state". In this process, they will also learn to apply these (=our) ideals reflectively and critically on contemporary challenges to democratic practice like elite domination, racism and populism. Reading and interpreting the sources will enable them to interpret social scientific and philosophical texts and ideas with fluency. At the conclusion of the course students will be able to write a competent research paper that critically and reflectively analyzes core assumptions of present-day democratic practice.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: PARTICIPATION: ? 2 informal 10-minute presentations, ? 4 300-word reaction papers, ? steady and dedicated in-class discussion ? 1 draft of final paper & discussion thereof WRITTEN ASSIGNMENTS: ? 2 1200-word short papers ? 1 3000-word final research paper. PROPORTION (rule of thumb): Participation: ~33% (of which: reaction paper total ~15%, presentations ~25%, draft ~20%, class-discussion ~40%) + Short Papers (total) ~28% + Final Paper ~39%.

Locke, John: Second Treatise of Government, Indianapolis: Hackett, 1980. ? de Montesquieu, Charles-Louis: The Spirit of Law, Cambridge, New York: Cambridge University Press, 1989. ? Madison, James: The Federalist Papers, ed. by Isaac Kramnick, Harmondsworth: Penguin 1987. ? de Tocqueville, Alexis: Democracy In America, quoted from Cahn, Steven M. (ed.) Classics of Modern Political Theory, Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997, 722-752. ? Rousseau, Jean-Jacques: The Social Contract, Indianapolis: Hackett, 1987. ? Kant, Immanuel: Metaphysics of Morals, Cambridge, New York: Cambridge University Press, 1991, Perpetual Peace, Indianapolis: Hackett, 1982. ? Mill, John Stuart: On Liberty, Indianapolis: Hackett, 1978. ? Habermas, Juergen: "On the pragmatic, the ethical and the moral employments of practical reason," in Justification and application, Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, 1993. ? The Declaration of Independence, The Constitution of the United States of America, quoted from The Federalist Papers, ed. by Isaac Kramnick, Harmondsworth: Penguin 1987. ADDITIONAL SOURCES ON CANVAS.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: There are many different and incommensurable kinds of goods: consumer goods (like cars and computers and clothes), personal relationships (love and friendship), goods of status, bodily goods (health, freedom from pain), opportunities for meaningful work, leisure, and so on. We will explore the moral and political implications of the idea that the way in which a specific good should be allocated, promoted and engaged with depends on the type of good it is. In particular, we'll be interested in the contrast between marketable goods - commodities - and other sorts of goods. If there are things that should not be for sale, why is that, and what does it say about the nature of value?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will
?Learn to identify and reconstruct the main arguments and assumptions of the authors we read in class
?Be able to write an essay that articulates a clear thesis and presents a thoughtful argument in support of that thesis
?Understand how economic markets may affect the way in which things are valued
?Understand the moral problems that can arise when certain types of goods are bought and sold

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on student performance on papers, as well as in-class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Michael Sandel, "What Money Can't Buy" (New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux) ISBN:9780374533656

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, we will explore a broad range of philosophical questions, both traditional and contemporary. We will pay particular attention to how these issues relate to our moral, social, and political values. Questions to be discussed include: What is the connection between belief in God and reason? Are there moral absolutes, or is morality relative? What should our view be on abortion, the death penalty, torture, and the status of nonhuman animals?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The abilities to think, read, and write critically and to develop and defend arguments will be emphasized.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureDiscussion section

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two paper outlines, worth 10% of the final grade One 5-6 page, double-spaced paper, worth 25% of the final grade One 6-7 page, double-spaced paper, worth 35% of the final grade Reading reports and class participation, worth 30% of the final grade

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings available on Canvas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Subtle mistakes in reasoning can get us into trouble, especially in philosophy where reasoning can be very intricate. Logic symbolizes arguments to make subtle mistakes easier to spot, and intricate arguments easier to follow. In this class we will first learn how to use symbols to represent certain natural language sentences. The symbolization allows us to give step-by-step reconstructions of arguments. When these step-by-step symbolized arguments have a certain profile, they represent good arguments. When they don't have that profile, the corresponding arguments can go wrong-and we can devise examples of when they go wrong! Throughout we'll address some concepts (such as truth and existence) that are deployed in philosophy, and how logical techniques can help us sort the good uses from the bad.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Learn to use logical tools to assess arguments.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce you to some of the greatest thinkers and movements in the philosophy of the ancient Greek world. We will focus on these thinkers' conceptions of the human soul, the capacity for knowledge, the good life, and law and morality. We will first discuss the views of the key figures in Classical philosophy: Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle. We will examine their answers to enduring questions such as: What are the fundamental constituents of reality? What is knowledge, and how do we come to have it? How can we be happy, and what is a good life? What makes for a just society? We will then move on to the Hellenistic period, and will examine Epicurean and Stoic conceptions of how we should live our lives, and why philosophy can help us flourish. Our emphasis will be on analyzing both these philosophers' views, and their reasons and arguments for holding these positions.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This class focuses on developing skills that are central to humanities classes. These include: skills in reading a text closely and critically, skills in writing clearly and in constructing a well-defended argument, and skills in productive group discussion. Since this class is designed to be a course in the history of philosophy, there will be both historical and philosophical objectives. Historical objectives: Ancient texts are often hard to read and interpret. The style, organization, and context of production of these texts are quite different from contemporary readings. Our goals as historians will be to read these texts closely and interpret them charitably, taking into account the historical context in which they were produced, and to understand what these authors are saying, why they are saying these things, and who their interlocutors are. Philosophical objectives: The philosophers we will read make sophisticated distinctions, analyze concepts, offer arguments and counter-arguments, present evidence, and attempt to refute their opponents' views. Our goals as philosophers will be to discover the main problems and questions that occupied philosophers in this ?period in the domains of physics, metaphysics, and ethics. We will learn to identify, analyze, map, and reconstruct the arguments and views advanced in these texts, with a view to understanding these author's positions, and their motivations for proposing them. Finally, we will learn to assess these proposals and arguments, and evaluate whether they are plausible and coherent. By the end of this course, you will have developed and refined the following general skills: (i) how to read difficult philosophical material; (ii) how to identify and reconstruct arguments; and (iii) how to produce and clearly articulate your own arguments, both in writing ?and orally in class.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureDiscussion section

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Writing and Assessment: You will write three 2-page essays and two 4-page essays. The first of the three 2-page essays will receive comments, but no actual grade. (However, we will tell you what the grade would have been.) The second 2-page essay will be a substantial re-write of the first essay. The idea is to give you an honest assessment, and advice on how to improve your paper without penalizing you. The short essays are designed to help you focus your reading of the texts. The longer essays are designed to help you develop your critical skills in evaluating positions and arguments. There will also be a final exam on the date and time scheduled by the Registrar. Grades will be calculated as follows: 2-page Essays (15% each) 4-page Essays (20% each) Final Exam (20%) Section Attendance and Participation (10%) **Note, again, that you will not be graded on the first essay.**

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Classics of Pragmatist Thought

Pragmatism is probably the first, but certainly the most important genuinely North American philosophical tradition. The classical writings of Peirce, James, Dewey set the stage for a completely new orientation in epistemology, moral and political theory, psychology and many other fields. Basic to all Pragmatist writers is the belief that the active and interactive human being in its natural and social environment has to stand at the center of reflection. They thus emphasize volitional, procedural, social, and evolutionary aspects of knowledge of any kind. Given this focus on practically involved intelligent agents, political pragmatists like Dewey, Addams, Locke explore the natural origins, revisability and legitimacy of moral and political norms. They develop the idea of a critical use of knowledge and its connection to non-violent democratic conduct. Neopragmatists (Rorty and Putnam) explore the philosophical and political implications of critical thinking.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: 1) Students will become competent in the basic texts in the pragmatist philosophical literature from Peirce to Putnam. 2) Students will acquire an enhanced sensitivity for method, logical analysis of theoretical and practical complexes and their connection, as well as an increased expertise in the close written and oral analysis of complex thoughts and textual sources. 3) One of the central aims will be, following the central topic of pragmatist thought, to offer students a complete reflective awareness of the structure of problem-solving behavior in cognitive, scientific, ethical and cultural affairs, and to train them in applying this competency to cases. 4) Students will acquire an awareness of the close connections between 'theoretical' positions and political conditions.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: One short paper (Midterm, ca. 1600 words), ca. 35% of final grade. One final paper (~3500 words), ca. 45% of final grade. Participation in Discussion and Lecture 20%.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
H S Thayer (ed) Pragmatism: The Classic Writings ISBN 9780915145379
And a course reader with writings of Peirce, Dewey, Alain Locke, Jane Addams, Rorty, Putnam.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will explore how philosophy can help us un- derstand our place in the cosmos. The course covers a variety of topics at the intersection of science and philos- ophy. How does the world we observe emerge from the microscopic world science tells us about? What are the laws of nature? What is time? What is life? The course's emphasis is not on leading students to particular conclu- sions about these topics. Instead, it is to learn how to ask these questions critically and to understand what would count as evidence that is relevant to their answer.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students in the course will: (a) Acquire knowledge of the key philosophical questions within cosmology. (b) Become familiar with the methodologies of philosophy in general. (c) Acquire the ability to analyze philosophical arguments critically, rigorously and independently. (d) Work on their ability to respond critically to philosophical readings. (e) Acquire the ability to produce abstract presentation of philosophical problems and think of possible solutions to them in terms of the abstract representation.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureDiscussion section

descriptions.value: Papers, study questions

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce students to some perennial questions in the philosophy of morality. We will be concerned with questions about (1) the nature of morality: For instance, are there universal, objective truths about right and wrong? Or is morality ultimately a subjective or relative matter? (2) The substance of morality: Are there certain actions that are absolutely forbidden, no matter what the consequences? When evaluating a person's action, in what way do his or her motives matter? And (3) the importance of morality: Should we really care whether or not we do the right thing?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: None

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will (1) Gain an understanding of important issues and theories in moral philosophy. (2) Learn to interpret and philosophical texts and arguments. (3) Critically evaluate their own moral convictions. (4) Learn to construct arguments and clearly explain philosophical ideas in writing.

descriptions.value: This course is an analysis of ethical and political issues that arise in medicine, with particular attention to questions posed by developments in biotechnology. Topics to be considered include human research, abortion, euthanasia, genetic engineering, and the allocation of medical resources.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: At the conclusion of this course, students will understand the core principles and methods of contemporary bioethics, and their application in clinical and research contexts. They will also have proficiency in reconstructing and evaluating moral and political arguments.

name: The Brady Scholars Program: The Good Life

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first in a sequence of three courses required of sophomores in the Brady Scholars Program in Ethics and Civic Life. Our topic, the good life, will be explored by reading and discussing several recent books, as well as authors of antiquity (Plato, Epictetus, Marcus Aurelius). We will ask: Are there objective truths about what is valuable - or about anything? Does life have a point or meaning? What should one try to get out of life? How should we think about death? Is each person the final judge of what is good for that individual, or is it possible to be mistaken about where one's good lies? What is the relationship between living well and being moral? How important is pleasure? Since more good is better than less, should we aim at all times to promote "the greatest happiness of the greatest number"?

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements

name: Introduction to the Philosophy of Art

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to some of the main questions, concepts, and theorists in the philosophy of art. We will discuss the nature and value of aesthetic appreciation, of art objects, and of artistic activity, considering questions such as: Does the nature and value of art lie in its expression of emotion, its originality, or its meaning? Is artistic activity a special type of action, requiring particular natural gifts (genius), or is it similar to other forms of activity? What counts as a truthful or false artistic representation? does anything a museum curator chooses to exhibit count, automatically, as art?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will develop their critical thinking and writing skills. They will become familiar with some of the central positions and debates concerning art in the history of philosophy. They will gain theoretical tools for thinking about their own experience of beauty and the arts, and about the significance of these phenomena for human social, moral and political life

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Combined lecture and discussion, with additional discussion sections

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students' grades will be based primarily on written work, including short reading responses (10%), two papers (of 4-6 pp.) (50%), and a final exam (25%), but will also be based in part on class participation (15%).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class will consider the high points of Spinoza's metaphysics and epistemology as described in Books I & II of the Ethics. The class will contains lecture and discussion as we work through Spinoza's proofs and explanations one at a time. Among the issues to be discussed are: God, causality, free will, determinism, our place in nature, perception, knowledge, and the relation between mind and body. Connections will be drawn between Spinoza and Aristotle, Descartes, and Leibniz.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The student will be expected to know the general outline of Spinoza's thought on these issues, the problems he tried to solve, and the problems he created.

descriptions.value: Lecture and discussion

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will be an introduction to German Idealism with particular attention paid to the problem of whether metaphysics is possible as a science. To this end, we will read Kant's _Prolegomena to Any Future Metaphysics_, the introductions to Fichte's _Wissenschaftslehre_, and the "Preliminary Conception" of Hegel's _Encyclopedia of the Philosophical Sciences in Outline_.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The objective of this course is to understand the basic concepts and problems of German Idealism.

descriptions.value: LectureSeminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two papers will be assigned.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will explore the nature of the mind and its relation to the brain, focusing on issues of foundational significance for psychology and cognitive science. It will be organized around group of fundamental questions. First, is the mind like a computer program? If so, what kind? Is it organized like a symbolic computation system, or like a complex network of associations? What does this tell us about how the mind relates to the brain? Second, to what extent is the mind organized around separate `modules', as opposed to being one single general intelligence engine? Third, to what extent are our cognitive abilities innate, and to what extent are they acquired through learning? Readings will be drawn from classic and contemporary papers in philosophy, psychology, and neuroscience.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will develop an understanding of central issues in the philosophy of psychology, mastery of a range of philosophical tools and techniques, and the ability to apply these to specific problems in the philosophy of psychology and the foundations of cognitive science.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture and discussion

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Short papers, final exam, and class participation.

descriptions.value: Robert Cummins and Denise Dellarosa Cummins (eds.), Minds, Brains, and Computers: The Foundations of Cognitive Science, Blackwell Publishers, 2000. ISBN: 1-55786-877-8

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will trace the major preoccupations of of analytic philosophy from its beginnings in the late 19th century up until the present moment, with readings by central figures such as Frege, Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Strawson, Quine, Grice, Evans, Lewis and Kripke, as well as by prominent historians of the tradition. We will also consider some challenges to contemporary analytic philosophy's inherited sets of priorities and methodologies.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will acquire a familiarity with many of the major works of analytic philosophy.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Reading responses, a midterm, and a final paper.

All other materials will be made available on Canvas.

name: Topics in Social and Political Philosophy

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Critical Race and Gender Theory. This course explores the intersection of critical race theory and critical gender theory. We will examine the performative and embodied aspects of race, gender and sexuality, giving special attention to intersectionality, performativity theory, queer theory, and critical phenomenology of race, gender, and sexuality. Authors will include: Franz Fanon, Iris Marion Young, Judith Butler, Maria Lugones, Kimberlé Crenshaw, Sarah Ahmed, Mariana Ortega, and Gayle Salamon, among others.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will receive training in critical thinking about race, gender, and sexuality. Students will learn to apply the critical concepts and perspectives in critical race theory and critical gender theory to social and political issues.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: LectureSeminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Papers

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Most readings will be made available on Canvas. But there is a required monograph that we will read at the end: Gayle Salamon: The Life and Death of Latisha King; A Critical Phenomenology of Transphobia. New York University Press, 2018 ISBN 9781479892525

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course explores the moral thought of one of the most influential figures in philosophy. Immanuel Kant systematizes and defends several familiar moral ideas, such as the unconditional authority of moral requirements and the dignity of each individual. He argues that acting morally is both a requirement of reason and the condition for our freedom, so that morally wrong action is both irrational and a kind of bondage. His approach to moral theory persists in its power, and remains one of a handful of live options among moral philosophers working today. We will engage in a careful study of this system, focusing on the Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals, and also reading parts of the Critique of Practical Reason, the Metaphysics of Morals, and Religion within the Bounds of Mere Reason.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: REQUIREMENTS: At least one prior writing-based philosophy class.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will be expected to have an understanding of the basic concepts of Kant's moral theory and the relations among them, as well as knowledge of what makes a Kantian approach to moral theory distinctive.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The course will be organized around lectures, with plenty of time for questions and discussion.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: EVALUATION METHOD: 3 two-page papers, 1 seven-page and a final exam.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Do corporations have social responsibilities that extend beyond mere compliance with law? Or is business ethics a contradiction in terms? In this course, we will attempt to answer these questions. We will survey the major contemporary theories of business ethics, and we will apply these frameworks to issues such as climate change and worker's rights. Readings will be drawn from economics and organizational theory as well as philosophy.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will develop skills in understanding and synthesizing philosophical, organizational, and economic analyses of the social responsibilities of business. Students will gain proficiency in recognizing, analyzing, and constructing moral and political arguments.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: TBD

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Most readings for this course are available online through the library website. Some additional readings will be collected in a course reader.

name: The Brady Scholars Program: The Civically Engaged Life

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Brady Scholars in their senior year will meet frequently throughout the quarter to move ahead with the collaborative project they have chosen as their service to the Evanston community.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements

name: Proseminar (1St-Yr Philosophy Grad Students Only)
topic: Understanding and Reason in Kant's Theoretical

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this seminar on Kant's theoretical philosophy, we will focus on Kant's conceptions of the human capacities of thought - understanding, reason, and reflection - as well as his related conceptions of philosophical practice or method: critique and dialectic. We will investigate Kant's reasons for sharpening his distinctions among these three modes of thinking over the course of his philosophical development, and the implications of those distinctions for his criticism of the rationalist philosophy of his predecessors, and for his own developing views in epistemology and metaphysics. As this course is a proseminar, we will also work on developing aspects of graduate-level work, including oral presentation/q and a, engagement with secondary literature, and revision practices.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: First-Year Graduate Students Only

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will be familiar with central concepts of Kant's theoretical philosophy, as well as current trends in scholarly literature concerning them. Students will develop professional writing and speaking skills.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on class participation, oral presentations, and work towards a final seminar paper (due in the second quarter of the course).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Immanuel Kant, Theoretical Philosophy 1755-1770, Cambridge University Press 1992. ISBN 0-521-53170-5 Immanuel Kant, Critique of Pure Reason, Cambridge University Press 1998. ISBN 978-0-521-65729

Secondary literature readings by (e.g.) Theodor Adorno, G.W.F. Hegel, Béatrice Longuenesse, Melissa Merritt, Eric Watkins, and Marcus Willaschek will be made available electronically

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: We will read all of Plato's "Republic," always with attention to the contemporary relevance of this dialogue.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Familiarity with the philosophical issues raised in the works studied.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Short papers, a long paper, in class contributions.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Plato: Republic (Hackett) 978 0 872 20737 0
Jonny Thakkar: Plato as Critical Theorist (Harvard University Press) 978 0 674 97176 9
Other translations of the "Republic" are acceptable.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Seminar in Language and Mind: What is the relation between language and our wider cognitive faculties? This course will explore this question, focusing on a number of related issues. First, to what extent is our linguistic competence the result of a distinct cognitive faculty or module? If there is one, what is the nature of this faculty, and how does it relate to our wider cognitive abilities? How much of what we normally think of as 'language' might be part of such a faculty? Second, how much does our linguistic competence influence other aspects of cognition? Does the language we speak influence how we categorize objects or navigate the world? If it does, how extensive can such influence be and how can it happen? Readings will be drawn from a range of works by philosophers, linguists, and psychologists.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Department Consent

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Familiarity with current theories about the mind/language interface.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Papers

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: TBD

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar will work chapter by chapter through my book manuscript "The Modal Future". We will cover: the semantics and pragmatic of future discourse; the relationship between philosophy of language and metaphysics; the epistemology of future belief; the nature of prediction; cutting edge work on future cognition.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Graduate Students Only

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will have an understanding of all of the key debates surrounding future thought and talk. Students will also have a grasp of which problems in this area are open, and potentially inviting research topics.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Paper, final

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: N/A - my book manuscript will be provided

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course, we will examine Hegel's philosophy of history and Marx's theory of history (and if time permits, we will consider some other philosophical or sociological approaches to history).

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Graduate Students Only

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The goal is to understand the philosophical presuppositions involved in these two very influential 19th century approaches to the rationality of historical change.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Final paper and one short assignment.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Hegel, G. W. F.; Lectures on the Philosophy of World History Introduction (Cambridge Studies in the History and Theory of Politics) (Cambridge, 1981), 978-0521281454
Marx, Karl; The Marx-Engels Reader (Norton, 1978), 978-0-393-09040-6
Cohen, G. A.; Karl Marx's Theory of History: A Defense (Princeton, 2000), 0-691-07068-7

name: First-Year Seminar
topic: Breaking the laws of nature:  physics in speculati

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will explore the fundamental ideas of modern physics by way of counter example. From Newton to Einstein, the laws of physics are regularly broken in works of fantasy and science fiction, and by asking what physical laws are broken (and with what consequences) we can come to a clearer understanding of the real world around us. We will ask why both Jedi and blasters violate conservation of momentum, how the ansible's faster-than-light communication in Ender's Game could lead to awkward conversations with one's past (or future) self, and what the impact is of a magic system that enables a perpetual motion machine, among other questions. We will also see how much speculation is still possible without undue violence to the nature of the universe. No particular physics or math background is required.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: For first-year student with lively interest in the difference between modern physics and what they learned in high school physics and/or in a first college physics course.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Seven Brief Lessons on Physics, by Carlo Rovelli, ISBN: 978-0-399-18441-3

Previous Editions: Only 1 edition
Online/eBook available: Yes
Price Range: $10-$15
Other Purchases: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course sequence is similar to 135-1 but mathematically more advanced. Concurrent registration in the ISP mathematics course, MATH 281-1,2,3 or its equivalent is required. PHYSICS 125-1 covers Newtonian mechanics: motion in 2 and 3 dimensions, Newton's laws, work and kinetic energy, conservation laws for energy, momentum, and angular momentum, rotational dynamics, gravity, central forces, planetary motion. PHYSICS 125-2 covers classical electricity and magnetism: Coulomb's law, electric fields, complex charge distributions, electrostatic potential, capacitance, resistance, inductance, circuits, magnetic fields, magnetic induction, alternating circuits, Maxwell's equations. PHYSICS 125-3 covers development of modern physics starting from Maxwell's equations: wave equations, light, interference, diffraction, Bohr model of the hydrogen atom, photo-electric effect, Compton scattering, quantum mechanics, Schrodinger equation and applications, harmonic oscillator, atoms, molecules, special relativity.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Physics for Scientists and Engineers, 6th edition by Paul A. Tipler and Gene Mosca. ISBN: 978-1429201322 publisher- W. H. Freeman


Previous Editions: Yes, any edition is fine
Online/eBook available: Yes
Price Range: $29.82- $49.94
Other Purchases: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first quarter of a three-quarter, algebra-based physics course with lecture. Physics is the most basic of the sciences, dealing with the behavior and structure of matter. Lectures illustrate physical principles: mechanics, motion, momentum and energy, and fluids. Continues as PHYSICS 130-2, 3. Students taking this course must also enroll in a Physics Lab 136-1. Actual demonstrations of many physical principles will be shown in the lecture when ever possible. Weekly quizzes emphasize problem solving. The goal of the course is for the student to gain an understanding of the nature of the physical principles which govern the world around us and the universe beyond, through models which draw on our everyday experiences. Topics: 1. Motion in One Dimension 2. Vectors 3. Motion in a Plane 4. Particle Dynamics 5. Work and Energy 6. Conservation of Energy 7. Conservation of Linear Momentum 8. Collisions 9. Rotational Kinematics 10. Rotational Dynamics and Conservation of Angular Momentum 11. Oscillations 12. Fluids.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Basic knowledge of High School algebra and trigonometry.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lectures with demonstrations and discussion sections.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades for this course are based on two in-class midterms, a final exam, and quizzes

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first quarter of a three-quarter sequence in calculus-based classical physics, with an introduction to modern physics in the third quarter. It is intended for science and engineering majors and premedical students. This course offers an introduction to fundamental topics in classical mechanics, including kinematics, relative motion, Newton's Laws, work and energy, linear and angular momentum, rigid body rotation, and orbital motion.

Concurrent registration in the corresponding quarter of PHYSICS 136-1,2,3 (laboratory) is required. Prior physics is not necessary. PHYSICS 135-1,2,3 are sequential prerequisites.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Physics 140-1 is the first part of a three-course sequence in classical physics intended primarily for prospective physics majors and minors and other students with a special interest in physics. The course offers an introduction to fundamental topics in classical mechanics, including kinematics, relative motion, Newton's Laws, work and energy, linear and angular momentum, and rigid body rotation, with special attention paid to establishing strong connections between physical concepts and mathematical techniques. This course will be taught in an active learning style.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The course will consist of lectures as well as extensive collaborative problem solving. Thursday enrichment sessions provide students with additional exposure to the course material, as well as review of relevant mathematical principles and techniques.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on participation in class activities, prelecture feedback, homework assignments, and three exams with individual and collaborative components.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Online access to course text, Physics for Scientists and Engineers by Knight, will be available through MasteringPhysics. Access codes are available for purchase at www.masteringphysics.com.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Permission may be obtained from Marc Royster, mjroyster@u.northwestern.edu

name: Mathematical Tools for the Physical Sciences

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This two-quarter course introduces the methods of reasoning and calculation common in the physical sciences. The goal is to learn how to calculate efficiently, accurately, and quickly, in physical contexts. Quarter 1 covers the functions of physics, dimensional analysis, small parameter expansions, complex-valued functions, vectors, simultaneous linear equations, the linear eigenvalue problem, and integration. Quarter 2 covers multiple integrals, nonCartesian coordinates, Gaussian integrals, the gamma function, Stirling's formula, probability distributions, constant coefficient linear differential equations, and Fourier analysis.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: PREREQUISITES: Physics 135-1, Math 220, 224 and 230 (or equivalent).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: It is intended that students will have basic competency in all the areas listed in the overview.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three 50-minute lectures weekly, graded homework and/or quiz assignment, reading assignments.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly evaluation by homework, quizzes or similar; 1 midterm, and 1 final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: None. Instructor will supply notes.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first course in a two-quarter sequence which covers advanced classical mechanics. Topics in 330-1 include Newtonian mechanics, conservation laws, Lagrangian mechanics, and central-force motion. Special topics may also be introduced.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Phyx 135-1,2,3, Math 220, 224, and 240, Math 250- have taken or concurrently enrolled in. Or equivalents.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three one-hour lectures and a one-hour discussion per week. New material can be introduced in discussion. It is not optional.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Final and one or more midterm examinations. Weekly problem sets.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Classical Mechanics , by John R. Taylor, ISBN: 978-1-891389-22-1


Previous Editions: Only 1 edition
Online/eBook available: No
Price Range: $17.99- $102.44
Other Purchases: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Quarter 2
(PHYS333-2): Electrodynamics. Faraday's law and (Maxwell's version of) Ampere's law, Maxwell equations; Potential formulation of electrodynamics; Poynting's theorem and other conservation laws in electrodynamics; Electromagnetic waves; Electromagnetic radiation.

PHYS361-0 continues advanced discussion of special relativity and electromagnetism.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Introduction to Electrodynamics, 4th Edition David J. Griffiths

Previous editions: Yes, 3rd or 4th edition preferred, 2nd edition acceptable
Online: Yes
Price Range: $64.46-$162.00
Other requirements: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students will learn to perform statistical analysis, give presentations, and write journal articles while reproducing some of the most important results in modern physics. Students will complete three experiments from a selection that includes Nuclear magnetic resonance, Saturated absorption spectroscopy, Entangled photons, Mossbauer spectroscopy, Muon lifetime, Gamma angular correlations, and the Chaotic pendulum.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: 333-1,2 or consent of instructor: 359-1 is not a prerequisite for 360-0.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn to give technical presentations, write reports in the style of journal articles, and do basic statistical data analysis while performing experiments in modern physics including nuclear and particle physics, atomic physics, quantum physics, condensed matter physics, and chaos.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Classes begin with one-hour lectures on statistical data analysis for the first part of the course, and with student presentations on the theory behind the experiments in the lab for the second part of the course. A three hour lab session follows the lecture or presentations.
Each student is to complete three experiments during the course.
Students perform labs in pairs and produce individual lab reports in the style of journal articles. Students have full access to the lab outside of class hours, once safety training requirements are satisfied.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The statistics portion of the course will conclude with an exam on basic statistical data analysis. Students will perform three experiments during the course - for each lab the student will give a 5-minute presentation, complete a short problem set, turn in a lab notebook, and write a lab report in the style of a journal article. Grades are based on the demonstrated understanding of the physics being studied, technical communication technique, correct quantitative data analysis, and success in meeting lab objectives. The final is a 1-hour presentation given to the instructor on one of the labs completed during the course. The final is graded in equal parts on the presentation of physics theory, experimental apparatus/procedure, and results/analysis.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Three firmly bound, quadrille ruled notebooks to keep daily records work in the laboratory (one notebook per lab).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
Statistical Data Analysis by- Glen Cowan, Oxford Press, ISBN: 978-0198501558

Previous Editions: Yes, any edition is fine
Online: Yes
Price: $44.04-$130.00
Other: Three firmly bound, quadrille ruled notebooks to keep daily records work in the laboratory (one notebook per lab).


Access to a word processing program such as Tex, OpenOffice Writer, or Microsoft Word. Handwritten or typed reports are accepted; however, modifications are much easier and quicker when word processing software is employed.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is an advanced course in classical mechanics, using Goldstein's classic "Classical Mechanics." We will cover Lagrangians, the two-body problem, small oscillations, rigid bodies, Hamiltonians, planetary dynamics and a bit of chaos.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Classical Mechanics by Goldstein, publisher- Addison-Wesley, ISBN- 978-0201029185

Previous Editions: Yes, 3rd or 2nd
Online/eBook available: No
Price Range: $28.69- $71.40
Other Purchases: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The topics covered will include a subset of: techniques for the solution of differential equations; approximations such as the method of steepest descent; techniques for integration; complex analysis; the special functions of mathematical physics; usage of Greens functions and eigenfunctions to solve differential equations; introduction to groups and group representations.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: You should know the basic mathematical techniques used in undergraduate physics classes: vector calculus, methods for the solution of ordinary and partial differential equations, linear algebra and basic complex variables. Brief reviews of these topics will be given as they are needed during the course.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on weekly homework assignments, a midterm exam, and a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
1. Mathematical Methods for Physicists 7th edition by Arfken and Weber
ISBN: 978-0123846549

Previous Editions: Yes, any edition is fine
Online/eBook available: Yes
Price Range: $18- $100
Other Purchases: None

2. "Mathematical Methods of Physics" - Mathews and Walker ISBN-13: 978-0805370027

Previous Editions: Yes, any edition is fine
Online/eBook available: No
Price Range: $42- $45
Other Purchases: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first of a three-quarter sequence of a graduate-level course on quantum mechanics and its applications to the microphysical world. This quarter will cover the mathematical and physical foundations of quantum mechanics, measurement theory, and applications to the mechanical oscillators, two-state systems, quantum tunneling and interference phenomena in atomic and sub-atomic systems.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Physics 339-1,2 or the equivalent.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three one-hour lectures per week.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Principles of Quantum Mechanics, 2nd edition, by R.Shankar, publisher- Plenum Press, ISBN- 978-0306447907

Previous Editions: No
Online/eBook available: Yes
Price Range: $30.00- $73.00
Other Purchases: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to the phenomena of superconductivity, superconducting materials and their many applications in basic science and technology. This is a lecture-based course on the basic theory and phenomenology of superconductivity and its applications. Fundamentals include the electrical and magnetic properties of superconductors, London's theory of the electromagnetic response of superconductors, Landau and Ginzburg's theory for the thermodynamics and magnetic properties of type I and type II superconductors, the origin of quantized magnetic flux, the Josephson effect, and the operation of Superconducting Quantum Interference Devices (SQUIDs) for high-precision magnetometry. Applications are wide ranging, from superconducting quantum electronics to superconducting radio-frequency cavities for particle accelerators.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: No graduate level prerequisites. Undergraduate-level knowledge of thermodynamics, and an undergraduate-level course on quantum mechanics will be assumed. In particular, this course does not require graduate-level quantum mechanics, solid-state physics or graduate-level statistical mechanics.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The course primarily consists of lectures. In addition there will be guest lectures by Drs. Anna Grassellino and Alex Romanenko from Fermi Lab. Also planned is a visit to the Superconducting RF Cavity Laboratory at Fermi National Lab.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Term paper and Oral report

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Lecture Notes provided by the instructors

Textbooks:
"Superconductivity" by J. B. Ketterson, Cambridge University Press (2000)

Previous Editions: No
Online: Yes
Price Range: $100- $115
Other Purchases: None

OR

"Introduction to Superconductivity" by Michael Tinkham, Dover, ISBN: 978-0486435039

Previous Editions: Any edition is okay
Online: No
Price Range: $20-$100
Other Purchases: None

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first quarter of a two quarter graduate sequence that will cover some aspects of condensed matter systems. The first quarter will be devoted to an introduction of the physics of electrons on a crystal lattice, including Bloch electrons, band structure, symmetries, semiclassical description of electrons in magnetic fields, and the Boltzmann equation description of electron transport. Towards the end, it will also introduce phonons. The second quarter will continue with phonons, and then cover electron-electron interactions, electron-phonon interactions, scattering of electrons from impurities, and magnetism.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Physics 414-1,2, or permission of the instructor.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two 90 minute classes per week.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly homework sets, a midterm examination and final examination.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: The course is based on lecture notes, so there is no required text. The first quarter is loosely based on Otto Madelung's introductory text, Introduction to Solid State Theory. Other texts that I will draw material from include Ashcroft and Mermin, Solid State Theory; Kittel, Introduction to Solid State Physics; and Ziman, Theory of Solids.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first quarter in a three-quarter sequence covering quantum field theory. Topics discussed in the sequence include: Lagrangian field theory, relativistic Lagrangians and relativistic wave equations, symmetries and conservation laws, canonical quantization, covariant perturbation theory, the S-Matrix, cross sections and lifetimes, elementary processes of quantum electrodynamics, quantum chromodynamics, and electroweak processes.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Phyx 412-1,2,3 (Quantum Mechanics)

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two 90-minute lectures per week.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: 70% from weekly homework assignments and 30% from a take-home final exam

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Quantum Field Theory and the Standard Model 1st Edition by Matthew Schwartz
ISBN-13: 978-1107034730

Previous Editions: None
Online/eBook available: Yes
Price Range: $33- $64
Other Purchases: None

name: Statistical Methods for Physicists and Astronomers

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Data analysis in the modern age requires familiarity of many concepts and methods from statistics. This course provides an introduction to the basics as well as exposure to some of the most advanced techniques. The emphasis will be on practical problems from physics and astronomy, rather than on theory or on statistical methods from other fields. Prior knowledge of statistics is not required. Homework assignments will require some numerical work on a computer.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Students should be able to write elementary computer programs
in python, C++, or C.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will be expected to understand what a probability density function is
and how to evaluate point estimators and confidence intervals. They should understand Bayes' Theorem
and grasp a variety of frequentist and Bayesian methods. They should be able to perform linear,
nonlinear, and multidimensional regression (e.g. curve fitting), and they should be comfortable with
Maximum Likelihood and Least Squares methods. They should understand hypothesis testing and
model selection.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Lectures two or three times per week, with extensive worked problems
as homework.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Homework scores, one in-class midterm exam, and a final written project.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
There is one required textbook.

1. G. Cowan, Statistical Data Analysis, Oxford Science Publications, 1998
ISBN-13: 978-0198501558

Previous Editions: There is only one edition
Online/eBook available: No
Price Range: $39.49- $59.66
Other Purchases: None

name: Introduction to Biological Physics: From Molecules to Cells (IBiS 410)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Quantitative approach to molecular and cell biology, focused on developing an understanding of connections between biomolecule structure and dynamics, and behavior of cells. The course will also include review of topics from statistics of random variables and statistical data analysis relevant to biology and biophysics.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Permission number required, contact Cathy Prullage, IBiS office

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Basic biophysics of cells and biomolecules. Experience setting up mathematical models of molecular dynamics and genetic processes inside cells, using analytical and numerical methods. Matlab programming methods will be taught.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Class lectures on core mathematical material, programming lectures.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Problem sets (5, 55%), in-class midterm (15%), final exam (30%).

descriptions.value: No required texts

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course, 108-1, is the first in a three-quarter sequence designed to introduce students to Polish language and culture. We learn the basic Polish grammar and vocabulary; we focus on speaking, reading, writing and listening.

As a complement to the linguistic side of the course, the student will gain a greater familiarity with Polish history and culture through varied means including readings of literary works, articles from contemporary Polish newspapers and movies.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
"Plato's Road to Resilience", Prof. Monoson Fall 2019
This seminar will guide students in a slow, close reading (in English translation) of a globally significant text from Greek antiquity that has had nearly unparalleled cross-cultural and historical impact on a wide range of areas of human creativity ? Plato's Republic. Well-known episodes in this text include the ship of state, allegory of the cave and the philosopher-ruler. Our group will pay special attention to some striking 21st century political resonances of episodes in the text (especially its account of the vulnerabilities of democracy and their links to the development of tyranny) as well as its sustained portrait of a "resilient" person. Assignments will include short seminar presentations. Frequent papers of varying lengths (from one paragraph to 3 pages). No final exam. Please obtain the edition of the Republic published by Cambridge Texts in the History of Political Thought entitled "Plato, The Republic," edited by GRF Ferrari, translated by Tom Griffith. Other supporting scholarship will be posted to the canvas site.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Short seminar presentations. Frequent papers of varying lengths (from one paragraph to 5 pages). No final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Plato, The Republic. Edited by G. R. F. Ferrari. Translated by Tom Griffith. Publisher: Cambridge University Press. (Cambridge Texts the History of Political Thought).

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Fall 2019 Prof. Stuelpnagel "The Press & The Political Process"
Presidents and presidential candidates often claim that the press is either "liberal" or "conservative." But many factors drive what the public receives as news. Those factors include: the economics of the business; information biases that come from striving to be "objective;" work routines by journalists; and the need to tell a story in a simple fashion so that readers and viewers can easily understand the subject. This fall we will be following the actions of the Trump administration, the reaction in Congress, the mid-term election and the on-going investigation into the possible collusion of the Trump campaign with Russia during the election. Trump declared the press is "the enemy of the people" during his campaign and now as president, what impact does that have on politics in America?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: There are several objectives for this class. The first is to give you a better understanding of how the press impacts presidential campaigns and, after the elections, the issues confronting the country. The second is to give you the opportunity to do independent research in this area and to train you in the proper methods of research and writing.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: This course is a seminar. You must come to class having done the assigned reading and you will be expected to participate in class discussion. There is no such thing as a bad or foolish question in this class. Our dialogues and discussions will be conducted in a respectful manor.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Your grade will be determined by your class participation (25%) and by your performance in three written papers (75%). Those papers will include a two-to-three-page Op-Ed opinion piece that is carefully researched and footnoted, a five-page book review, and a ten to twelve-page final term paper. All of your papers must be double spaced. In all of your work I want you to take a point of view. You can rewrite your Op-Ed and book review for a higher grade if it is below the B level, but the rewrites are due at the beginning of the next class period from when you first receive them back. Please submit first drafts of all of the assignments so that I can offer suggestions for improvement.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
News: The Politics of Illusion, Tenth Edition, W. Lance Bennett ISBN-10: 022634486X
The Political Science Student Writer's Manual, eighth edition by Gregory M. Scott and Stephen M. Garrison. The Political Science Student Writer's Manual, seventh edition by Gregory M. Scott and Stephen M. Garrison.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Fall 2019, "Alts, Populists, Neos, and Billionaires: Right Politics Worldwide in the 21st Century" Prof. Seawright The news is filled with accounts of novel right-leaning political movements: the alt-right, the Koch brothers, the National Front in France, Jair Bolsonaro's movement in Brazil. What kinds of politics do these seemingly diverse movements advocate? Are they similar enough to legitimately be grouped as "right" movements, or are they too distinctive? Are they just the old-fashioned right from the 20th century in new aesthetics, or have they changed substantively? We will explore these questions reading a series of books and articles about contemporary right-leaning political actors in the U.S., Europe, Latin America, and elsewhere.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: First-year student

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students who complete this seminar should be able to:

? summarize and evaluate arguments made by others;
? formulate persuasive arguments of their own, orally and in writing, based on the careful analysis of evidence;
? cite sources appropriately;
? write competently enough to satisfy the Weinberg College writing requirement;
? develop informed and creative accounts of 21st-century developments in right-leaning politics.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly short writing assignments culminating in a final term paper.

David Neiwert
Verso

Cas Mudde and Cristobal Rovira Kaltwasser
Oxford University Press

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Fall 2019 "Political Controversy/Political Skill" Prof. Court
This course presents a choice between enjoying the sensation of being right and the possibility of moving one's personal and political agenda forward in concrete ways. Lately, political culture has been almost exclusively about the former to the detriment of the latter. In this course, participants will exercise political skills in the classroom and apply them to their own political advocacy. This course stresses the radical difference between political skills and political punditry, one requiring practice and application, the other requiring only primitive rhetorical skills.

This course will ask students to develop their civic knowledge, communication abilities, and networks of relationships that will define their role as an active civic actor, providing genuine hands-on experience as an engaged citizen. Participants are asked to faithfully articulate views from a variety of perspectives, inevitably, from perspectives that run contrary to their own. The goal of political skill is distinct from debate, the later centered around winning, the former around understanding.

This course also introduces entering first-year students to Northwestern University, how to navigate the institution, the curriculum, and how to craft their own academic experience.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: First-year student

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Expectations: Students in this course are expected to do both individual writing and presentation work and group work. Groups will be selected at random at the beginning of the semester and be remixed before each new unit. Variation in political views among members of any group is expected. Responsibilities and roles in group discussions and debates will rotate. It is inevitable that students will articulate and advocate for political views that contrast with their own views. This is not an example of political indoctrination. Indeed, past experience has shown unequivocally that these activities tend to strengthen political views rather than weaken them. The goal of this class is to strengthen students analytical, argumentation, and presentation skills, the skills needed to move any agenda forward. Debates and discussions will be graded collectively?everyone receives the same grade?therefore it is the responsibility of members to keep each other on task throughout the semester.
Since face-to-face activities are all group activities, and that this is where the real work of the class will happen, attendance is mandatory. All students are required to attend every class meeting, and agree to be present and participating.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Discussion; Presentations; Reading Responses; Final Paper

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings on Canvas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Fall 2019 Prof. Will Reno "The American Way of War" This course surveys the changing American strategies in the conduct of warfare since the end of the Cold War in 1989. The course opens with a consideration of the massive military buildup and assault on Iraq in 1991. The American military presence in that region never went away. This presence provides us with a framework for analyzing the changing character of warfare. Consideration of the Iraq War (2003-2011) focuses on the development of counterinsurgency and the emergence of multi-domain warfare (i.e., political warfare, information warfare, etc.) and increased reliance on low-profile Special Operations Forces. Our attention then turns to recent challenges of hybrid warfare (i.e., hacking and fake news and their roles in conflicts), and the advent of flexible responses such as increased American reliance on drones and contractors in the conduct of warfare. The course ends with the consideration of several emerging American war-fighting strategies.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: First year students

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
By the end of this course, students should know:
1. Key features of recent American military strategy and how they affect important outcomes.
2. Differences across conflicts since 1991, key issues, nature and organization of US military strategy, and relevant policy making processes
3. Core concepts in comparative political analysis .
4. How to articulate a comparative empirical political theory and modify it in light of empirical evidence.
5. How to distinguish between normative arguments about military issues and questions that require empirical investigation.
6. How to construct a causal argument to explain variation in politically relevant outcomes.
7. How to apply a political science theory to analyze real world events.
8. How to write an analytic paper in political science.
9. How to effectively communicate comparative political analysis in written and oral forms.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion oriented seminar

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
? Class attendance and participation (20%): Every student is expected to attend every class meeting and come prepared to discuss the required reading material. Questions are provided for each meeting. These may provide a basis for discussion, and students are most welcome to pose other questions and issues.

? Four essays (20% each): In accordance with this course's status as a fall quarter first year seminar, students will expect it to focus on writing. These essays should be in the 6-8 page range. Due dates will be noted in the course schedule. Students will receive a memo at least ten days before each assignment is due. These memos will take into account discussions with students about possible essay topics.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Russell Weigley. 1973. The American Way of War: A History of United States Military Strategy and Policy. Indiana University Press (ISBN: 978-0-253-28029-9)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is an introduction to political theory. Students learn about the central themes, questions, and concepts that animate political theory and the history of political thought. They closely read and analyze canonical texts in the Western tradition, in addition to related texts from other traditions.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture & Discussion Sections

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Paper # 1: 25%
Paper # 2: 25%
Final exam: 25%
Class participation: 25%
