descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course provides an overview of Latin American literature and culture before the modernismo movement of the late nineteenth century. We will study a range of historical contexts and perspectives to consider how early literary texts and narratives shaped the formation of the so-called New World. Our readings will cover topics including colonization, class, gender, and race and will grapple with questions surrounding the problematic meanings of discovery, conquest, and identity. Together, we will consider not only the history of knowledge production in Latin America but also how that history highlights the limits of representation. With this goal in mind, we will explore distinct narrative forms, including but not limited to chronicles, letters, poems, illustrations, and forms of record keeping.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Survey of the modern period, including modernismo, the historical avant-garde, the "Boom," and recent literary trends. Authors such as Delmira Agustini, Jorge Luis Borges, Julio Cortázar, Rubén Darío, Gabriel García Márquez, José Martí, Pablo Neruda, Cristina Peri Rossi, and Elena Poniatowska.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: 220

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Huellas de la Literatura Hispanoamericanas

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course offers an overview of early 20th century avant-garde movements in Latin America and the historical contexts in which they emerged. In particular, it focuses on the main urban centers of vanguard practices in the region, including Buenos Aires, Mexico City, São Paulo, Havana, and Lima. We will pay special attention to how avant-gardist artists and writers negotiated foreign influence and local conditions, and how these movements conceived themselves as profoundly regional while speaking in an international idiom. We will emphasize the engagement with problematics in their local and global varieties, including race, gender, capitalism, imperialism and modernity.

Prerequisites: SPAN 250, 251, 260 or 261

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All reading materials will be available in Canvas

name: Visual Culture in Latina/o America and Spain
topic: Art As Idea: The Idea Of The Artist

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course aims at exploring the ways in which Latin American artists incorporated concerns, techniques, and methodologies of conceptualism into their practices since the early 1960s. We will look at the connections with mainstream (US-Western Europe) conceptual art, but we will concentrate on the differences to address issues of political activism, pedagogy, and art theory. Paying particular attention to the transition from art as craft to art as idea, we will inquire into how the studied works present a specific idea of the artist and its role in Latin American societies. The class will be in close dialogue with the exhibition Pop América, on view at the Block Museum during the Fall Quarter.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisite: 1 course from SPANISH 250-0, SPANISH 251-0, SPANISH 260-0, or SPANISH 261-0.

name: Topics in Latin American, Latina and Latino, and Iberian Literatures and Cultures
topic: Pop America - Art, Culture and Politics 1960s-1970

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course examines the participation and significant contribution of Latin American and Latinx artists and writers working at the same time and alongside their US and European counter parts in the turbulent decades of mid-20th century to construct a hemispheric vision of Pop Art. Introducing new historical frameworks reshapes debates over Pop's perceived political neutrality, social inclusiveness, and aesthetic innovations creating a vital dialogue that crosses national borders and connects the design of the Chicano/a movement in the US with the vivid images of the Cuban Revolution and innovations in the tradition of Mexican printmaking. We will highlight the Pop art's rich visual strategies and explore how these artists and writers, poets made bold contributions to conceptualism, performance, and new-media art, emphasizing their stance on social protest, justice movements across the continent, and debates about capitalist consumption, freedom and counter-culture. Analyzing the production of artists like Jorge de la Vega, Marta Minujin, Beatriz Gonzalez, Marisol, Helio Oiticica, Hugo Rivera Scott alongside Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein and Robert Indiana among others, we build transnational accounts and a full view of America following iconic Pop images as they travel between New York, Sao Paulo, Bogota, Mexico, San Francisco, Buenos Aires and La Habana.

This course is taught in English and in conjunction with the Block Museum exhibition Pop America so we will have a rich programming: a curator's talk, gallery visits and guest speakers.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All materials will be available in Canvas.

name: Topics in Latin American, Latina and Latino, and Iberian Literatures and Cultures

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Throughout the twentieth century, Latin America experienced a wave of violent and authoritarian dictatorships that threatened the survival not only of individual victims but of the respective nations whose democracies had been overturned. These regimes, with the support of foreign countries such as the United States, committed atrocities that the region still reckons with today. In their horror and unexpectedness, these atrocities?such as the genocide of indigenous communities; the illegal incarceration, torture, and sexual abuse of political dissidents; and the disappearance of victims' bodies?destabilized not only the regimes themselves but their democratic successors as well. This course addresses the question of survival through contemporary films that reflect upon the authoritarian regimes in Brazil (1964-85), Chile (1973-90), and Argentina (1976-83). Together, we will explore documentary and feature films that grapple with the effects that these regimes had?and continue to have?on society, politics, and international relations. While our focus will be on films released after 2000, we will turn to works of criticism to situate those films within historical cinematic traditions in Latin America.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will provide students with a nuanced understanding of topics of fin-de-siecle Latin American culture related to the market, aesthetics, and politics. We will explore the relationship between nineteenth-century cultural productions and material objects, focusing on the circulation and textual description of these objects. The idea is to understand how certain objects-including but not limited to gloves, watches, umbrellas, books, magazines, newspapers, photographs, albums, cloth, brooms and irons-and parts of the body-including hands, feet, and anuses-revealed an urgent new sensibility regarding material culture and a subsequent reorientation toward objects.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All materials will be made available on Canvas.

name: Topics in Latin American Literature and/or Iberian Literatures & Culture
topic: Seeing, Saying, Witnessing: Latin American Testimo

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course will focus on how Latin American testimonial narratives theorize as well as dramatize witness figures and scenes of witnessing that exceed the critical concepts and proposals brought to bear on such works; how specific testimonial texts not only construct but also interrogate their own witnesses. Reading and discussion will be anchored in close reading.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: The class will be conducted in English. Advanced reading knowledge of Spanish required (English translations of required Spanish originals will also be available, as needed).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: All readings will be available in Canvas.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
Primary verbal materials include: Rodolfo Walsh, Operación masacre, 1957; Ediciones de la Flor, 1972 [Engl: Operation Massacre, Seven Stories P, 2013); Rigoberta Menchú [Elizabeth Burgos-Debray], Me llamo Rigoberta Menchú y así me nació la conciencia, Siglo XXI, 1983 [Engl: I, Rigoberta Menchú, An Indian Woman in Guatemala, Verso, 1984]; Jacobo Timerman, Preso sin nombre, celda sin número, 1981; U of Wisconsin P/Ediciones de la Flor, 2000 [Engl: Prisoner without a Name, Cell without a Number, U of Wisconsin P, 2002]. Primary visual materials include: Jorge Cedrón, dir., Operación masacre, 1973; Patricio Guzmán, dir., Nostalgia de la luz, 2010.
Secondary materials will offer critical, theoretical, and historical frameworks for close reading and discussion.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Cryptology is the study of secret writing, or more generally secure communication. We will discuss classical methods of cryptography, followed by the use of the German Enigma machine during World War II, and end by discussing modern cryptosystems such as RSA and PGP, digital signatures, and their use in internet security.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Discussion and problem sets.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Presentations, problem sets, papers, class discussion.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Craig Bauer, Secret History: The Story of Cryptology.
Series: Discrete Mathematics and Its Applications (Book 76)
Hardcover: 620 pages
Publisher: Chapman and Hall/CRC; 1 edition (March 25, 2013)
Language: English
ISBN-10: 1466561866
ISBN-13: 978-1466561861

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Professor Zabell has a joint appointment in the Math and Statistics departments. His interests include mathematical probability, applied statistics, forensic science, and the history of cryptography.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces students to the discipline of statistics as the science of collecting, understanding, and analyzing data. Students will learn how to process, explore, and use data to make inferences and conclusions about real world phenomena. Students will also learn how to better recognize, evaluate, and consume the statistical evidence that regularly encounter during their everyday lives - news, social media, infotainment, etc.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Mastery of high school algebra.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Use statistical software to wrangle data (i.e., manage and process data).
2. Use statistical software to perform exploratory data analyses. That is, explore data numerically and visually to gain understanding through data and generate hypotheses and inferences to later test.
3. Recognize the importance of data collection, identify limitations in data collection methods, and determine how they affect the scope of inference.
4. Have a conceptual understanding of the unified nature of statistical inference.
5. Apply estimation and testing methods to analyze single variables or the relationship between two variables in order to understand natural phenomena and make data-based decisions.
6. Model numerical response variables using a single or multiple explanatory variable(s).
7. Interpret results correctly, effectively, and in context without relying on statistical jargon.
8. Critique data-based claims and evaluate data-based decisions.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated through (1) responses to requests for discussion/comment on topics through Canvas; (2) online homework; (3) labs/activities; (4) a midterm exam and; (5) a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
A laptop is required for this class as students are expected to bring it to class and work on labs/projects during this time. This requirement will not prevent students from taking this course. If access to a laptop is an issue, then please contact the course instructor (or department) and an accommodation will be made.

Free online textbook, Statistical Inference via Data Science (https://nulib.github.io/moderndive_book/)

name: Introductory Statistics for the Social Sciences

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class is titled Introductory Statistics for the Social Sciences. We will cover descriptive statistics, probability, random variables, sampling distributions, confidence intervals, and significance tests. At the end of the term, we will introduce regression.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: We will meet in lecture three times per week. We will meet in section once per week.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on problem sets, two midterm exams, and a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: The textbook for the course is Statistics for Business and Economics (Eighth Edition) by Paul Newbold, William L. Carlson, and Betty M. Thorne. We are using Statistics for Business and Economics: Second Custom Edition for Northwestern University, which includes just the first 11 chapters from the eighth edition. The ISBN-13 is 978-1-256-86179-9.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
NOTE: This section of the 301-1 course is open to declared Data Science minors only and requires Department permission to register. For more information on the new Minor in Data Science offered by the Department of Statistics starting in Fall 2019, see https://www.statistics.northwestern.edu/undergraduate/data_science_minor/

Course Overview:
As the initial course in the STAT 301 Data Science series, our objective is to build foundational analytical skills and knowledge for data science. While many data science problems will require knowledge of multiple coding languages and technologies, this course chooses to utilize R and RStudio to conduct data science. Students will develop skills to effectively manage, manipulate, and analyze data in R. These skills will be developed through project/lab based learning (1-2 projects/labs per week). The skills developed in this course are necessary for STAT 301-2 and STAT 301-3.

ATTENDANCE AT THE FIRST CLASS IS MANDATORY

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: At least a basic understanding of statistics is necessary (i.e. STAT 202 or 210). Some basic familiarity with R is desirable, but not entirely necessary as long as an effort is made to learn some basic R outside of class. Students should be prepared to spend approximately 5 to 9 hours outside of class per week working on this course - dependent on knowledge of R.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: (1) Students will be able to identify and follow the general steps/stages required to complete a typical data science project; (2) Students will learn and demonstrate the use of standard data science tools necessary to effectively and efficiently import, transform, visualize, model, and communicate data; and (3) Students will learn and demonstrate the use of programming techniques to further augment standard data science tools. (4) Students will be able to conduct and properly communicate a thorough exploratory data analysis.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: A typical class will devote about 10-20 minutes to discussion/lecture with the remaining time devoted to projects/labs where students will either work by themselves or in groups. Students will be expected to adequately prepare for each discussion/lecture by reviewing assigned material (e.g. readings, videos, etc?) because the majority of class time will be spent working on projects/labs - designed around the assigned material. Students will be expected to collaborate and engage with other students to help each other learn and solve problems. There will be a final project in place of a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: (1) R for Data Science by Hadley Wickham & Garrett Grolemund - Free online version: http://r4ds.had.co.nz/. (2) Students are expected to bring a laptop to class. This requirement will not prevent students from taking this course. If access to a laptop is an issue, then please contact the course instructor and an accommodation will be made.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: We will develop fundamental concepts of probability and statistical theory, with applications. Topics include sample spaces, probability measures, conditional probability, independence, random variables, distributions, expected values, variance, and limit theory. The sequels (320-2,3) emphasize statistical inference.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Calculus at the level of Math 234 (Multiple Integration) and a prior statistics course.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: We will develop fundamental concepts of probability and statistical theory, with applications. Topics include sample spaces, probability measures, conditional probability, independence, random variables, distributions, expected values, variance, and limit theory. The sequels (320-2,3) emphasize statistical inference.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Calculus at the level of Math 234 (Multiple Integration) and a prior statistics course.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)

ISBN-13: 9780534399429;
Mathematical Statistics and Data Analysis (3rd Edition);

Duxbury Press India

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Statistics 325 covers the essential statistical principles used in sampling human populations and many other populations. Topics include (1) sample designs such as simple random, stratified, and cluster sampling, (2) choosing the appropriate statistical estimators to use in conjunction with a given design, (3) accounting for non-response, and (4) estimating the sampling variances of estimators. The course does not cover questionnaire design.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
i. Calculus at level of Math 230 (differential calculus of multivariable functions), and
ii. Two previous courses in probability and statistics, including at least one at the 300 level in either Statistics (other than Stat 330), Econometrics, IE/MS, Math or MMSS.

If you do not meet both prerequisites (i) and (ii), you need permission of instructor. The formal mathematical level is not high but the conceptual level is challenging for many undergraduates. Statistics majors are encouraged but not required to take Stat 320 first. Graduate students should take Stat 425.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. Improve analysis of survey data
-use calibration estimators (ratio and regression estimators)
-account for complexity of design in analytic procedures
-to correctly estimate error in analyses

2. Improve design of sample surveys and other means for gathering statistical data.
-get the most accuracy for least cost
-be able to predict accuracy a priori
-be able to estimate precision a posteriori

3. Master enough basic principles, theory, and vocabulary to learn more on your own after this course.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Lecture

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class attendance + participation, homework exercises, midterm, final paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: No purchases are necessary. Slides used in lectures will be posted on CANVAS, along with more detailed lecture notes. No textbook is required. It is not a bad idea for students with professional interest in statistics to build a library and purchase and get acquainted with a good book on sampling, but no book purchase is required.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
A suggested but optional textbook is:
ISBN: 978-0495105275;
Sampling: Design and Analysis (2nd Edition);
Sharon L Lohr;
Brooks/Cole, Cengage Learning.

It is a required text for Stat 425 and can be found in the campus bookstore.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is primarily for graduate students who intend to design studies and analyze data. This course stands by itself and also serves as a background for further statistics courses, helping to provide the intuition which can sometimes be lost amid the formulas. Topics to be discussed include design of experiments, descriptive statistics, correlation and regression, probability, sampling, estimation and testing.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Graduate students.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two lectures per week plus discussion section.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Weekly homework, and final.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: We consider uses of statistics - as numbers and as methodology - for use in the context of Human Rights (HR). We take as HR those stipulated in existing international laws. The emphasis of the course is on the discovery and critique of statistical methods used in the HR context, including development, analysis, interpretation, use, and misuse of statistical data for description, assessment, evaluation, and political action. Examples of HR topics include missing females, deaths of combatants and noncombatants from war, disappearances, criminal justice, violence against women, trafficking, child labor, profiling, free elections, hunger, refugees, poverty, illegal immigration, hate crimes and discrimination

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: 2 of 325, 350, 320-2,3; ECON 381-1,2; MATH 386-1,2; IEMS 303, 304; or consent of instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
a. Describe ways that different statistical methods are used in different areas of human rights
b. Interpret the analyses based on the application of the methods for human rights
c. Understand how statistics are misused - intentionally and unintentionally - in human rights contexts
d. More readily tease out and critique unstated assumptions behind statistical analyses
e. Identify human rights issues to which statistical methods and data could be applied more effectively
f. Identify problems that need development of new statistical methods
g. Begin to develop and/or improve new statistical methods for human rights work
h. Learn some new statistical methods, although not as a primary goal nor emphasis of the course.
i. Learn to grapple with application of statistics to new and often ill-defined problems.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar; 2 80-minute meetings per week. The discussions often are led by the students. Extensive readings are required, and students are required to participate even when others lead the discussions.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will make 2 class presentations as seminar leader (@20% of grade) and submit 1 preliminary draft (@10% of grade) and 1 final draft (@15% of grade) of a substantial term paper. Students will also be graded on their participation in seminar discussions led by others (35% of grade). Students are required to meet multiple times with instructor to: develop presentation, choose term paper topic, and review rough draft of term paper (points subtracted from grade if students skip meetings or are unprepared).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Reading materials are provided in CANVAS or through electronic reserve at the library. No textbook purchase is required. Students will discover research materials with help of instructor and reference librarians.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: This is a different statistics class than any you have taken before, in part because it is run as a seminar and in part because the statistics so strongly depend on the context, which is complex.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The goal of the Statistics 420 sequence is to provide a comprehensive introduction to statistical theory and methodology at a level not requiring advanced probability theory (i.e., measure theory). Statistics 420-1 covers distribution theory. Distribution theory is concerned with probability distributions of random variables, particularly those concepts that arise frequently in statistical theory. The emphasis on this course is on the precise and careful statement of results and on the accurate determination of quantities such as moments, distribution functions, and so on, that are often used in statistical methodology. Prerequisites: A good background in calculus, real analysis (e.g., the concept of a limit), linear algebra, elementary probability theory, and statistical methods.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: A good background in calculus, real analysis (e.g., the concept of a limit), linear algebra, elementary probability theory, and statistical methods.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course surveys theory and methods for the analysis of categorical response and count data. Topics covered include the exact and approximate inference for contingency tables, logistic and Poisson regression, ordinal and multinomial logit models.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: Regression analysis and maximum likelihood methods of statistical theory.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grading: Based on assignments, projects, and presentation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Required: Agresti, A. (2002) Categorical Data Analysis, 2nd edition, New York: Wiley.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The purpose of this course is to provide an introduction to a variety of computational algorithms for Bayesian inference. Two types of methods are considered in detail: observed data and data augmentation methods. The observed data methods are applied directly to the likelihood or to the posterior density. These include: Newton- Raphson, Laplace's method, Monte Carlo and Metropolis methods. The data augmentation methods rely on an augmentation of the data which simplifies the likelihood or posterior density. These include: EM, Data Augmentation, Poor Man's Data Augmentation and the Gibbs sampler. All methods are motivated and illustrated with real examples.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Stat 420-1,2,3 are prerequisites

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This course provides the student with a good introduction to Bayesian inference, the ability to read application papers, and the ability to apply these methods to problems of interest to the student. Students understand at a heuristic level how the methods work and when a given method may be preferred over another.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first part of a three-quarter sequence of beginning Swahili. The course equips learners with the necessary listening, speaking, reading and writing skills so as to understand basic Swahili. We shall learn about the history of Swahili language, its place in East Africa, and discuss how to interact with Swahili speakers in culturally appropriate ways. Through a combination of lectures, lab sessions and performance of cultural and communicative activities, learners will gain an understanding of basic Swahili grammatical structures and cultural insights of the people of East Africa. No prior knowledge of Swahili is required to enroll in this course.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: On completion of the course, students should be able to appreciate basic cultural practices of the Swahili speaking people. They should also comprehend basic Swahili and use simple grammatical constructions to perform day-to-day linguistic functions such as greetings, self-introduction and interpersonal conversations.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The final grade will be based on the following seven major areas of language use: attendance and participation (10%), homework (15%), Portfolio (15%), two sit-in quizzes (15%), Mid-term exam (15%), final exam (20%), and participation in either four language tables, PAS Wednesday lunch lectures, and cultural events or a combination of any four of them (10 %).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
(these texts also apply to the Winter and Spring "Swahili I" courses):
1. Hinnebusch, Thomas J. and Sarah Mirza. Kiswahili: Msingi wa Kusema, Kusoma na Kuandika, 2nd Ed. Lenham, Maryland: University Press of America, 1998
2. Swahili-English, English-Swahili Practical Dictionary (Hippocrene Practical Dictionary) by Nicholas Awde.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first part of a three-quarter sequence of Intermediate Swahili. The course builds on the foundation established in beginning Swahili. It is designed to enhance students' communicative skills and a deeper cultural awareness about Swahili and East Africa. To enroll in the course, a student is required to have satisfactorily completed the three levels of beginning Swahili or the equivalent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The course will generally focus on polishing and enhancing student comprehension and communicative skills. Although the primary goal of the course is to strengthen the five skill areas of reading, writing, speaking, listening and culture, emphasis will be placed on the productive and receptive oral-aural skills of speaking and listening respectively. There will, therefore, be a deliberate tilt towards conversation practice as a means of strengthening student competence in communicative skills.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The class employs a combination of lectures, lab sessions and group performances, and will be conducted almost exclusively in Swahili with a lot of conversation practice. Authentic texts will be introduced to supplement the primary textbook, covering various Swahili registers, including but not limited to literary excerpts, newspaper articles, radio broadcasts and other available Swahili material. Such materials are aimed at introducing the students to current and more specialized Swahili vocabulary. Students will engage in Swahili cultural activities and class presentations that will be conducted mainly in Swahili. By the end of the course, students are expected to be able to understand and express themselves orally and in writing at an intermediate level.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The final grade will be based on the following seven major areas of language use: attendance and participation (10%), homework (15%), weekly journal entries (10%), two sit-in quizzes (20%), Mid-term exam (20%), final exam (15%) and participation in either four language tables, PAS Wednesday lunch lectures, and cultural events or a combination of any four of them (10 %).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1. Muaka, L., & Muaka, A. (2006). Tusome Kiswahili: A Multidimensional Approach to the Teaching and Learning of Swahili as a Foreign Language. NALRC Press: Madison, WI.
2. Swahili - English, English - Swahili Practical Dictionary (Hippocrene Practical Dictionary) by Nicholas Awde.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
First-year Turkish (Turkish 111) is a three-quarter introductory course in modern Turkish. This course aims to introduce students to the essential points of modern Turkish grammar and vocabulary to develop basic reading, writing, speaking and listening skills. The course also provides insights into modern Turkish culture through the language. With this in mind, the textbook is supplemented by additional printed and audio-visual materials provided by the instructor.

Turkish 111-1, taught in the Fall Quarter, is the first quarter of first-year Turkish. The course aims to introduce students to the essential points of modern Turkish grammar and vocabulary to develop basic reading, writing, speaking and listening skills. The course also provides insights into modern Turkish culture through the language. We use texts an audio centered around topics in Elementary Turkish I as well as work with additional printed audio and video material provided by the instructor. The course covers units 1-7 in Elementary Turkish I. Bi-weekly Turkish Language Table meetings allow students additional opportunities to practice speaking and listening skills, and further exposure to Turkish culture. The course ends with a class trip to a Turkish restaurant in Chicago where students will be able to communicate in Turkish outside of the classroom and utilize the skills they developed throughout the quarter. No prior knowledge of Turkish is necessary.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: There are no prerequisites for the course.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students completing three quarters of Turkish 111 will be able to read and comprehend simple, authentic texts on familiar topics, write informal notes and short paragraphs on topics connected to daily life, and to initiate and sustain conversations on daily-life topics with educated native speakers.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: First-year Turkish uses a communicative, proficiency-oriented approach with fully integrated audiovisual media to teach modern Turkish as a living language. The instructor will use an interactive approach in the classroom, including reading, translations, listening and conversational practice as interactive small group exercises.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
The final grade for the course will be based on the following criteria:
- Class participation and attendance,
- Homework consisting of (but not limited to) assignments from the exercises in the textbook and handouts,
- Grammar and vocabulary quizzes to determine the general level of progress in the classroom,
- One midterm and one final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Elementary Turkish: A Complete Course for Beginners. Revised Third Edition (2015). Kurtulu? Öztopçu. Kebikeç-Yay?nlar? Sanat Kitabevi. ISBN: 978-975-7981-40-4.
The two-volume textbook can be purchased online at http://www.elementaryturkish.com/buy/. Please purchase the print book, not the e-book. Additional materials will be provided by the instructor.

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value: Full attendance and active class participation are strongly encouraged for the successful completion of the course. In addition to regular participation in class activities, it is important to complete all your homework on time.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Second-year Turkish (Turkish 121) is a three-quarter intermediate course in modern Turkish. This course aims to continue basic Turkish grammar, and further develop reading, writing, speaking and listening skills acquired in elementary Turkish, through the use of printed and audio-visual materials. The course also provides insights into modern Turkish culture through the language.

Turkish 121-1, taught in the Fall Quarter, is the first quarter of second-year Turkish. The course builds on material learned in first-year Turkish by introducing additional grammar and sentence structures, by presenting new vocabulary, and by providing students ample opportunities to practice and expand all skills. We will continue to use texts and audio centered around topics in Elementary Turkish II as well as work with additional printed audio and video material provided by the instructor. The course overs Units 18-22 in Elementary Turkish II. Bi-weekly Turkish Language Table meetings allow students additional opportunities to practice speaking and listening skills, and further exposure to Turkish culture. The course ends with a class trip to a Turkish restaurant in Chicago where students will be able to communicate in Turkish outside of the classroom and utilize the skills they developed throughout the quarter.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Turkish 111-3 or equivalent; or instructor's consent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students completing three quarters of Turkish 121 will be able to understand and produce passages in written Turkish of medium length, understand spoken Turkish and engage in spoken discourse of medium complexity on everyday topics.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Second-year Turkish uses a communicative, proficiency-oriented approach with fully integrated audiovisual media to teach modern Turkish as a living language. The instructor will use an interactive approach in the classroom, including reading, translations, listening and conversational practice as interactive small group exercises.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method

The final grade for the course will be based on the following criteria:
- Class participation and attendance,

- One midterm and one final exam.
